editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To my much honoured friend TOBIAS GARBRAND, Doctor of Phy≈øick, and Principall of Glocester-hall, in OXFORD.
div.p:
IT is my ambition to let the world know upon what ≈øcore it is that I do e≈øpecially honour men. It is not Sir! as they are high born Heirs of the great Potentates, for which mo≈øt honour them (and upon which account I al≈øo ≈øhall not deny them their due) but as they excell in hone≈øty, and are friends to Art. That poor Philo≈øophers ≈øhould take no delight in riches, and rich men ≈øhould take great delight in Philo≈øophy, is to me an argument, that there
is more delight, honor, and ≈øatisfaction in the one then in the enjoyment of the other. I once read of a Noble mans Porter that let in all that were rich apparelled, but excluded a poor Philo≈øopher: but I ≈øhould, if I had been in his place, have rather let in the Philo≈øopher without the gay cloathes, then the gay cloathes without the Philo≈øopher. As long as I have ≈øen≈øe or rea≈øon, I ≈øhall improve them to the honour of Art, e≈øpecially that of Alchymie. In the perfection thereof there are riches, honour, health, and length of dayes: by it Arte≈øius lived 1000. years, Flammell built 28 Ho≈øpitalls with large revenues to them, be≈øides Churches and Chappels; for it; both they and divers more were accounted Philo≈øophers, and wi≈øe men, which ≈øounds more honourable in my eares then all the ratling and empty titles of honour what≈øoever be≈øides. In the perfection of this Art, I mean the accompli≈øhing of the Elixir, is the Sulphur of Philo≈øophers ≈øet at liberty, which gratifies the relea≈øers thereof with three Kingdomes, viz. Vegetable, Animall, and Minerall, and what cannot they do, and how honourable are they, that have the command of the≈øe? They may command Lead into Gold, dying plants into fruitfulne≈ø≈øe, the ≈øick into health, old age into youth, darkne≈ø≈øe into light, and what not? A month would fail to give you an account of their power and dominations. Now for the effecting of this I ≈øhall be≈øides what I have advi≈øed in the Epi≈øtle to the Reader, ≈øay only this; Court the Mother, and you winne the Daughter, prevail with Nature, and the fair Diana of the Philo≈øophers is at your ≈øervice.

Now if you cannot prevaile with Nature for the faire≈øt of her daughters, viz. the Mercury of Philo≈øophers, yet ≈øhe hath other Daughters of wonderfull beauty al≈øo, as
are the E≈ø≈øences and Magi≈øteries of Philo≈øophers, which al≈øo are endowed with riches, honour, and health‚ñ™ and any of the≈øe you may more ea≈øily prevail with their mother Nature for. This Art of Alchymie is that S ‚Ä¢ lary Art, which is more noble then all the other ≈øix Arts, and Sciences, and if it did once throughly ≈øhine forth out of the clouds whereby it is eclip≈øed, would darken all the re≈øt, (as the Sun doth the other ≈øix planets) or at lea≈øt ≈øwallow up their light. This is that true naturall Philo≈øophy which mo≈øt accurately anatomizeth Nature and naturall things, and ocularly demon≈øtrates the principles and operations of them. That empty naturall philo≈øophy which is read in the Univer≈øities, is ≈øcarce the meane≈øt hand-maid to this Queen of Arts. It is pity there is ≈øuch great encouragement for many empty and unprofitable Arts, and none for this, and ≈øuch like ingenuities, which if promoted would render an Univer≈øity far more flouri≈øhing then the former. I once read or heard of a famous Univer≈øity beyond Sea, that was faln into decay, through what cau≈øe I know not: but there was a generall councell held by the learned, how to re≈øtore it to its primitive glory. The Medium at la≈øt agreed upon was the promoting of Alchymie, and encouraging the Arti≈øts them≈øelves. But I never expect to ≈øee ≈øuch rationall actings in this Nation, till ≈øhadows vani≈øh, ≈øub≈øtances flouri≈øh, and truth prevail: which time I hope is at hand and de≈øired by all true Arti≈øts, and to my knowledge, e≈øpecially by your ≈øelf, upon which account I truly honour you. Now to your ≈øelfe therefore I crave leave to adumbrate ≈øomething of that Art which I know you will be willing for the publick good to promote. I dedicate this Treati≈øe to you, not that it is
worthy your acceptance, but that it may receive worth by your accepting of it. I pre≈øent it to you (as men bring lead to Philo≈øophers to be tinged into gold) to receive the ≈øtamp of your favour, and approbation, that it may pa≈øt currant, with acceptance among≈øt the ≈øons of Art, whereby you will continue to oblige him who is

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt obliged Servant, JOHN FRENCH.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
THere is a glut of Chymicall books, but a ≈øcarcity of Chymicall truthes: Nature and Art affords variety of Spagyricall preparations, but they are as yet partly undi≈ø ‚Ä¢ overed, partly di≈øper≈øed in many books and tho≈øe of divers Languages, and partly re≈øerved in private mens hands. When therefore I con≈øidered what need there is of, and how acceptable a generall treati≈øe of Distillations might be, e≈øpecially to our Engli≈øh Nation (and the rather ≈øince Baker upon Di≈øtillations is by rea≈øon of the de≈øcription of a few furnaces, and ve≈ø≈øels therein, be≈øides which there is ≈ømall variety either of preparations, or curio≈øities, ≈øold at ≈øuch a high rate) I thought I could do them no better ≈øervice then to pre≈øent them with ≈øuch a treati≈øe of that ≈øubject, which ≈øhould contain in it the choi≈øe≈øt preparations of the ≈øelecte≈øt Authors both ancient and moderne, and tho≈øe of ≈øeverall languages, and which I have attained by my own long, and manuall experience, together with ≈øuch as I have by way of exchange purcha≈øed out of the hands of private men, ‚Ä¢ hich they had monopolized as great ≈øecrets. But on the other hand when I con≈øidered what a multitude of Arti≈øts there are in this Nation, from many of which more and better things might be expected then from my ≈øelf, I was at a nonplus in my re≈øolutions, fearing it might be accounted an unpardonable pre≈øumption in me to undertake that which might be better performed by others. But for the avoiding of this a≈øper≈øion, be plea≈øed to under≈øtand that I pre≈øent not this to the world under any other notion then of a rough draught (which indeed is the worke of the more unskilfull, and therefore of my ≈øelf, without exception) to be poli≈øhed by
the more expert Arti≈øt. I rejoyce as at the break of the day after a long tedious night, to ≈øee how this ≈øolary art of Alchymie begins for to ≈øhine f ‚Ä¢ rth out of the clouds of reproach which it hath a long time unde≈øervedly layen under. There are two things which have a long time eclip≈øed it, viz. the mi≈øts of ignorance, and the ≈øpecious lunary body of deceit. Ari≈øe O Sun of truth, and di≈øpell the≈øe interpo≈øed fogs, that the Queen of Arts may triumph in ≈øplendour! If men did beleeve what this Art could effect, and what variety there is in it, they would be no longer ≈øtraightned by, nor bound up to or jurare in verba Galeni, vel Ari≈øto ‚Ä¢ elis, but would now ≈øub≈øcribe a new engagement to be true and faithfull to the principles of He ‚Ä¢ mes, and Parace ‚Ä¢ ≈øus, as they ≈øtand e≈øtabli≈øhed without Ari≈øto ‚Ä¢ le their prince, and Galen, and Hippocrates, their lords and ma≈øters. They would no longer ≈øtand dreaming forth, Sic dicit Galenus, but Ip≈øe dixit Hermes. I de≈øire not to be mi≈øtaken as if I did deny Galen his due, or Hippocrates what is his right, for indeed they wrote excellently in many things, and de≈øerved well thereby; That which I cannot allow of in them is their ≈øtrict ob≈øervation of the quadruplicity of humours (which in the ≈øchoole of Paracel≈øus, and writings of Helmont, where the Anatomy of humours hath been mo≈øt rationally and fully di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, hath been ≈øufficiently confuted) and their confining them≈øelves to ≈øuch crude medicines, which are more fit to be put into Spagyricall ve≈øsels for a further dige≈øtion, then into mens bodies to be fermented therein. Certainly if men were le≈ø≈øe ignorant they would preferre cordiall e≈ø≈øences before crude juices, bal≈øamicall Elixirs before flegmatick waters, the Mercury of philo≈øophers before common quick≈øilver. But many men have ≈øo little in≈øight in this Art, that they ≈øcarce believe any thing in it beyond the Di≈øtilling of Waters and Oils, and extracting of Salts; nay many that pretend to Philo≈øophy, and would
be accounted Philo≈øophers, are ≈øo unbeleeving, that, as ≈øaith Sandivogius, although he would have intimated the true Art to them word by word, yet they would by no meanes under≈øtand or beleeve that there was any water in the Philo≈øophers ≈øea. And as he in this ca≈øe, ≈øo I in another know divers that will not beleeve that common quick≈øilver can of it ≈øelfe be turned wholy into a tran≈øparent water, or that gla≈ø≈øe can be reduced into ≈øand and ≈øalt of which it was made, ≈øaying that fu≈øio vitrificatoria e≈øt ultima fu≈øio; or that an hearb may be made to grow in two hours, and the Idea of a plant to appear in a gla≈ø≈øe, as if the very plant it ≈øelfe were there, and this from the e≈ø≈øence thereof, and ≈øuch like preparations as the≈øe: the two former whereof may be done in half an hour, but the latter requires a longer time, but yet pos≈øible. And for the po≈ø≈øibility of the Elixir, you ≈øhall a≈ø≈øoon per≈øwade them to beleeve they know nothing (which is very hard, nay an impo≈ø≈øible thing to do) then to beleeve the po≈ø≈øibility thereof. If there be any ≈øuch thing (≈øay they) why are not the po≈ø≈øe≈øsors thereof infinitely rich, famous, do many miracles and cures, and live long? The≈øe Objections, e≈øpecially ≈øome of them, ≈øcarce de≈øerve an an≈øwer; yet I ≈øhall to ≈øhew the vanity of them make ≈øome reply thereunto. Did not Arte≈øius by the help of this medicine live 1000. yeares? Did not Flammell build fourteen Ho≈øpitals in Paris be≈øides as many in Boleigne, be≈øides Churches, and Chappels with large revenews to them all? Did not Bacon do many miracles? and Paracel≈øus many miraculous cures? Be≈øides what ≈øaith Sandivogius? I have, ≈øaith he, incurred more dangers, and difficulties by di≈øcovering my ≈øelf to have this ≈øecret, then ever I had profit by it, and when≈øoever I would di≈øcover my ≈øelfe to the great Ones, it alwayes redounded to my prejudice, and danger. Can a man that carrieth alwaies about him 10000. pounds worth of Jewels and gold, travel every where up and
downe, ≈øafe, and not be robbed? Have not many rich moneymongers been tortured into a confe≈ø≈øion where their money was concealed? Did you never heare of a vapouring fellow in London, that portending to the knowledge of this My≈øtery was on a ≈øuddaine caught a≈øide by money-thir≈øters, and by them tormented with tortures little le≈øse then tho≈øe of hell, being forced thereby (if he had knowne it) into a di≈øcovery of it? To ≈øay nothing of being in danger of being ≈øubjected, and en≈ølaved to the plea≈øure of Princes, and of becoming in≈øtrumentall to their luxury, and tyranny, as al≈øo being deprived of all liberty, as once Raimundus Lullius. The truth is, the greate≈øt matter that Philo≈øophers aime at, is the enjoyment of them≈øelves, for which cau≈øe they have ≈øequestred them≈øelves from the world, and become Hermites: Well therefore and like a Philo≈øopher ≈øpake Sandivogius, when he ≈øaid, Beleeve me, if I were not a man of that ≈øtate and condition that I ‚Ä¢ m of, nothing would be more plea≈øant to me then a ≈øolatary life, or with Diogenes to live hid under a tub; for I ≈øee all things in this world to be but vanity, and that deceit, and covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe prevail much, that all things are vendible, and that vice doth excel vertue. I ≈øee the better things of the life to come before mine eyes, I rejoice in the≈øe: Now I do not wonder, as before I did, why Philo≈øophers when they have attained this medicine, have not cared to have their daies ≈øhortned, (although by the vertue of their medicine they could have prolonged them) for every Philo≈øopher hath the life to come ≈øo cleerly ≈øet before his eyes, as thy face is ≈øeen in a gla≈ø≈øe. Thus much by way of reply to the frivolous objections of tho≈øe that beleeve not the verity of this Art, and not onely ≈øo, but will not beleeve it. If you ≈øhould di≈øcover to them the proce≈ø≈øe of the Philo≈øophers ≈øtone, they would laugh at your ≈øimplicity, and I will warrant you never make u≈øe of it. Nay if you ≈øhould
make projection before them, they would think that even in that there were a fallacy, ≈øo unbeleeving are they: ≈øo I finde them, and ≈øo I leave them, and ≈øhall for ever finde them the ≈øame.

There is another ≈øort of men by whom this Art hath been much ≈øcandalized, and they indeed have brought a great Odium upon it by carrying about, and vending their whites, and reds, their ≈øophi≈øticated oils, and ≈øalts, their dangerous and ill prepared Turbithes, and Aurum vitae's. And indeed it were worth while, and I might do good ≈øervice for the Nation, to di≈øcover their cheats, as their ≈øophi≈øticating of Chymicall oils with ≈øpirit of Turpentine, and ≈øalts with ≈øalt extracted out of any wood-a≈øhes and ≈øuch like, but here is not place for ≈øo large a di≈øcour≈øe as this would amount to. I ≈øhall only at this time relate to you how Penotus was cheated with a ≈øophi≈øticated Oil of gold: for, ≈øaith he, I gave 24. duckets for the proce≈ø≈øe of an Aurum potabile which was much cryed ‚Ä¢ p and magnified at Prague, but at la≈øt it proved to be nothing but a mixture of oil of Camphire, Cloves, Fennel-≈øeed, and of Vitriall tinged with the leaves of Gold. I know I ≈øhall incurre the di≈øplea≈øure of ≈øome, but they are ≈øophisticating, cheating mountebaÃÑcks, who indeed de≈øerve to be bound to the peace, becau≈øe many men, I dare ≈øwear, through their means go in danger of their lives. Better it is that their knavery ≈øhould be detected, then a noble Art through their villany be clouded, and a≈øper≈øed.

Now we mu≈øt con≈øider that there are degrees in this Art; for there is the accompli≈øhing of the Elixir it ≈øelf, and there is the di≈øcovering of many excellent e≈ø≈øences, magi≈øteries, and ≈øpirits, &c. which abundantly recompen≈øe the di≈øcoverers thereof with profit, health, and delight. Is not Paracel≈øus his Ludus that di≈ø≈øolves the ≈øtone, and all tartarous matter in the body into a liquor, worth finding out?
Is not his Tinea Scatura a mo≈øt noble medicine, that extingui≈øheth all preternaturall heat in the body in a moment: Is not his Altahe≈øt a famous di≈ø≈øolvent, that can in an in≈øtant di≈ø≈øolve all things into their first principles, and withall is a ≈øpecificum again≈øt all di≈øtempers of the liver? who would not take paines to make the quinte≈ø≈øence of honey‚ñ™ and the Philo≈øophicall ≈øpirit of Wine, which are cordiall and bal≈øamicall even to admiration? A whole day would fail to reckon up all the excellent, admirable rar ‚Ä¢ ties that by this ≈øpagyricall Art might be brought to light, in the ≈øearching out of which, why may not the Elixir it ≈øelfe at la≈øt be attained unto? Is it not po≈ø≈øible for them that pa≈ø≈øe through many Philo≈øophicall preparations to unfold at la≈øt the riddles, and Hieroglyphicks of the Philo≈øophers? or were they all meer Phanta≈ømes? Is there no fundamentum in re for this ≈øecret? Is there no ≈øperme in gold? Is it not po≈ø≈øible to exalt it for multiplication? Is there no univer≈øall ≈øpirit in the world? Is it not po≈ø≈øible to finde that collected in one thing, which is di≈øper≈øed in all things? What is that which makes gold incorruptible? What induced the Philo≈øophers to examine gold for the matter of their medicine? Was not all gold once living? Is there none of this living gold, the matter of Philo≈øophres, to be had? Did Sandivogius the la≈øt of knowne Philo≈øophers ≈øpend it all? Surely there is matter enough for Philo≈øophers, and al≈øo ≈øome Philo≈øophers at this day for the matter, although they are unknowne to us. There are, ≈øaith Sandivogius, without doubt many men of a good con≈øcience both of high and low degree (I ≈øpeak knowingly) that have this medicine, and keep it ≈øecretly. If ≈øo, let no man be di≈øcouraged in the pro≈øecution of it, e≈øpecially if he take along with him the five Keyes‚ñ™ which Nollius ≈øets down,
which indeed all Philo≈øophers with one con≈øent enjoyne the u≈øe and ob≈øervation of.
1. Seeing it is a thing divine, and cele≈øtiall, it mu≈øt be ≈øought for from above, and that not without a full re≈øolution for a pious, and charitable improvement of it.

2. Before thou betake≈øt thy ≈øelfe to the worke, propound to thy ≈øelfe what thou ≈øeeke≈øt for, and enter not upon the practicke till thou art fir≈øt well ver≈øed in the theory, for it is much better to learn with thy braines, and imagination, then with thy hands, and co≈øts, and e≈øpecially ≈øtudy nature well; and ≈øee if thy propo≈øals be agreeable to the po≈ø≈øibility thereof.

3. Diligently read the ≈øayings of true Philo≈øophers, read them over again and again, and meditate on them, and take heed thou doe≈øt not read the writings of Impo≈øters in ≈øtead of the Books of the true Philo≈øophers. Compare their ≈øayings with the po≈ø≈øibility of Nature, and ob≈øcure places with cleare, and where Philo≈øophers ≈øay they have erred doe thou beware, and con≈øider well the generall axioms of Philo≈øophers, and read ≈øo long till thou ≈øee≈øt a ≈øweet Harmony, and con≈øent in the ≈øayings of them.

5. If it be po≈ø≈øible, acquaint thy ≈øelf throughly with ≈øome true Philo≈øophers. Although they will not directly di≈øcover them≈øelves that they have this ≈øecret, yet by one circum≈øtance or another it may be concluded how neer they are to it. Would not any rationall man that had been conver≈øant with Bacon, and ≈øeeing him doe ≈øuch miraculous things,
or with Sandivogius who did intimate the Art to ≈øome word by word, have concluded that they were not ignorant of it? There have been Philo≈øophers, and perhaps ≈øtill are, that although they will not di≈øcover how it is made, yet may certifie you, to the ≈øaving of a great deal of co≈øt, pains, and time, how it is not made: and to be convinced of an errour is a great ≈øtep to the truth. If Ripley had been by any Tutor convinced of tho≈øe many errours before he had bought his knowledge at ≈øo deare a rate, he had long before, with le≈ø≈øe charges attained to his ble≈ø≈øed de≈øire.

And as a friendly Tutor in this, ≈øo in all ≈øpagyricall preparations what≈øoever, is of all things mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary. A faithfull well experienced ma≈øter will teach thee more in the my≈øteries of Alchymy in a quarter of a year, then by thine owne ≈øtudies and chargeable operations thou ≈øhalt learn in ≈øeven yeares. In the fir≈øt place therefore, and above all things apply thy ≈øelfe to an expert, faithfull, and comm ‚Ä¢ nicative Arti≈øt, and account it a great gain, if thou can≈øt purcha≈øe his favour, though with a good gratuity, to lead thee through the manuall practice of the chiefe≈øt, and choi≈øe≈øt preparations. I ≈øaid apply thy ≈øelf to an Arti≈øt, for there is ≈øcarce any proce≈ø≈øe in all Chymi≈øtry ≈øo ea≈øie that he that never ≈øaw it done will be to ≈øeek, and commit ≈øome errours in the doing of it. I ≈øaid expert, that he may be able to in≈øtruct thee aright; faithful, that as he is able, ≈øo may faithfully performe what he promi≈øeth; and communicative, that he may be free in di≈øcovering him≈øelfe and his Art to thee. The truth is, mo≈øt Arti≈øts re≈øerve that to them≈øelves, which they know, either out of a de≈øire to be admired the more for their undi≈øcovered ≈øecrets, or out of envie to others knowledge. But how far this humour is approvable in them, I leave it to others to judge; and as for my part I have here
communicated upon the account of a bare acceptance onely what I have with many years paines, much reading, and great co≈øts known. There is but one thing which I de≈øire to be ≈øilent in as touching the proce≈ø≈øe thereof; as for the thing it ≈øelfe to be prepared, what it is I have el≈øewhere in this Treati≈øe expre≈øsed; and the preparing of that is indeed a thing worthy of any ones knowing, and which perhaps hereafter I may make known to ≈øome. I am of the ≈øame mind with Sandivogius, that that fourth Monarchy which is Northerne, is d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ning, in which (as the ancient Philo≈øophers did divine) all Arts and Sciences ≈øhall flouri≈øh, and greater and more things ≈øhall be di≈øcovered then in the three former. The≈øe Monarchies the Philo≈øophers reckon not according to the more potent, but according to the corners of the world, whereof the Northerne is the la≈øt, and indeed is no other then the golden age, in which all tyranny, oppre≈ø≈øion, envie, and covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe ≈øhall cea≈øe, when there ≈øhall be one prince and one people abounding with love and mercy, and flouri≈øhing in peace: which day I earne≈øtly expect.

In the mean time if what I know may adde to thy experience, thou ha≈øt it freely. And if I ≈øhall ≈øee that this Treati≈øe of Di≈øtillation pa≈ø≈øe with acceptance umong≈øt the Arti≈øts of this Nation, I ≈øhall hereafter gratifie them for their good will with two other parts of Chymi≈øtrie, viz. Sublimaton, and Calcination; and I hope this will be an occa≈øion to ≈øet the more expert Arti≈øts on work, for the communicating their experiences to the world. One thing (courteous Reader) let me de≈øire thee to take notice of, viz. whereas every proce≈ø≈øe is ≈øet down plain, yet all of them mu≈øt be proceeded in ≈øecundum Artem Alchymi≈øtae, (which Art indeed is obtained by experience) and therefore many that work according to the bare proce≈ø≈øe effect not what they intend;
and the rea≈øon is, becau≈øe there was ≈øome art of the Alchymi≈øt wanting. To conclude, if thou knowe≈øt more or better things then the≈øe, be candid, and impart them; (con≈øidering that I wrote the≈øe for them that know them not) if not, accept of the endeavours of thy Friend

div.head: What di≈øtillation is; and the kinds thereof.
div.p: I Shall not ≈øtand here to ≈øhew whence the Art of Di≈øtillation had its originall, as being a thing not ea≈øily to be proved, and if known, yet little conducing to our en≈øuing di≈øcour≈øe. But let us under≈øtand what Di≈øtillation is, of which there are three principall and chief definitions, or de≈øcriptions.

1 Di≈øtillation is a certain Art of extracting the Liquor, or the humid part of things by vertue of heat (as the matter ≈øhall require) being fir≈øt re≈øolved into a vapour, and then conden≈øed again by cold.
2. Di≈øtillation is the art of extracting the ≈øpirituall and e≈ø≈øential humidity from the flegmatick, or of the flegmatick, from the ≈øpirituall.
3 Di≈øtillation is the changing of gro≈ø≈øe thick bodies into a thinner and liquid ≈øub≈øtance, or ≈øeparation of the pure liquor from the impure feces.

I ≈øhall treat of Di≈øtillation according to all the≈øe three acceptions, and no otherwi≈øe; hence I ≈øhall exclude Sublimation, and Calcination, which are of dry ≈øub≈øtances, unle≈ø≈øe I ≈øhall by the way make u≈øe of either in relation to the perfecting of any kind of Di≈øtillation.

Now becau≈øe all, or mo≈øt of the≈øe di≈øtillations are to be performed by heat, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to under≈øtand how many
degrees of heat there are, and which are convenient for every operation, and they are principally four.
The fir≈øt is only a warmth, as is that of hor≈øe dung, of the Sun, of warm water, and the vapour thereof, which kind of heat ≈øerves for putrefaction, and dige≈øtion.

2 The ≈øecond is of ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ething water, and the vapour thereof, as al≈øo of a≈øhes, and ≈øerves to di≈øtill tho≈øe things which are ≈øubtile, and moi≈øt, as al≈øo for the rectifying of any ≈øpirit or oil.
3 The third is of ≈øand and filings of iron, which ≈øerves to di≈øtill things ≈øubtle, and dry, or gro≈ø≈øe and moi≈øt.

4 The fourth is of a naked fire, clo≈øe, open, or with a bla≈øt, which ≈øerves to di≈øtill Metalls and Minerals, and hard gummie things, as Amber, &c. I do not ≈øay ≈øerves only to di≈øtill the≈øe, for many of the former di≈øtillations are performed by this heat, as the di≈øtilling of Spirits and Oils, &c. in a copper ≈øtill over a naked fire; but the≈øe may be di≈øtilled by the two former degrees of heat; but Mineralls and ≈øuch like cannot but by this fourth degree alone.

div.head: Of the matter and form of Furnaces.
div.p: THe matter of Furnaces is various, for they may be made either of brick and clay, or clay alone with whites of Egges, hair, and filings of Iron, (and of the≈øe if the clay be fat are made the be≈øt, and mo≈øt durable Furnaces) or of Iron, or Copper, ca≈øt or forged. The forms al≈øo of Furnaces are various.

The fitte≈øt form for Di≈øtillation is round; for ≈øo the heat of the fire being carryed up equally diffu≈øeth it ≈øelf every way‚ñ™ which happens not in a Furnace of another figure, as four ≈øquare or triangular, for the corners di≈øper≈øe and ≈øeparate the force of the fire. Their magnitude mu≈øt be ≈øuch as ≈øhal be fit for the receiving of the ve≈ø≈øel; their thickne≈ø≈øe ≈øo great as nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhall ≈øeem to require; only thus much ob≈øerve, that if they be made of forged iron or copper, they mu≈øt be coated within ≈øide, e≈øpecially if you intend to u≈øe them for a ≈øtrong fire. They mu≈øt be madewith
two bottomes, di≈øtingui≈øht as it were, into two forges‚ñ™ the one below which may receive the a≈øhes, the other above to contain the fire. The bottom of this upper mu≈øt either be an iron grate, or el≈øe an Iron plate perforated with many holes, that ≈øo the a≈øhes may the more ea≈øily fall down into the bottome, which otherwi≈øe would put ‚Ä¢ out the fire. Yet ≈øome Furnaces have three partitions, as the Furnace for Reverberation, and the Regi≈øter Furnace. In the fir≈øt and lowe≈øt the a≈øhes are received, in the ≈øecond the fire is put, and in the third of the Furnace for Reverberation, the matter which is to be reverberated. This third ought to have a ≈øemi-circular cover, that ≈øo the heat may be reflected upon the contained matter. The bottome of the third and uppermo≈øt partition of the Regi≈øter Furnace mu≈øt be either a plate of iron, or a ≈ømooth ≈øtone perforated with holes, having ≈øtopples of ≈øtone fitted thereunto, which you may take out or put in, as you would have the heat increa≈øed or decrea≈øed. In the top or upper part of all the≈øe Furnaces where it ≈øhal ≈øeem mo≈øt fit, there mu≈øt be two or three holes made, that by them the ≈ømoak may more freely pa≈øs out, and the air let in to make the fire burn the ≈øtronger if need require, or el≈øe which are to be ≈øhut with ≈øtopples made fit to them. The mouths of the fore-mentioned partitions mu≈øt have ≈øhutters, ju≈øt like an Ovens mouth, with which you may ≈øhut them clo≈øe, or leave them open if you would have the fire burn ≈øtronger. But in defect of a Furnace, or fit matter to make one, we may u≈øe a Kettle or a Pot ≈øet upon a Trevet, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew when we come to give you a de≈øcription of the Furnace and Ve≈ø≈øels. The truth is, a good Arti≈øt will make any ≈øhift, yea and in half a dayes time make a Furnace or ≈øomething equivalent to it for any operations.

div.head: Of Ve≈ø≈øels fit for di≈øtillation.
div.p:
VE≈ø≈øels for Di≈øtillation are of various matter and forme. For they may be either of Lead, which I altogether di≈øapprove of, for that they turn the liquors into a white and milky ≈øub≈øtance, be≈øide the malignity they give to them; or they may be of Copper, Iron, or Tin, which are better then the former;
or of Jug-metall, or Potters-metall glazed, or Gla≈ø≈øe, which are the be≈øt of all, where they may be u≈øed without fear of breaking or melting. Some make them of ≈øilver, but they are very chargeable. They that are able and willing may have the benefit of them.

div.head: Of Lutes for coating of gla≈ø≈øes and for Clo≈øures, as al≈øo ≈øeverall wayes of ≈øtopping gla≈ø≈øes.
div.p: THe be≈øt Lute is made thus, viz. Take of Loam and ≈øand tempered with ≈øalt water (which keeps it from cleaving) to the≈øe adde the Caput Mortuum, of Vitrioll, or Aqua fortis, and ≈øcaling of Iron, and temper them well together, and this ≈øerveth to coat Retorts or any gla≈ø≈øe ve≈ø≈øells that mu≈øt endure a mo≈øt ≈øtrong fire, and will never fail if well made. Some adde Flax, beaten Gla≈ø≈øe, and Pots, and flint, &c.
Take un≈ølaked Lime, and Lin≈øeed oil, mix them wel together and make thereof a Lute which will be ≈øo hard that no ≈øpirit will pierce it, and this ≈øerves for the clo≈øure of Gla≈ø≈øes.

Or,
Take Loam and the white of an egge, mix them into a pa≈øte, and ≈øpread it on a cloth. This al≈øo is a good clo≈øure.

Or,
Moi≈øten an Ox bladder in the white of an egge beaten to water, or in defect of a bladder u≈øe paper, and bind them round where the ve≈ø≈øells are joined together, one over another two or three times.

Or,
If the ≈øpirits in the gla≈ø≈øe be exceeding corro≈øive, then u≈øe the Caput mortuum of Aqua fortis, Lin≈øeed oil, and chalk mixed together.

If a Gla≈ø≈øe be cracked, then wet a linnen cloth in the white of an egge beaten to water, and lay upon it, and upon that pre≈øently while≈øt it is wet, ≈øift ≈øome un≈ølaked Lime, and pre≈ø≈øe it clo≈øe with your hand, when that is dry lay on another cloth thus wet as before, and on it ≈øift more Lime.

A ve≈ø≈øell may be ≈øtopt ≈øo clo≈øe with Quick≈øilver that no ≈øpirit
can breath forth, by which means the gla≈ø≈øe will be pre≈øerved from breaking by the inclo≈øed ≈øpirits, (for the head will fir≈øt yeild before the gla≈ø≈øe breaks) the Ve≈ø≈øell mu≈øt be made as the figure here-under ≈øheweth. This al≈øo is a good way to pre≈øerve ≈øpirits already di≈øtilled from the air.
A, Signifies the head or cover.
B, The body or ve≈ø≈øell it ≈øelf.

C, The little gla≈ø≈øe to take out the Liquor that is in the ve≈ø≈øell becau≈øe it cannot well be poured out, as by rea≈øon of the Quick-≈øilver which will be apt to be lo≈øt, ≈øo by rea≈øon of the form of the Ve≈ø≈øell it ≈øelf.
D, A fal≈øe bottom where the Quick-≈øilver mu≈øt lye, into which the head mu≈øt be ≈øet upon the Quick-≈øilver that ≈øo the Quick-≈øilver may come above the bottome of the Head.
Al≈øo you may make ≈øtopples of Gla≈ø≈øes ground ≈øo ≈ømooth that no vapour can get forth by them, as you may ≈øee by this pattern.
A, Signifies the ‚Ä¢ topple of gla≈ø≈øe ground very ≈ømooth and fit to the mouth of the Ve≈ø≈øell.

But the be≈øt way is to have a crooked pipe, which may have quick-≈øilver in it, and be well luted to the body that no ≈øpirit can get forth: and by this means the gla≈ø≈øe will never break, for the quick-≈øilver will fir≈øt yeeld.
A, The crooked pipe.
B, The gla≈ø≈øe body.
Or upon the top of a gla≈ø≈øe ≈øtopple there may be fa≈øtned ≈øome lead, that if the ≈øpirit be too ≈øtrong it wil only heave up the ≈øtopple and let it fall down again.
C, The gla≈ø≈øe ≈øtopple with lead on the top.
D, The mouth of the ve≈ø≈øell it ≈øelf.

div.head: Now the way to nip up ‚Ä¢ gla≈ø≈øe, or ≈øeal it up Hermetically is after this manner.
div.p: PUt what matter you plea≈øe into a bolt head with a long neck or pipe, put this pipe through a pan that hath a little hole made in the bottom thereof, that the top of it may be three or four inches above the pan, clo≈øe up the hole round about the pipe with clay, then put coals in the pan and kindle fir≈øt tho≈øe that are furthe≈øt off from the pipe that the heat may come by degrees to the pipe (for otherwi≈øe a ≈øudden heat will break it) when the pipe is hot, blow the coals about it till it melt, then with a pair of ≈øhears cut it off where it is melted, and then with a pair of tongs clo≈øe it together.

Note that after you have clo≈øed it you mu≈øt put the burning coals upon the top thereof, and let it thus ≈øtand till all be cold
which mu≈øt be done by degrees, for otherwi≈øe the gla≈ø≈øe will certainly crack in the place where it is nipped.
Note that the pan mu≈øt ≈øtand upon ≈øome frame, or ≈øome hollow place that there may be a pa≈ø≈øage for the pipe to come through it
Al≈øo the bolt ‚Ä¢ head mu≈øt ≈øtand upon a treefoot or ≈øome other firme place according to this figure.

div.head: An Explanation of ≈øuch hard words, and terms of Art, which are u≈øed in this en≈øuing Treati≈øe.
div.p: A Malgamation, is a calcining or corroding metals with quick≈øilver, and it is done thus. Take any metall except iron, beaten into thin leafs, or very ≈ømall powder, mix it with about 8. parts of quick-≈øilver (which may the better be done if both be heated fir≈øt) that they may become one uniform ma≈ø≈øe, evaporate the quick-≈øilver over the fire, and the metall will be left in the bottom as a thin calx.

Calcination it a reducing any thing into a Calx, and making it fryable, and it may be done two wayes,
By firing
By reducing into a≈øhes.
By reverberating.
By Coro≈øion
By Amalgamation,
Precipitation,
Fumigation or vaporation,
Cementation or ≈øtratification.

Circulation, is when any liquor is ≈øo placed in dige≈øtion, that it ≈øhall ri≈øe up and fall down, ri≈øe up and fall down, and ≈øo do continually, and thereby become more dige≈øted and mature, for which u≈øe for the mo≈øt part we u≈øe a Pelican.

Clarification, is the ≈øeparating of the gro≈ø≈øe feces from any decoction or juice, and it is done three wayes,
By the white of an Egge,
By dige≈øtion,
By filtration.
Coagulation, is the reducing of any liquid thing to a thicker ≈øub≈øtance by evaporating the humidity.
Cohgbation, is the frequent ab≈øtraction of any Ilquor, po ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed oft-times on the feces from whence it was di≈øtilled, by di≈øtillation.
Congelation, is when any liquor being decocted to the height, is afterward by ≈øetling into any cold place turned into a tran≈øparent ≈øub≈øtance like unto ice.
Coro≈øion, is the Calcining of bodyes by corro≈øive things.

div.head: D.
div.p: Decantation, is the pouring off of any liquor which hath a ≈øetling, by inclination.

Deliquium, is the di≈ø≈øolving of a hard body into a liquor, as
≈øalt, or the powder of any calcined matter, &c. in a moi≈øt, cold place.
De≈øcen≈øion, is when the e≈ø≈øentiall juice di≈ø≈øolved from the matter to be di≈øtilled doth de≈øcend, or fall downward.
De≈øpumation, is the taking off the froth that floats on the top with a ≈øpoone or feather, or by percolation.

Di≈øtillation, is the extracting of the humid part of things by vertue of heat, being fir≈øt re≈øolved into a vapour, and then conden≈øed again by cold. Thus it is generally taken, but how more particularly, I ≈øhall afterward ≈øhew.
Dige≈øtion, is a concocting, or maturation of crude things by an ea≈øie and gentle heat.
Di≈ø≈øolution, is the turning of bodies into a liquor by the addition of ≈øome humidity.

Dulcoration, or Dulcification, is either the wa≈øhing off the ≈øalt from any matter that was calcined therewith, with warm water, in which the ≈øalt is di≈ø≈øolved, and the matter dulcified: or it is ≈øweetning of things with ≈øugar, or honey, or ≈øyrup.

div.head: E.
div.p: Elevation, is the ri≈øing of any matter in manner of fume, or vapour, by virtue of heat.
Evaporation, or Exhalation, is the vapouring away of any moi≈øture.
Exaltation, is when any matter doth by dige≈øtion attain to a greater purity.
Expre≈ø≈øion, is the extracting of any liquor by the hand, or by a Pre≈ø≈øe.
Extraction, is the drawing forth of an e≈ø≈øence from a corporeall matter by ≈øome fit liquor, as ≈øpirit of wine, the feces remaining in the bottome.

div.head: F.
div.p: Fermentation, is when any thing is re≈øolved into it ≈øelf, and is rarified, and ripened, whether it be done by any ferment added to it, or by dige≈øtion only.
Filtration, is the ≈øeparation of any liquid matter from its feces by making it run through a brown paper made like a tunnell, or a little bag of woollen cloth, or through ≈øhreds.

Fixation, is the making of any volatile, ≈øpiritual body endure
the fire, and not flye away, whether it be done by often reiterated di≈øtillations, or ≈øublimations, or by the adding of ≈øome fixing thing to it.
Fumigation, is the calcining of bodies by the fume of ≈øharp ≈øpirits, whether vegetable or minerall, the bodies being laid over the mouth of the ve≈ø≈øell wherein the ≈øharp ≈øpirits are.

div.head: H.
div.p: Hamectation, or Irrigation, is a ≈øprinkling of moi≈øture upon any thing.

div.head: I.
div.p: Imbibition, is when any dry body drinks in any moi≈øture that is put upon it.

Infu≈øion, is the putting of any hard matter into liquor, for the virtue thereof to be extracted.

div.head: L.
div.p: Levigation, is the reducing of any hard matter into a mo≈øt fine powder.

Lutation, is either the ≈øtopping of the orifices of ve≈ø≈øels, that no vapour pa≈ø≈øe out, or the coating of any ve≈ø≈øell to pre≈øerve it
‚Ä¢ rom breaking in the fire.

div.head: M.
div.p: Maceration, is the ≈øame as Dige≈øtion.

Men≈øtruum, is any Liquor that ≈øerves for the extracting the e≈ø≈øence of any thing.

div.head: P.
div.p: Precipitation, is when bodies corroded by corro≈øive ≈øpirits either by the evaporating of the ≈øpirits remain in the bottome, or by pouring ≈øomething upon the ≈øpirit, as oil of Tartar, or a good quantity of water, do fall to the bottom.

div.head: Q.
div.p: Quinte≈ø≈øence, is an ab≈øolute, pure and well dige≈øted medicine, drawn from any ≈øub≈øtance, either animall, vegetable or minerall.

div.head: R.
div.p: Rectification, is either the drawing of the flegm from the ≈øpirit, or of the ≈øpirit from the flegm, or the exaltation of any Liquor by a reiterated di≈øtillation.

div.head: S.
div.p: Solution, is a di≈ø≈øolving or attenuating of bodies.

div.head: T.
div.p: Tran≈ømutation, is the changing of a thing in ≈øub≈øtance, colour, and quality.

div.head: V.
div.p: Volatile, is that which flyeth the fire.

div.head: Rules to be con≈øidered in Di≈øtillation.

div.p:
Make choice of a fit place in your hou≈øe for the furnace, ≈øo that it may neither hinder any thing, nor be in danger of the falling of any thing into it that ≈øhall lye over it: for a forcing Furnace it will be be≈øt to ≈øet it in a chimney, becau≈øe a ≈øtrong heat is u≈øed to it, and many times there are u≈øed brands which will ≈ømoak, and the fire being great the danger thereof may be prevented, and of things of a maligne and venenate qualitie being
di≈øtilled in ≈øuch a Furnace, the fume or vapour, if the gla≈øs ≈øhould break, may be carryed up into the chimney which otherwi≈øe will flye about the room to thy prejudice.

In all kinds of Di≈øtillation the ve≈ø≈øels are not to be filled too full, for if you di≈øtill Liquors they will run over, if other ≈øolider things, the one part will be burnt before the other part be at all worked upon, but fill the fourth part of Gourds, the half of Retorts, the third part of copper ve≈ø≈øels; and in rectifying of ≈øpirits fill the ve≈ø≈øell half full.

Let tho≈øe things which are flatulent, as wax, ro≈øin, and ≈øuch like, as al≈øo tho≈øe things which do ea≈øily boil up, as honey, be put in a le≈ø≈øer quantity, and be di≈øtilled in greater ve≈ø≈øels, with the addition of ≈øalt, ≈øand, or ≈øuch like.
There be ≈øome things which require a ≈øtrong fire, yet you mu≈øt have a care that the fire be not too vehement for fear their nature ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed.
You mu≈øt have a care that the lute with which ve≈ø≈øels are clo≈øed, do not give vent and alter the nature of the Liquor; e≈øpecially when a ≈øtrong fire is to be u≈øed.
Acid Liquors have this peculiar property, that the weaker part goes forth fir≈øt, and the ≈øtronger la≈øt; but in fermented and Liquors the ≈øpirit goeth fir≈øt, then the flegme.

If the Liquor retain a certain Empyreuma, or ≈ømatch of the fire, thou ≈øhalt help it by putting it into a gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt, and ≈øo expo≈øing it to the heat of the Sun, and now and then opening the gla≈øs that the fiery impre≈ø≈øion may exhale, or el≈øe let the gla≈øs ≈øtand in a cold moi≈øt place.

When thou take≈øt an earthen or gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel from the fire, expo≈øe it not to the cold air too ≈øuddenly for fear it ≈øhould break.
If thou would≈øt have a Balneum as hot as a≈øhes, put ≈øand or ≈øawdu≈øt into it, that the heat of the water may be therewith kept in, and made more inten≈øe.

If you would make a heat with hor≈øe-dung, the manner is this, viz. make a hole in the ground, then lay one cour≈øe of hor≈øe dung a foot thick, then a cour≈øe of un≈ølaked lime half a foot thick, then another of dung, as before, then ≈øet in your ve≈ø≈øel, and lay round it lime and hor≈øe dung mixt together; pre≈øs it down very hard; you mu≈øt ≈øprinkle it every other day with water, and when it cea≈øeth to be hot, then take it out and put in more.
Note that alwayes ≈øand or a≈øhes mu≈øt be well ≈øi≈øted, for otherwi≈øe a coal or ≈øtone therein may break your gla≈øs.

The time for putrefaction of things is various, for if the thing to be putrefied be vegetables and green, le≈øs time is required, if dry, a longer, if Minerals, the longe≈øt of all. Thus much note, that t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ gs are ≈øooner putrefied in cloudy weather then in fair.

If thou would≈øt keep vegetables fre≈øh and green all the year, gather them in a dry day, and put them into an earthen ve≈ø≈øel, which you mu≈øt ≈øtop clo≈øe, and ≈øet in a cold place: and they will, as ≈øaith Glauberus, keep fre≈øh a whole year.

Do not expect to extract the e≈ø≈øence of any vegetable unle≈øs by making u≈øe of the feces, left after di≈øtillation: for if you take tho≈øe feces, as for example of a nettle, and make a decoction thereof, and ≈øtrain it and ≈øet it in the fro≈øt, it wil be congealed & in it will appear a thou≈øand leaves of nettles with their prickles which when the decoction is again re≈øolved by heat, vani≈øh away, which ≈øhews that the e≈ø≈øence of the vegetables lies in the ≈øalt thereof.

In all your operations, diligently ob≈øerve the proce≈ø≈øes which you read, and vary not a tittle from them, for ≈øometimes a ≈ømal mi≈øtake or neglect ≈øpoils the whole operation, and fru≈øtrates your expectation.
Try not at fir≈øt experiments of great co≈øt, or great difficulty, for it will be a great di≈øcouragement to thee, and thou wilt be very apt to mi≈øtake.

If any would enter upon the practi≈øe of Chymi≈øtrie, let him apply him≈øelf to ≈øome expert Arti≈øt for to be in≈øtructed in the manual operation of things, for by this means he wil learn more in two months, then he can by his practi≈øe and ≈øtudy in 7 years, as al≈øo avoid much pains and co≈øt, and redeem much time which el≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity he will lo≈øe.
Enter not upon any operation, unle≈øs it be con≈øi≈øtent with the po≈ø≈øibility of nature, which therefore thou mu≈øt endeavour as much as po≈ø≈øibly may be, to under≈øtand well.

Do not interpret all things thou reade≈øt according to the literall ≈øen≈øe, for Philo≈øophers when they wrote any thing too excellent for the vulgar to know, expre≈ø≈øed it enigmatically, that the ≈øons of Art only might under≈øtand it.
In all thy operations propo≈øe a good end to thy ≈øelf, as not to u≈øe any excellent experiment that thou ≈øhalt di≈øcover, to any ill end, but for the publick good.

It wil be nece≈ø≈øary that thou knowe≈øt all ≈øuch in≈øtruments that thou ≈øhalt u≈øe about thy Furnace and Gla≈ø≈øes, whereof ≈øome are already expre≈ø≈øed, and ≈øome more are ≈øhewn in the following page.

A, Signifies an iron rod with two iron rings at the ends thereof, which must be heated red hot, and applyed to that part of the gla≈øs which thou would≈øt break off. When thou ha≈øt held it there ≈øo long till the gla≈øs be very hot, then take it off, and drop ≈øome cold water where thou would≈øt have it break off, and it will pre≈øently crack in ≈øunder. The≈øe rings are for ≈øuch gla≈ø≈øes as will goe into them: Thou mu≈øt have divers of this ≈øort, even of all ≈øizes.

div.head: Common di≈øtilled ≈øimple waters, are made thus.
div.p: TAke what herbs or flowers you plea≈øe, put them into a common cold Still, and let them di≈øtill gently.
This is the form of a common cold Still.

But note that this kinde of water is but the flegm of the vegetable which you di≈øtil, and hath very little vertue or odour in it; only ro≈øes and mints and two or three more have an odour, but all be≈øides, have as little vertue as common di≈øtilled water.
I do not deny but that it may be ≈øo ordered, that the≈øe kinds of waters may partake both of the ≈ømell and ≈øtrength of their vegetables in a good mea≈øure, and it is thus.

div.head: To make waters in a cold Still that ≈øhall have the full ≈ømell and vertue of the vegetable.
div.p: TAke what herbs, flowers, or roots you plea≈øe (≈øo that they be green) brui≈øe them and mix with them ≈øome leaven, and let them ≈øtand clo≈øe covered for four or five days: then di≈øtil them after the manner afore≈øaid.

div.head: Another way to make Water ta≈øte and ≈ømell ≈øtrong of its vegetable.
div.p: WHen you have di≈øtilled any vegetable in a cold Still after the u≈øuall manner (≈øo that you take heed you dry not the hearb too much, which you may prevent by putting a brown paper in the bottom of the Still, giving it a gentle fire, and turning the cake before it be quite dryed) take the cakes that remain in the bottome of the Still, and the water that is di≈øtilled from thence (having a good quantity thereof) and put them into a hot Still, and let them ≈øtand warm for the ≈øpace of 24 hours, then di≈øtil them. Then if you would have the water ≈øtrong, put the ≈øaid water into more fre≈øh cakes, ca≈øting away the other, and doe as before. This is the true≈øt and be≈øt way to have the water of any vegetables. Al≈øo thou ≈øhalt by this way purcha≈øe ≈øome oil which is to be ≈øeparated and to be kept by it ≈øelf.

div.head: To make water at any time of the year in a cold Still without green herbs, ≈øo that the water ≈øhall ≈ømell ≈øtrong of the hearb.
div.p: PUt fair water into the body of the cold Still, then hang a bag full of that hearb that thou would≈øt have the water of, being fir≈øt dryed, or ≈øeed or root thereof fir≈øt brui≈øed, then make a ≈øtrong fire under the Still.

Note that tho≈øe vegetables of which the water is made after this and the former manner, mu≈øt be of a fragrant ≈ømell, for ≈øuch as have but little or no ≈ømell cannot yeeld a water of any con≈øiderable odour.

div.head: Another way to make a water ta≈øte and ≈ømell ≈øtrong of its vegetables.
div.p:
TAke of the dry hearb, or ≈øeed, or root brui≈øed, to a pound of each, put 12, pints of ≈øpring water, di≈øtill them in a hot Still or Alembick, and the water that is di≈øtilled off put upon
more of the fre≈øh hearbs, ≈øeeds, or roots; do this three or four times, and thou ≈øhalt have a water full of the vertue of the vegetable, being almo≈øt as ≈øtrong as a ≈øpirit.

div.head: To make the water of the flowers of Ja≈ømin, Honey-≈øuckles, or Woodbine, Violets, Lillies, &c. retain the ≈ømell of their flowers.
div.p:
The rea≈øon why the≈øe flowers in the common way of di≈øtillation yeeld a water of no fragrancie at all, although they them≈øelves are very odoriforous, are either becau≈øe if a ≈øtronger fire be made in the di≈øtilling of them, the gro≈ø≈øer and more earthy ≈øpirit cometh out with the finer, and troubleth it, as it is in ca≈øe the flowers be cru≈øhed or brui≈øed (where the odour up
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
the ≈øame account is lo≈øt) or becau≈øe the odoriferous ≈øpirit thereof being thin and very ≈øubtle, ri≈øeth with a gentle heat, but for lack of body vapours away. The a ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ therefore that is here required, is to prevent the mixtion of the gro≈ø≈øer ≈øpirit with the finer, and to give ≈øuch a body to the finer that ≈øhall not emba≈øe it: and it is thus.

Take of either of the afore≈øaid flowers gathered fre≈øh, and at noon in a fair day, let them not at all be brui≈øed. Infu≈øe a handfull of them in two quarts of White-wine (which mu≈øt be very good, or el≈øe you labour in vain) for the ≈øpace of half an hour, then take them forth, and infu≈øe in the ≈øame wine the ≈øame quantity of fre≈øh flowers, this do eight or ten times, but ≈øtill remember that they be not infu≈øed above half an hour, (for according to the rule of infu≈øion, a ≈øhort ≈øtay of the body that hath a fine ≈øpirit in the liquor receiveth the ≈øpirit; but a longer ≈øtay confoundeth it, becau≈øe it draweth forth the earthy part withall, which de≈øtroyeth the finer:) then di≈øtill this liquor (all the flowers being fir≈øt taken out) in a gla≈øs gourd in a very gentle Balneo, or over a vapour of hot water, the joints of the gla≈øs being very well clo≈øed, and thou ≈øhalt have a water of a mo≈øt fragrant odour. By this means the ≈øpirit of the wine which ≈øerves to body the fine odoriferous ≈øpirit of the flowers ari≈øeth as ≈øoon as the fine ≈øpirit it ≈øelf, without any earthine≈øs mixed with it.
Note that in defect of Wine, Aqua vitae will ≈øerve; al≈øo ≈øtrong beer, but not altogether ≈øo well, becau≈øe there is more gro≈øs earthine≈øs in it then in wine.
The water of either of the≈øe flowers is a mo≈øt fragrant perfume, and may be u≈øed as a very delicate ≈øweet water, and is no ≈ømall ≈øecret.

div.p: TAke of what Berries you plea≈øe being full ripe, put them into a gourd gla≈øs, ≈øtrewing upon them a good quantity of powdered ≈øugar, cover them clo≈øe, let them ≈øtand three weeks or a month, then di≈øtill them in Balneo.

div.p:
TAke of Elder berries as many as you plea≈øe, pre≈øs out the juice thereof, to every gallon thereof put a pint of Whitewine vinegar, of the lees of Whitewine a pint, let them ≈øtand in a

div.p: TAke as many rotten apples as you plea≈øe, brui≈øe them, and di≈øtill them either in a common cold Still, or gourd gla≈ø≈øes in Balneo.

div.head: How to make Aqua vitae, and ≈øpirit of Wine out of Wine.
div.p:
TAke of what wine you plea≈øe, put it into a copper Still, two parts of three being empty, di≈øtill it with a worm untill
no more ≈øpirit come off, then this ≈øpirit will ≈øerve for the making of any ≈øpirits out of vegetables: but if thou would≈øt have it ≈øtronger di≈øtill it again, and half will remain behind as an in≈øipid flegm: and if thou would≈øt have it yet ≈øtronger, di≈øtill it again, for every di≈øtillation wil leave behind one moity of flegm or thereabouts; So ≈øhalt thou have a mo≈øt pure and ≈øtrong ≈øpirit of wine.

div.head: How to make Aqua vitae out of beer.
div.p:
TAke of ≈øtale ≈øtrong-beer or rather the grounds thereof, pu it into a Copper Still with a worm, di≈øtill it gently (or otherwi≈øe it will make the head of the Still fly up) and there wil
come forth a weak ≈øpirit, which is called low wine: of which when thou ha≈øt a good quantity thou maye≈øt di≈øtill it again of it ≈øelf, and there will come forth a good Aqua vitae. And if thou di≈øtille≈øt it two or three times more, thou ≈øhalt have as ≈øtrong a ≈øpirit as out of wine, and indeed betwixt which and the ≈øpirit of wine, thou ≈øhalt perceive none or very little difference.

div.head: How to rectifie ≈øpirit of Wine or Aqua vitae.
div.p: DI≈øtill it in Balneo untill the la≈øt drop that comes off be hot, and full of ≈øpirit.
Note that every time there will remain in the bottome a quantity as weak as water.
Note al≈øo that every time thou di≈øtille≈øt it, when thou perceive≈øt that a very weak water comes over, thou ≈øhalt then end that di≈øtillation.

div.head: To make the Magi≈øtery of Wine, which will be one of the greate≈øt Cordials, and mo≈øt odoriferous Liquor in the world.
div.p: TAke good old rich Canary Wine, put it into a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øell that it may fill the third part thereof, nip it up and ≈øet it in a continuall heat of hor≈øe dung for the ≈øpace of four months: then in fro≈øty weather ≈øet it forth into the colde≈øt place of the air you can, for the ≈øpace of a month, that it may be congealed: And ≈øo the cold will drive in the true ≈øpirit of the wine into the Center thereof, and ≈øeparate it perfectly from its flegm. That which is congealed ca≈øt away; but that which is not congealed e≈øteem as the true ≈øpirit of Wine. Circulate this in a Pelican with a moderate heat for the ≈øpace of a month, and thou ≈øhalt have the true magi≈øtery or ≈øpirit of Wine, which as it is mo≈øt cordial, ≈øo al≈øo mo≈øt bal≈øamicall, exceeding all bal≈øames for the cure of Wounds.

div.head: To make another Magi≈øtery of Wine that a few drops thereof ≈øhall turn Water into perfect Wine.
div.p: TAke of the be≈øt Canary Wine, as much as you plea≈øe, let it ≈øtand in putrefaction forty dayes, then di≈øtill it in B ‚Ä¢ lneo, and there will come forth a ≈øpirit, and at la≈øt an oil, ≈øeparate the one from the other, and rectifie the ≈øpirit. Set the oil again in putrefaction forty dayes, and then di≈øtill it. The feces that are left after the fir≈øt Di≈øtillation will yeeld a volatile ≈øalt, which mu≈øt be extracted without Calcination, with the flegm of the ≈øpirit, purifie it well, then impregnate the ≈øalt with its ≈øpirit, and dige≈øt them, then adde the oil, and dige≈øt them together till they become a red powder, which you may u≈øe as it is, or el≈øe ≈øet it in a cellar till it be di≈ø≈øolved into a liquor, and a few drops thereof will doe as above ≈øaid.

div.head: To make an oil of Wine.
div.p: TAke weak ≈øpirit of Wine, di≈øtil it in a Ve≈ø≈øel of a long neck, then pour on this ≈øpirit again upon the flegm, di≈øtill it again, do this ≈øeverall times, and you ≈øhall ≈øee the oil of the Wine ≈øwim on the flegm, which flegm you mu≈øt ≈øeparate from the oil by a tunnell.
If this oil be afterward circulated for a month, it will thereby become mo≈øt odoriferous, and of ≈øingular vertue, and good, being both very cordiall and bal≈øamicall.

div.head: To extract the ≈øpirit out of Wine by the ≈øpirit of Wine.
div.p: PUt ≈øpirit of Wine well rectified upon Canary on Rheni≈øh Wine, ≈øo cautiou≈øly that it may not mix with, but ≈øwim upon the Wine, let them ≈øtand without ≈øtirring the ≈øpace of 48 hours. Then will the ≈øpirit that is in the Wine ri≈øe up and join it ≈øelf to the ≈øpirit that ≈øwims on the top, which you ≈øhall perceive by the weakne≈øs of the flegm, which you mu≈øt let run out at a tap, which mu≈øt be made in the bottome of the ve≈ø≈øell for that purpo≈øe, and ≈øo be ≈øeparated from the ≈øpirit.

div.head: To make a very ≈øubtill ≈øpirit of Wine at the fir≈øt di≈øtilling.
div.p: TAke white, or wheaten bread as ≈øoon as it comes forth of the Oven, break it in the middle, i. e. the upper ≈øide from the lower ≈øide, and hang it in a Gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øell over Canary Wine, but ≈øo that it touch not the wine; then cover the ve≈ø≈øel and let it ≈øo ≈øtand untill the bread ≈øwell and be ≈øufficiently impregnated with the Spirit of Wine, which it will attract from the Wine: then take out that bread and put in more, till you have a con≈øiderable quantity of bread thus moi≈øtned. Then put this bread into a gla≈øs body, and di≈øtill it in Balneo, and you ≈øhall have a a very ≈øubtile ≈øpirit, which you may yet rectifie by Circulation.
