The ve≈ø≈øell on your right hand is to boil water in for any u≈øe, al≈øo to brew in.

div.head: The Spirit of any Vegetable is made thus.
div.p: TAke of what vegetable you plea≈øe, two pound, macerate it in ≈øix Gallons of Aqua vitae or low Wines, or Sack, for the ≈øpace of 24. hours, then let them be di≈øtilled by an Alembick, or hot Still, putting to every pound of the ≈øpirit two ounces of mo≈øt pure ≈øugar.

Note that the two fir≈øt pints may be called the ≈øtronger ≈øpirit, and the re≈øt the weaker ≈øpirit, or indeed the water, but if they be both mixed together, they will make an excellent midling ≈øpirit, for the former hath more of the ≈øpirit of wine, and the latter more of the vertue and odour of the vegetable.

After this manner may be made the ≈øpirit of
Herbs,
Flowers,
the Roots of Vegetables
the Seeds of Vegetables
Berries,
Barks,
Rinds,
and Spices.
Note that the Hearbs and Flowers mu≈øt be cut ≈ømall, the re≈øt brui≈øed.

If you would make it ≈øtronger, then take all the fore≈øaid ≈øpirit, and as much more Sack or low Wines, and put them upon the ≈øame quantity of fre≈øh vegetables and di≈øtil them; repeat this three or four times if thou plea≈øe≈øt.
Note al≈øo that the Vegetable mu≈øt be dryed; becau≈øe el≈øe the ≈øpirit will not be ≈øo good, as if otherwi≈øe.

div.head: The form of an Alembick.
div.p:
A, Signifies the ve≈ø≈øel which mu≈øt be of Copper, in which the m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ is contained, and which o ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ be ≈øet over a naked fire.

B, Signifies the belly that is fa≈øtned to the Neck, that the Neck may the more commodiou≈øly be applyed to the large mouth of the ve≈ø≈øel. But it may be ≈øo ordered that the mouth of the upper ve≈ø≈øell and lower ve≈ø≈øel may be ≈øo fitted that they ≈øhall not need this Belly.
C, The long Neck of the upper ve≈ø≈øel whereby the ≈øpirit or water pa≈ø≈øing is ≈øomewhat cooled.
D, The head.
E, The ve≈ø≈øel that compa≈ø≈øeth the head, into which cold water is centinually poured after the heating.
F, The long receiver.
G, The top or Cock letting out the water when it is hot.

div.head: The Spirit of any vegetable may ≈øuddenly, at any time of the year be made thus.
div.p: Take of what Hearb, Flower, Seeds, or Roots you plea≈øe. Fil the head of the Stil therewith, then cover the mouth thereof with a cour≈øe Canvas, and ≈øet it on the Stil, having fir≈øt put into it ≈øack, or low Wines. Then give it fire.
If at any time thou would≈øt have the ≈øpirt be of the colour of its vegetable, then put of the flowers thereof dryed a good quantity in the no≈øe of the Still.

div.head: To make any vegetable yeeld its ≈øpirit quickly.
div.p:
Take of what vegetables you plea≈øe, whether it be the ≈øeed flower, root, fruit, or leaves thereof, cut or brui≈øe them ≈ømall,
then put them into warm water, put ye≈øt or balm to them, and cover them warm, and let them work three days as doth Beer, then di≈øtill them and they will yeeld their ≈øpirit ea≈øily.

div.head: To reduce the whole „Äà‚óä„Äâ into a liquor which may wel be called the E≈ø≈øence thereof.
div.p: Take the whole Hearb with flowers, and roots, make it very clean: then brui≈øe it in a ≈øtone Morter, put it into a large gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel, ≈øo that two parts of three may be empty: then cover it exceeding clo≈øe, and let it ≈øtand in putrefaction in a moderate heat the ≈øpace of half a year, and it will be all turned into a water.

div.head: To make an E≈ø≈øence of any Hearb, which being put into a gla≈øs, and held over a gentle fire, the lively form and Idea of the Hearb wil appear in the Gla≈øs.
div.p: Take the foregoing water and di≈øtill it in a gourd gla≈øs (the joints being well clo≈øed) in a≈øhes, and there will come forth a Water and an Oil, and in the upper part of the ve≈ø≈øel wil hang a volatile ≈øalt. The oil ≈øeparate from the water, and keep by it ≈øelf; with the water purifie the volatile ≈øalt by di≈ø≈øolving, filtring, and coagulating. The ≈øalt being thus purified imbibe with the ≈øaid oil, untill it will imbibe no more, dige≈øt them wel together for a month in a ve≈ø≈øell hermetically ≈øealed. And by this means you ≈øhall have a mo≈øt ≈øubtill e≈ø≈øence, which being held over a gentle heat will fly up into the gla≈øs, and repre≈øent the perfect Idea of that vegetable whereof it is the e≈ø≈øence.

div.head: The true E≈ø≈øence or rather Quinte≈ø≈øence of any Hearb is made thus.
div.p:
When thou ha≈øt made the water and oil of any vegetable, fir≈øt calcine, i. e. burn to a≈øhes the remainder of the Hearb, with the a≈øhes make a Lye by pouring its own water thereon; when thou ha≈øt drawn out all the ≈øtrength of the a≈øhes, then take „Äà‚óä„Äâ
the Lye, being fir≈øt filtred; and vapour it away, and at the bottome thou ≈øhalt find a black ≈øalt: which thou mu≈øt take and
put into a Crucible and melt it in a ≈øtrong fire (covering the Crucible all the time it is melting) after it is melted let it boil half an hour or more, then take it out: and beat it ≈ømall, and ≈øet it in a cellar on a Marble ≈øtone or in a broad gla≈øs, and it wil all be re≈øolved into a Liquor; this Liquor filter, and vapour away the humidity till it be very dry, and as white as ≈ønow. Then let this ≈øalt imbibe as much of the oil of the ≈øame vegetable as it can, but no more le≈øt thou labour in vain. Then dige≈øt them together till the oil will not ri≈øe from the Salt, but both become a fixed powder, melting with an ea≈øie heat.

div.head: To extract the Quinte≈ø≈øence of all Vegetables.
div.p: Take of what ≈øpices flowers, ≈øeeds, hearbs, woods you plea≈øe, put them into rectified ≈øpirit of Wine; let the ≈øpirit extract in dige≈øtion till no more feces fal to the bottome, but all their e≈ø≈øence is gone into the ≈øpirit of Wine, upon which being thus impregnated pour a ≈øtrong ≈øpirit of ≈øalt and dige≈øt it in Balneo, till an oil ≈øwim above, which ≈øeparate with a Tunnell, or draw off the ≈øpirit of Wine in Balneo and the oil will remain clear at the bottom, but before the ≈øpirit of Wine is ab≈øtracted, the oil is bloud red, and a true Quinte≈ø≈øence.

div.head: An excellent E≈ø≈øence of any Vegetable may be made thus.
div.p: Take of the di≈øtilled oil of any vegetable, with it imbibe the be≈øt Manna being very well depurated, untill it will imbibe no more, then dige≈øt them a month, and thou ≈øhalt have the true bal≈øome and excellent E≈ø≈øence of any vegetable.
This hath the vertues of the vegetable whereof it was made, but in a more eminent manner.
The depuration of Manna for this u≈øe is a great ≈øecret.

div.head: Water or Spirit of Manna, is made thus.
div.p:
Take of the be≈øt Manna one part, of Nitre two parts, put them into an Ox bladder, and tying it clo≈øe, put it into warm water to be di≈ø≈øolved. Di≈øtill this water in an Alembick, and
there will come forth an in≈øipid water, ≈øudorificall and laxative.

div.head: The Chimicall Oil of the Hearb or Flower of any Vegetable is made thus.
div.p: Take of the Hearb or Flower dryed one pound, of Spring water twenty four pints, di≈øtill them in a great Alembick, with its cooler or Gopper Stil, with a worm pa≈ø≈øing through a ve≈ø≈øel of cold water. Let the oil that is drawn with the water be ≈øeparated with a Tunnell or ≈øeparating gla≈øs, and let the water that is ≈øeparated be kept for a new Di≈øtillation.

Note that if this water be u≈øed two or three times in the drawing of the oil, it will be an excellent water of that vegetable from which it is di≈øtilled, and as good as mo≈øt that ≈øhal be drawn any other way.

After the ≈øame manner are made oil of the dry rinds of
Orenges,
Citrons,
Lemons,
But note that the≈øe Rinds mu≈øt be fre≈øh, and (the inward whitene≈øs being ≈øeparated) be brui≈øed.

div.head: The Oil commonly called the ≈øpirit of Ro≈øes.
div.p: Take of Damask or Red Ro≈øes, being fre≈øh, as many as you plea≈øe, infu≈øe them in as much warm water as is ≈øufficient for the ≈øpace of twenty four hours. Then ≈øtrain and pre≈øs them, and repeat the infu≈øion ≈øeverall times with pre≈ø≈øing, untill the liquor become fully impregnated, which then mu≈øt be di≈øtilled in an Alembick with a refrigeratory or Copper Still with a worm; let the ≈øpirit which ≈øwims on the water be ≈øeparated, and the water kept for a new inf ‚Ä¢ ≈øion.

This kind of ≈øpirit may be made by brui≈øing the Ro≈øes with Salt, or laying a lane of Ro≈øes and another of Salt, and ≈øo keeping them half a year or more, which then mu≈øt be di≈øtilled in as much common water, or Ro≈øe water as is ≈øufficient.

div.head: Oils are made out of ≈øeeds thus.
div.p: Take of what ≈øeeds you plea≈øe, brui≈øed, two pound, of ≈øpring water twenty pints, let them be macerated for the ≈øpace of 24. hours, and then be di≈øtilled in a copper Still with a worm, or Alembick with its refrigerating. The oil extracted with the water, being ≈øeparated with a tunnell, keep the water for a new Di≈øtillation.

This Water after three or four di≈øtillations is a very excellent water, and better then is drawn any way out of that vegetable whereof the≈øe are ≈øeeds; I mean for vertue, though not always for ≈ømell.
After the ≈øame manner are made oils out of ≈øpices, and aromaticall woods.

div.head: Oils are made out of Berries thus.
div.p: Take of what Berries you plea≈øe, being fre≈øh 25. pound, brui≈øe them and put them into a wooden ve≈ø≈øell with 12 pints of ≈øpring water, and a pound of the ≈øtronge≈øt leaven; let them be put in a cellar (the ve≈ø≈øel being clo≈øe ≈øtopped) for the ≈øpace of three months, then let them be di≈øtilled in an Alembick, or copper Still with their refrigeratory, with as much ≈øpring water as is ≈øufficient. After the ≈øeparation of the oil, let the water be kept for a new di≈øtillation. Note that the water being u≈øed in two or three Di≈øtillations is a very excellent water, and full of the vertue of the Berries.

div.head: Oil is made out of any ≈øolid Wood thus.
div.p: Take of what Wood you plea≈øe, made into gro≈øs powder, as much as you will, let it be put into a Retort, and di≈øtilled in ≈øand. The oil which fir≈øt di≈øtils, as being the thinner and ≈øweeter, mu≈øt be kept apart; which with rectifying with much water may yet be made more plea≈øant; the acid water or ≈øpirit, which in di≈øtilling comes fir≈øt forth, being ≈øeparated; which al≈øo (being rectified from the flegm with the heat of a Balneum) may be kept for u≈øe, being full of the vertue of the wood.

div.head: To make a mo≈øt excellent oil out of any Wood or Gummes in a ≈øhort time, without much co≈øt.
div.p: Take of what Wood you plea≈øe, or Gumme brui≈øed ≈ømall, put it into a ve≈ø≈øel fit for it, then pour on ≈øo much of ≈øpirit of ≈øalt as will cover your matter, then ≈øet it in ≈øand with an Alembick, make the ≈øpirit boil, ≈øo all the oil flyeth over with a little flegm, for the ≈øpirit of ≈øalt by its ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe freeth the oil, ≈øo that it flyeth over very ea≈øily.
The ≈øpirit of ≈øalt being rectified may ≈øerve again.

div.head: To make vegetables yeeld their oil ea≈øily.
div.p: Di≈øtill them being fir≈øt brui≈øed, in ≈øalt water, for ≈øalt freeth the oil from its body: Let them fir≈øt be macerated three or four days in the ≈øaid water.

div.head: Oil or Spirit of Turpentine is made thus.
div.p: Take of Venice Turpentine, as much as you plea≈øe, of ≈øpring water four times as much, let them be put into an Alembick, or copper Still with its refrigeratory, then put fire under it: ≈øo there will di≈øtil a thin white oil like water, and in the bottom of the ve≈ø≈øel wil remain a hard gum called Colophonia, which is called boiled Turpentine: That white oil may be better and freer from the ≈ømell of the fire if it be drawn in Balneo, with a gourd, and gla≈øs head.
Common oil Olive may be di≈øtilled after this manner, and be made very plea≈øant and ≈øweet, al≈øo mo≈øt unctious things, as Sperma ceti.

div.head: Oil of Gums, Refines, fat and oily things, may be drawn thus.
div.p: Take of either of the≈øe which you plea≈øe, being melted, a pound, mix it with three pound of the powder of tiles, or un≈ølaked lime; put them into a Retort, and extract an oil, which with plenty of water may be rectified.
Note that the water from whence the oil is ≈øeparated, is of excellent vertue; according to the nature of the matter from whence it is drawn.

div.head: Oil of Camphire is made thus.
div.p: Take of Camphire ≈øliced thin, as much as you plea≈øe, put it into a double quantity of Aqua fortis or ≈øpirit of Wine, let the gla≈ø≈øe having a narrow neck, be ≈øet by the fire, or on ≈øand or a≈øhes the ≈øpace of five or ≈øix hours, ≈øhaking the gla≈ø≈øe every half hour, and the Camphire will all be di≈ø≈øolved and ≈øwim on the Aqua fortis, or ≈øpirit of Wine like an oil.
Note that if you ≈øeparate it, it will all be hard ag ‚Ä¢ in pre≈øently, but not otherwi≈øe.

div.head: Another way to make Oile of Camphire, that it ≈øhall not be reduced again.
div.p: Take of Camphire powdered, as much as you plea≈øe, put it into a gla≈øs like a Urinal, put upon it another Urinal-gla≈øs inverted, the joints being clo≈øe ≈øhut ≈øublime it in a≈øhes, inverting tho≈øe Urinals ≈øo often till the Camphire be turned into an oil, then circulate it for the ≈øpace of a month, and it wil be ≈øo ≈øubtle that it will all pre≈øently vapour away in the air, if the gla≈øs be open.

div.head: Another way to make oil of Camphire.
div.p:
Take two ounces of Camphire, di≈ø≈øolve it in four ounces or pure oil olive, then put them into four pints of fair water, di≈øti ‚Ä¢
them all together in a gla≈øs gourd, either in a≈øhes or Balneo, and there will di≈øtil both water and oil, which ≈øeparate and keep by it ≈øelf.

All the≈øe kinds of oil of Camphire are very good again≈øt putrefaction, fits of the Mother, pa≈ø≈øions of the heart, &c. A few drops thereof may be taken in any liquor, or the bre≈øt be anointed therewith: Al≈øo the fume thereof may be taken in at the mouth.

div.head: A true Oil of Sugar.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt white Sugar-candie, imbibe it with the be≈øt ≈øpirit of Wine ten times, after every time drying it again, then hang it in a white ≈øilken bag in a moi≈øt cellar over a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øell that it may di≈ø≈øolve, and drop into it. Evaporate the water in Balneo, and in the bottome will the oil remain.
This is very excellent in all di≈øtempers of the Lungs.

div.head: Oil of Amber is made thus.
div.p: Take of yellow Amber one part, of the powder of flints calcined, or the powder of tiles two parts; mingle them, and put them into a Retort, and di≈øtill them in ≈øand; The oil which is white, and clear, which fir≈øt di≈øtilled off, keep by it ≈øelf, continuing the Di≈øtillation as long as any oyl di≈øtils off, then let both oyls be rectified apart in a good quantity of water.
The ≈øalt of Amber, which adheres to the neck of the Retort within ≈øide, being gathered let be purified by ≈øolution, filtration, and coagulation according to art, and be kept for u≈øe.
After this manner may be made Oyls out of any gums which may be powdered.

div.head: Oyl of Myrrhe is made thus.
div.p: Take of Myrrhe brui≈øed, of Bay-≈øalt, of each ≈øix pound, let them be di≈ø≈øolved in ≈øixty pints of ≈øpring water and be di≈øtilled in an Alembick, or Copper Still according to Art.

div.head: Oyl of Myrrhe per deliquium, or by di≈ø≈øolution, is made thus.
div.p: Take Hen-egs boiled hard, and cut in the middle length-ways, take out the yelks, then fill up the hollow half way with powder of Myrrhe, and join the parts together again binding them with a thread, and ≈øo ≈øet them upon a grate betwixt two platters in a cold moi≈øt place, ≈øo the liquor of the Myrrhe di≈ø≈øolved will di≈øtill into the lower platter.

div.head: Oil of Tartar per deliquium, i. e. by di≈ø≈øolution.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt Tartar calcined white according to Art, put it into a cotten bag, hang it in the cellar or ≈øome moi≈øt place, putting under a Receiver.

div.head: Oyls by Expre≈ø≈øion are made thus.
div.p: Take of what things you plea≈øe, ≈øuch as will afford an oyl by expre≈ø≈øion, brui≈øe them, then put them into a bag, and pre≈øs them ≈øtrongly, putting a ve≈ø≈øel under to receive the oyl.
Note that they mu≈øt ≈øtand in the Pre≈øs ≈øome hours, becau≈øe the oyl drops by little and little.
Note al≈øo that if you warm them before you put them into the Pre≈øs they will yeeld more oyl, but then it will not keep good ≈øo long as otherwi≈øe.

After this manner are made oyls of
Nutmegs,
Mace,
Almonds,
Lin≈øeed,
and ≈øuch like.

div.head: A vomiting and purging Oil made by expre≈ø≈øion.
div.p:
Take of the Berries of Ebulus or Dwarfe Elder, as many as you plea≈øe, let them be dryed but not over-much, then brui≈øe them, and in brui≈øing them moi≈øten them with the be≈øt
≈øpirit of Wine, untill they begin to be oily; then warm them by the fire, and pre≈øs forth the oil, and ≈øet it in the ≈øun to be purified.
Ten drops of this oil taken inwardly worketh upward and downward, and is very good again≈øt the drop≈øie, and all wateri≈øh di≈øea≈øes.
The belly being therewith anointed, is made thereby ≈øoluble.
Any part that is much pained with the gout or any ≈øuch grief, is pre≈øently ea≈øed by being anointed with this oil.

div.head: Oil of Ja≈ømine is made thus.
div.p: Take of flowers of Ja≈ømine, as many as you plea≈øe, put them into as much ≈øweet mature oil as you plea≈øe, put them into a gla≈øs clo≈øe ≈øtopt, and ≈øet them into the Sun to be infu≈øed for the ≈øpace of twenty dayes, then take them out and ≈øtrain the oil from the flowers: and if thou would≈øt have the oil yet ≈øtronger, put in new flowers and do as before.
This is a plea≈øant perfume, and being mixt with oils and ointments, gives them a gratefull ≈ømell: It is al≈øo u≈øed in the perfuming of Leather.

After this manner may be made oil of any flowers, but becau≈øe I ≈øhall keep my ≈øelf to the Art of Di≈øtillation only, I ≈øhal not ≈øo far digre≈øs as to ≈øpeak of the≈øe kinds of oils: only I thought good to ≈øet down the oil of Ja≈ømine becau≈øe by rea≈øon of its fragrancy it hath ≈øome analogie with Chymicall oils that are made by Di≈øtillation.

div.head: To make any Oil or Water per de≈øcen≈øum.
div.p:
Take an earthen gourd, fill it full with wood or hearbs, or what you plea≈øe, being cut ≈ømall, then invert it, i e. turn it up≈øide down, and ≈øet it in the furnace, lute it well thereunto, then ≈øet another gourd of earth under it with a wider mouth that the uppermo≈øt may goe into it, before you put the one into the other, you mu≈øt have a little ve≈ø≈øell or in≈øtrument of Tin with brims round about on the top, by which it mu≈øt hang into the lower gourd, the body thereof being 2 or 3 inches deep,
and full of holes, that the oyl or water may drop through, and not the vegetable it ≈øelf. Into this In≈øtrument being fir≈øt ≈øet into the lower gourd, put the mouth of the upper gourd, then make thy fire on the top, and keep it burning as long as any liquor will drop.

div.head: Ths Figure of this furnace is thus.
div.p: A, Signifies the gourd containing the matter to be di≈øtilled.
B, The Furnace containing the Coals, ≈øo that they ≈øurround the upper gourd.
C, The lower gourd or recipient ≈øet upon ≈øtraw-rings.
D, The ve≈ø≈øell of Tin with holes and brims, which mu≈øt be ≈øet in the Recipient.

div.head: How to make an Oyl and Water out of Soot.
div.p: This may be di≈øtilled per de≈øcen≈øum, or by retort, as thus, viz. Take of the be≈øt Soot (which ≈øhines like Jet) fill with it a gla≈øs Retort coated, or earthen Retort to the neck, di≈øtil it with a ≈øtrong fire by degrees into a large Receiver, and there will come forth a yellowi≈øh ≈øpirit with a black oyl, which thou maye≈øt ≈øeparate and dige≈øt.

div.head: How to rectifie Spirits.
div.p: You mu≈øt ≈øet them in the Sun in gla≈ø≈øes well ≈øtopped, and half filled, being ≈øet in ≈øand to the third part of their eight that the water waxing hot by the heat of the Sun may ≈øeparate it ≈øelf from the flegm mixed therewith, which will be performed in in twelve or fifteen days. There is another better way to doe this, which is to di≈øtill them again in Balneo with a gentle fire, or if you wil put them into a retort furni≈øhed with its receiver, and ≈øet them upon cry≈øtal or iron bowls, or in an iron mortar directly oppo≈øite to the beams of the Sun, as you may learn by the≈øe en≈øuing ≈øigns.
Retort with its Receiver ≈øtanding upon Cry≈øtal bowls ju≈øt oppo≈øite to the Sun beams.
Another Retort with its Receiver ≈øtanding in a Marble or Iron mortar, directly oppo≈øite to the Sun.
A, Shews the Retort.
B, The Receiver.
C, The Cry≈øtal-Bowls.
A, Shews the Retort.
B, The Marble or Iron Mortar.
C, The Receiver.

div.head: How to rectifie all ≈øtinking, thick black Oils that are made by a Retort, and to take away their ≈øtink.
div.p: Take oyl of Amber, or any ≈øuch ≈øtinking oil, put it into a gla≈øs Retort, the fourth part only being full, pour on it drop by drop the ≈øpirit of Salt, (or any other acid ≈øpirit) and they will boil together; and when ≈øo much of the ≈øpirit is poured on that it boileth no more, then cea≈øe and di≈øtill it. Fir≈øt cometh over a ≈øtinking water, then a clear white well ≈ømelling oyl, and after that a yellow oyl which is indifferent good: but the ≈øpirit of Salt hath lo≈øt its ≈øharpne≈øs: the volatile ≈øalt of the oyl remaineth coagulated with the ≈øpirit of Salt, and is black, and ta≈øteth like ≈øalt Armoniack, and hath no ≈ømell being ≈øublimed from it. Now the rea≈øon of all this is, becau≈øe the volatile ≈øalt of the oyl which is the ca ‚Ä¢ ≈øe of the ≈øtink thereof, is fixed by the acid ≈øpirit of the Salt: for acid Spirits, and volatile Salts, are contrary the one to the other; and ≈øpirit of Urine or any volatile Salt, will precipitate any metall as well as ≈øalt of Tartar.
The≈øe oyls will remain clear, and have far more vertue, then the ordinary ≈øort of oyls have.

As for common ordinary di≈øtilled oyls, they need not, if they be well ≈øeparated from the water with which they were di≈øtilled, any rectifying at all: and if you goe about to rectifie them, you will lo≈øe good part of them, and make that which remains not at all the better. But if there be any better then another for rectifying of them it is by dige≈øtion, by which means there will be a ≈øeparation of what is flegmatick which you may ≈øeparate afterwards, and by this means you ≈øhall lo≈øe none of the oyls.

div.p: TAke of the be≈øt Bay-≈øalt as much as you plea≈øe, let it be di≈ø≈øolved in ≈øpring water, and filtred, mix with this brine in a Copper ve≈ø≈øell, of the powder of Bricks or Tiles twice or thrice as much as the Salt before its di≈ø≈øolution was in weight; let the water vapour away over the fire (continually ≈øtirring of it) untill it be dry; Then put this powder into a gla≈øs Retort well luted, or an earthen Retort, and put it into a Furnace (a large Receiver joined to it according to art) then give fire to it by degrees untill it will bear an open fire, for the ≈øpace of 12 hours. Thou ≈øhalt have a very acid oil or ≈øpirit in the Receiver. div.p: Di≈ø≈øolve Salt-Armoniack in di≈øtilled ≈øpirit of Urine over a moderate heat, in this ≈øpirit let Bricks beaten into ≈ømall pieces and made red hot be quenched, till they have imbibed all the water, then make Di≈øtillation in a Retort in ≈øand, or in a naked fire.

div.p: Take of Hungarian, or the be≈øt Engli≈øh Vitrial, as much as you plea≈øe, let it be melted in an earthen ve≈ø≈øell glazed, with a ≈øoft fire, that all the moi≈øture may exhale, continually ≈øtirring of it, untill it be brought into a yellow powder, which mu≈øt be put into a gla≈ø≈øe Retort well luted, or an earthen Retort that will endure the fire: Fit a large Receiver to the Retort and clo≈øe the joints wel together; then give it fire by degrees till the ≈øecond day, then make the ≈øtronge≈øt heat you can til the Receiver which before was dark with fumes be clear again; let the Liquor that is di≈øtilled off be put into a little Retort, and the flegm be drawn off in ≈øand, ≈øo will the oil be rectified, which is mo≈øt ≈øtrong and ponderous, and mu≈øt be kept by it ≈øelf.

div.p: Take of Sulphur vivum, as much as you plea≈øe, di≈ø≈øolve it as well as you can in Aqua fortis (made of Vitriall and Salt-peter;) then evaporate the Aqua fortis, and then reverberate the matter till it become very red; Extract the tincture with ≈øpirit of Wine, then dige≈øt them till the e≈ø≈øence be ≈øeparated from the ≈øpirit like an oil, and ≈øink to the bottome.

div.p:
Take of Cry≈øtalline Ar≈øenick (being fir≈øt ≈øublimed with Colcothar alone as much as you plea≈øe, mix it with an equal weight of the ≈øalt of Tartar and Salt-peter, and let them be betwixt two little pots or crucibles (whereof the upper hath a hole) calcined,

div.p: Take of Vitriall calcined two parts, of Nitre one part, grind and mix them well together, and put them into a gla≈ø≈øe Retort coated, or earthen Retort that will endure the fire, and ≈øet them into the Furnace in an open fire, and then having fitted a large Receiver di≈øtill it by degrees the ≈øpace of 24 hours, then rectifie the water or ≈øpirit in ≈øand.

div.p: Take of crude Antimony as much as you plea≈øe, of ≈øublimed Mercury a like quality, make them both into a very fine powder and mix them, and put them into a gla≈øs Retort, the neck whereof mu≈øt be large. div.p: Take flowers of Antimony, ≈øublime them with ≈øalt Armoniack ≈øix or ≈øeven times, then wa≈øh away the Salt with warm water, and dry the powder, which then lay thin on a Marble in a cellar till it be di≈ø≈øolved (which will be in ≈øix weeks time.) div.p: Di≈ø≈øolve what Metall, or Minerall you plea≈øe, in a ≈øtrong ≈øpirit of Salt (except ≈øilver which mu≈øt be di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua fortis) draw off the flegm in Balneo, pour on rectified ≈øpirit of Wine, dige≈øt them ≈øo long till a red oil ≈øwim above, which is the quinte≈ø≈øence of metals, and minerals, and is a very great ≈øecret.

div.p: Take of the ≈øubtile powder of the Regulus of Antimony as much as you plea≈øe, ≈øublime it of it ≈øelf til it wil ≈øublime no more (≈øtil putting what is ≈øublimed to that which remains at the bottom) or with ≈øalt Armoniack ≈øix or ≈øeven times (remembring that then you mu≈øt dulcifie it with warm water by di≈ø≈øolving therewith the ≈øalt, and dry the Precipitate afterwards.) Then evaporate part of this water and let it ≈øtand two or three dayes in the cellar to cry≈øtallize. The≈øe Cry≈øtals purifie, and dry. div.p: Take of the fore≈øaid Cry≈øtals, di≈ø≈øolve them in good rectified ≈øpirit of wine, dige≈øt them two months in Balneo, or hor≈øe dung: then evaporate the ≈øpirit of wine, and there will remain in the bottom the true oil or e≈ø≈øence of Antimony.

The afore≈øaid ≈øpirit, this oil, and e≈ø≈øence of Antimony may be equalized to Aurum potabile to all intents and purpo≈øes, according to a Medicinall u≈øe, e≈øpecially the ≈øixt E≈ø≈øence. The do≈øe is five or ≈øix grains.

div.head: A burning Spirit made out of Lead, mo≈øt fragrant and Bal≈øamicall.
div.p:
Take the Calx of Saturn, or el≈øe Minium, pour upon it ≈øo much ≈øpirit of Vinegar that may cover it four fingers breadth,
dige≈øt them in a warm place the ≈øpace of twenty four hours, often ≈øtirring them that the matter ≈øettle not too thick in the bottome: then decant the Men≈øtruum, and pour on more, dige≈øt it as before, and this do ≈øo often untill all the ≈øaltne≈øs be extracted. Filter and clarifie all the Men≈øtruum being put together, then evaporate it half away, and ≈øet the other part in a cold place till it cry≈øtallize. The≈øe Cry≈øtals di≈ø≈øolve again in fre≈øh ≈øpirit of Vinegar, filter and coagulate the Liquor again into Cry≈øtals, and this doe ≈øo often untill they be ≈øufficiently impregnated with the ≈øalt Armoniack of the Vinegar as with their proper ferment. Dige≈øt them in a temperate Balneo, that they may be re≈øolved into a Liquor like oil. Then di≈øtil this Liquor in ≈øand in a Retort, with a large Receiver annexed to it, and well clo≈øed that no ≈øpirits evaporate, together with the ob≈øervation of the degrees of the fire: then there wil di≈øtil forth a ≈øpirit of ≈øuch a fragrant ≈ømel that the fragrancie of all flowers, and compounded perfumes are not to be compared to it. After Di≈øtillation when all things are cold, take out, and ca≈øt away the black feces which is of no u≈øe. Then ≈øeparate the yellow oil, which ≈øwims on the top of the ≈øpirit, and the bloud red oil which ≈øinks to the bottome of it: Separate the flegm from the ≈øpirit in Balneo. Thou ≈øhalt by this means have a mo≈øt fragrant ≈øpirit that even ravi≈øheth the ≈øen≈øes; and ≈øo bal≈øamical, that it cures all old and new ≈øores inward and outward, and ≈øo cordiall that the dying are with admiration revived with it.
They that have this medicine need ≈øcarce u≈øe any other either for inward or outward griefs.

div.head: How to turn Quick-≈øilver into a water without mixing any thing with it, and to make thereof a good Purgative and Diaphoretick medicine.
div.p:
Take an ounce of Quick-≈øilver not purified, put it into a bolt head of gla≈øs, which you mu≈øt nip up, ≈øet it over a ≈øtrong fire in ≈øand for the ≈øpace of two months, and the Quick-≈øilver wil be turned into a red ≈øparkling Precipitate. Take this powder, and lay it thin on a Marble in a Cellar for the ≈øpace of two months, and it wil be turned into a water, which may be ≈øafely
taken inwardly, it wil work a little upward and downward, but chiefly by ≈øweat.
Note that you may ≈øet divers gla≈ø≈øes with the ≈øame matter in the ≈øame Furnace, that ≈øo you may make the greater quantity at a time.
I ≈øuppo≈øe it is the Sulphur which is in the Quick-≈øilver, and makes it ≈øo black, that being ≈øtirred up by the heat of the fire, fixeth the Mercury.

div.head: A fragrant oil of Mercury.
div.p: Take of Mercury ≈øeven times ≈øublimed, and as often revived with un≈ølaked Lime, as much as you plea≈øe, di≈ø≈øolve it in ≈øpirit of Nitre in a moderate heat, then ab≈øtract the ≈øpirit of ≈øalt, and edulcorate it very well by boiling it in ≈øpirit of Vinegar: then ab≈øtract the ≈øpirit of Vinegar, and wa≈øh it again with di≈øtilled rain water: then dry it, and dige≈øt it two months in a like quantity of the be≈øt rectified ≈øpirit of Wine you can get. Di≈øtil them by Retort, making your fire moderate at the beginning, afterwards increa≈øing it; then evaporate the ≈øpirit of Wine in Balneo, and there will remain in the bottome a mo≈øt fragrant oil of Mercury.
This oil ≈øo purifies the bloud by ≈øweat and urine, that it cures all di≈øtempers that ari≈øe from the impurity thereof, as the venereal di≈øea≈øe, &c.
The truth is, they that have this medicine well made need but few other medicines: the do≈øe is four or five drops.

div.head: To turn Mercury into a water by it ≈øelf.
div.p: Set this following ve≈ø≈øell being made of iron into a Furnace, ≈øo that the three bowls thereof be within the Furnace, and the Pipe and Receiver be without. Make your Furnace ≈øo as that there be a great hole left open at the top: where you mu≈øt put in your coals, ≈øhutting it afterward with a cover of ≈øtone made fit thereunto; on the top al≈øo mu≈øt be holes to let in air.

div.head: The Ve≈ø≈øell for this Operation.
div.p: Fir≈øt make your Iron ve≈ø≈øel as red hot as po≈ø≈øibly it can be made (or el≈øe you do nothing) having fir≈øt annexed an earthen well-glazed Receiver to the bottom of it. Then put half an ounce of Quick-≈øilver at a time in at the top (which pre≈øently ≈øtop with clay) and pre≈øently the Mercury will come over, part in a ≈øharp Liquor, and part as crude a Mercury as it was before, which you may put in again till it be all turned to water.
Note that unle≈øs the Quick-≈øilver give a great crack pre≈øently after it is put in, it is a ≈øign that the ve≈ø≈øell was not hot enough.
This operation being well pro≈øecuted may produce a medicine with which none under the Philo≈øophers Elixir may compare.

div.head: How to di≈øtill Spirits, and Oils out of Minerals, Vegetables, Bones, Horns, and fa≈øter, and in a greater quantity in one hour then in the common way in twenty four. This mu≈øt be done in ≈øuch a Furnace as this.
div.p: A, Signifies the Furnace with its iron, or earthen di≈øtilling ve≈ø≈øell walled in, to which a very large Recipient is joined. B, the Di≈øtiller, who with his left hand taketh off the cover, and with his right ca≈øteth in his prepared matter with an iron lad ‚Ä¢ e. C, the form of the di≈øtilling ve≈ø≈øell. D, the ≈øame, as it appeareth inward, E, the form of the ve≈ø≈øell not walled in but ≈øtanding on the coals for other u≈øes.
This Furnace mu≈øt be twice ≈øo high as wide, and the pipe mu≈øt be a foot long out of the Furnace.
The ve≈ø≈øell walled in mu≈øt be of earth for the di≈øtilling of Antimony, Sulphur, and ≈øuch things as will corode iron: but for other things iron is mo≈øt convenient.

Before you make any di≈øt ‚Ä¢ llation, let the ve≈ø≈øell which is walled in be red hot, then by little and little ca≈øt in your matter, which mu≈øt be cut or powdered ≈ømall, and clap down the cover into the fal≈øe bottome above, which is full of molten lead, and therefore ≈øuffereth no fume to goe forth.
When you ≈øee the fumes in the Receiver (which mu≈øt be of gla≈øs) to cea≈øe; and conden≈øed into a Liquor, then put in more matter.
By this way you may make a far greater di≈øpatch and di≈øtill a greater quantity out of the ≈øame proportion of matter, then by the common way.

By this way there is no danger of breaking your Receiver, and you may end and begin when you plea≈øe, and try divers experiments in one hour, and cannot make the fire too ≈øtrong, and may make the ≈øpirits of ≈øuch things as can hardly or not ≈øo well be made by a Retort, as the ≈øpirits of Salt, of Tartar, Harts-horn, Antimony, &c.

Salt and ≈øuch things as will flow mu≈øt have a bole, or powder of brick mixed with them before they be ca≈øt into the ve≈ø≈øell, or if you plea≈øe you may fir≈øt di≈ø≈øolve what ≈øalt you plea≈øe, and with red hot gro≈øs powder of Brick, imbibe the water, then ca≈øt in this powder by little and little into the di≈øtilling ve≈ø≈øell, and the Salt by this means will yeeld its ≈øpirit quickly and in aboundance. By either of the≈øe two wayes you may make a pound of the ≈øpirit of Nitre in an hour, and of ≈øalt in two hours.

Now whereas ≈øome things yeeld a ≈øpirit, and a thick and heavy oil, they may be rectified thus, viz. by putting them into a Retort, and di≈øtilling them in ≈øand or a≈øhes with a graduall heat: there wil come forth the flegme of ≈øome Liquors fir≈øt, and then the ≈øpirit; and of other ≈øome the ≈øpirit, and then the flegm, but of all the≈øe the heavy thick oil at la≈øt; which by di≈øtilling off becomes far clearer then before, which may again be rectified
by ≈øpirit of ≈øalt as I have ≈øhewed before, and therefore need not here repeat it.

div.head: To make an oil of Lapis Calaminaris.
div.p: Take of Lapis Calaminaris powdered, as much as you plea≈øe, pour on it five or ≈øix times as much of rectified ≈øpirit of Salt, ≈øhake them together continually or el≈øe it will be congealed into a hard ma≈øs, which can hardly be mollified again: when no more will di≈ø≈øolve in frigido, put it in warm ≈øand ≈øo long till the ≈øpirit of ≈øalt be of a high yellow colour; then pour it off and put on more til all be di≈ø≈øolved that wil, ca≈øt away the feces, put the ≈øolution into a gla≈øs body, and di≈øtill it in ≈øand: about the third part of the ≈øpirit of Salt cometh over as in≈øipid as common water, though the ≈øpirit were well rectified before, for the drine≈øs of the Lapis Calaminaris (which is the drie≈øt of all Minerals and Metals except Zink) retaineth the ≈øpirit after the flegm is come over; let the gla≈øs cool, and thou ≈øhalt find at the bottome a thick red oil very fat, even as Olive olive, and not very coro≈øive; keep it from the air, or el≈øe it turneth into water.
It is of wonderfull vertue for inward and outward griefs, for it hath in it a pure golden Sulphur.
Common Sulphur mixed with this oil, and melted in a ≈øtrong fire ≈øwimmeth like water above, and is tran≈øparent.

This oil di≈øtilled in a Retort with pure ≈øand in a ≈øtrong fire, yeeldeth a ≈øpirit like fire ≈øcarce to be contained in any ve≈ø≈øel, and di≈ø≈øolveth all metals except ≈øilver, and reduceth pure ≈øpirit of Wine into an oyl within a few days.

div.head: To make oyl of Talk.
div.p:
Take of the be≈øt Talk reduced into very thin flakes, make them red hot, and then quench them in the ≈øtronge≈øt Lixivium that Sope-boylers u≈øe; doe this fifteen times and it will become as white as ≈ønow: then powder it very ≈ømall and calcine it by fumigation i. e. by the fume of ≈øome very ≈øharp ≈øpirit as of Aqua fortis, or the like: when it hath been thus calcined for
the ≈øpace of a fortnight, it wil become ≈øomewhat mucilaginous, then ≈øet it in any heat of putrefaction as it is (for it hath imbibed enough of the ≈øharp ≈øpirit to moi≈øten and ferment it) for the ≈øpace of two months in a bolt head nipt up: then evaporate the acid ≈øpirit and dulcifie it with di≈øtilled rain water. After this extract what thou can≈øt out of it with the be≈øt rectified ≈øpirit of Wine, pour off the ≈øolution and evaporate the ≈øpirit of Wine, and at the bottome will be a mo≈øt beautiful oyl.
The oyl is the mo≈øt glorious fucus or paint in the World.

div.head: To make oyl of Talk another way.
div.p: Take of the fore≈øaid powder of Talk after it hath been putrefied, and again dulcified as much as you plea≈øe, put four times as much of the be≈øt circulated oyl of Camphire to it, dige≈øt them in Hor≈øe dung till all the powder be di≈ø≈øolved, and the oyl become mucilaginous, which will be within two months.
This is for the ≈øame u≈øe as the former.
There is required a great deal of pains and care and no ≈ømall co≈øt in the preparation of the≈øe oyls.

div.head: Oyl is made of Bole Armoniack, terra ≈øigillata, and ≈øuch kind of clay earths, thus.
div.p: Take of either of tho≈øe earths, as much as you plea≈øe, break it into ≈ømall pieces, and put it into a Retort over a naked fire for the ≈øpace of 12 hours, and there will di≈øtill into the Receiver (which mu≈øt be large) the flegm, then white Spirits in a little quantity, yet of a grateful ta≈øte and ≈ømel.

div.head: Oyl out of the≈øe kinds of earth is made better thus.
div.p:
Take of either of the≈øe earths, which you plea≈øe, as much as you will; pour upon it di≈øtilled rain water, ≈øet it in ≈øome warm place for a month or more, and the oyline≈øs will ≈øeparate from its body, of its own accord, and ≈øwim upon the water. Separate the water by a tunnel, and di≈øtil the oyl with five parts of the ≈øpirit of Wine well rectified, and there will come forth an oyl
oyl of a golden colour, ≈øwimming on the ≈øpirit which is a mo≈øt excellent Bal≈øame.

div.head: Spirit of un≈ølaked Lime is made thus.
div.p: Take of un≈ølaked Lime as much as thou plea≈øe≈øt; reduce it into a ≈øubtle powder, imbibe it with Spirit of Wine mo≈øt highly rectified (which mu≈øt be pure from all its flegm, or el≈øe you labour in vain) as much as it can imbibe; draw off the ≈øpirit of Wine with a gentle heat, cohobate it 8 or 10 times, ≈øo will the fiery vertue of the Lime be fortified.‚ÄîTake of this levigated Lime 10 ounces, pure ≈øalt of Tartar one ounce, the feces of Tartar after the ≈øalt is extracted 11 ounces; mix the≈øe well together, put them into a gla≈øs Retort coated, ≈øee that 2 parts of 3 be empty, di≈øtill them into two Receivers, the flegm into one, the ≈øpirit into the other, which mu≈øt have a little of rectified ≈øpirit of Wine in it to receive the ≈øpirit.
If thou wilt ≈øeparate the ≈øpirit of Wine, then put fire to it, and the ≈øpirit of Wine will burn away, and the ≈øpirit of the Lime ≈øtay behinde, which is a kind of a fixed ≈øpirit.
This is a very ≈øecret for the con≈øuming the Stone in the bladder, and the curing of the Gout.

div.head: Oyl made out of Tile-≈øtones, called the Oyl of Philo≈øophers.
div.p: Take of Bricks or Tiles, as many as you plea≈øe, break them into ≈ømall pieces, make them red fire hot, then quench them in pure old Oyl Olive (in which let them lye till they be cold) then take them out and grind them very ≈ømall, let the powder be put in a gla≈øs Retort, coated, a fit Receiver being put thereto and di≈øtil off the oyl in a naked fire by degrees, which being di≈øtilled off keep in a viall clo≈øe ≈øtopt.
This oyl is wonderfull penetrating, and is good again≈øt all cold di≈øtempers what≈øoever.

div.head: The Liquor or Water of Corall, is made thus.
div.p: Take Salt-Armoniack well purified by ≈øublimation, of red Coral finely powdered, of each a like quantity; ≈øublime them ≈øo often till the Corall will no more ri≈øe up, then take the Calx of Corall that remains in the bottome of the ≈øublimatory and put it on a marble or gla≈øs in the cellar to be di≈ø≈øolved; that which will not be di≈ø≈øolved ≈øublime again, and do as before till all be di≈ø≈øolved: and ≈øo thou ha≈øt the Liquor of Corall.

Note that if thou wilt have the true tincture of Coral, evaporate the humidity of the fore≈øaid Liquor, then extract the tincture out of the powder with ≈øpirit of Wine, which ≈øpirit evaporate to the con≈øi≈øtency of honey: and thou ha≈øt a mo≈øt rare medicine.
This medicine ≈øtrengtheneth all the parts in the body, and cures all di≈øtempers that ari≈øe from the weakne≈øs thereof.

div.head: To make a Water out of Lapis Armenus that ≈øhall have neither ta≈øte nor ≈ømell, a few drops whereof ≈øhal purge.
div.p: Take of Lapis Armenus powdered ≈ømall, and calcined, as much as you plea≈øe, ≈øublime it with ≈øalt Armoniack until it will ≈øublime no more but remain in the bottome of the ≈øublimatory, then take it out, and lay it very thin upon a marble in a cellar, and there let it lye two months, and it will be almo≈øt all di≈ø≈øolved into a Liquor.

Or thus:
Take of Lapis Armenus powdered ≈ømall and calcined, as much as you plea≈øe, pour upon it of di≈øtilled Vinegar, as much as wil cover it four fingers breadth, then ≈øet it over a gentle heat ≈øtirring of it two or three times in an hour, for the ≈øpace of ≈øix hours or thereabouts; then the ≈øpirit being tinged very blew with the powder, filtre off from the feces, then pour more ≈øpirit of vinegar on the feces and doe as before, till the ≈øpirit be tinged no more, then take all the blew ≈øpirit and vapour it
away, and at the bottome you ≈øhall have a ≈øalt, which you mu≈øt put into a calcining pot, and calcine ≈øo long in the fire till no more vapour will ari≈øe, and it become a dark red powder, then put it upon a marble in the cellar for the ≈øpace of two months, and it well be di≈ø≈øolved into a Liquor, a few drops whereof put into a gla≈øs of beer will purge delicately.

div.head: How to make a Furnace that ≈øhall of it ≈øelf without any ve≈ø≈øels which ≈øhould contain the matter, being put into it, ≈øublime Minerals, and di≈øtil all manner of Oils and Spirits out of Minerals, Vegetables, and Animals, and that in a very great quantity, in a very ≈øhort time, and with ≈ømall co≈øt.
div.p: THe Furnace is made as followeth: It may be made of one piece by a Potter, or of brick, round, or four-≈øquare, greater or le≈ø≈øer as you plea≈øe: if the in≈øide be one ≈øpan broad in the middle, it mu≈øt be four high: one for the A≈øh-hole, another above the grate to the middle Coal-hole, and two above the Pipe; this pipe being made of earth or iron mu≈øt be a ≈øpan long betwixt the Furnace and the Receiver, and a third part as wide as the Furnace within.
The Recipients mu≈øt be made of gla≈øs, or very good earth well luted together; the greater the better.
The fir≈øt Figure.
The ≈øecond Figure.
A, Signifies the A≈øh-hole, which mu≈øt be as wide as the Furnace, and alwayes open that the fire may burn the ≈øtronger.
B, The middle hole of the Furnace for the putting in of coals.
C, The ≈øtopple made of ≈øtone.
D, The upper hole of the Furnace with a fal≈øe bottome wherein ≈øand lyeth, which is there laid that the cover may lye the clo≈øer and keep in the fumes the better.
E, The Cover, which mu≈øt pre≈øently be clapt on a≈ø≈øoon as the matter to be di≈øtilled is put in.
F, The Pipe, which goeth out of the Furnace, and to which the Receiver is fitted.
G, The fir≈øt Recipient for flowers.
H, The ≈øecond.
I, The third.
K, A Stool whereon the first Recipient re≈øteth, in the mid≈øt whereof is a hole, through which goeth the neck of the Recipient, to which another gla≈øs is fitted.
L, The Gla≈øs fitted to the Recipient for the uniting the ≈øpirits that drop down.
M, Another Recipient united to the former gla≈øs, and into which the united ≈øpirits do run.
N, A Stoole through the middle whereof goeth a ≈øcrew for the rai≈øing of that Gla≈øs which is ≈øet under the fir≈øt Recipient, higher, or lower.
O,
P, The Grate with two thick iron bars, which lye fa≈øt, upon which four or five thinner are layed, which may be ≈øtirred when the Furnace is made clean.

Thus far the fir≈øt of the figures is explained, by which you may ≈øee how ≈øublimation and di≈øtillation is made at one time, viz. of tho≈øe things which will yeeld both flowers, and ≈øpirits, (the flowers ≈øticking in the three upper Recipients, and the ≈øpirits dropping down into the lower.)

Now follows the explanation of the ≈øecond figure, which is the ≈øame with the former in re≈øpect of the Furnace it ≈øelf, but differing in re≈øpect of the Recipients, which ≈øerve for the receiving of the ≈øpirits and oyls of ≈øuch things as yeeld no flowers. Therefore I ≈øhall begin with the explanation of the Receivers.
G, The fir≈øt crooked pipe as it is fitted to the pipe that comes out of the Furnace.

H, The-Recipient with its cover, in which is one hole for one crooked pipe to goe through, as you may ≈øee in the fir≈øt H, and two holes for two pipes to goe through, as you may ≈øee in the ≈øecond H, and in H H.

Note that the≈øe pipes may either be fa≈øtned to the cover being all of one piece, or they mu≈øt be wel luted, that no vapours may pa≈øs through. Now you mu≈øt conceive that in the lower Receivers the vapour that goeth out of the fir≈øt pipe goeth fir≈øt into the Receiver, then out of that into the next pipe, and ≈øo forward till it cometh into the la≈øt Receiver, by which means it is much cooled (for indeed ≈øuch vapours that come out of the Furnace, e≈øpecially when ≈øome materials are di≈øtilled, if there were not ≈øome ≈øuch art to cool them, would break all Recipients.)
I, A tub of water, wherein the Recipient ≈øtands, to cool the vapours and conden≈øe them.
K, The fir≈øt crooked pipe as it goeth into the Recipient.
L, The ≈øecond crooked pipe, whereof one end goeth into one Receiver, and another end into another.
M, The la≈øt crooked pipe to which you mu≈øt annex a Receiver.

Now the manner of di≈øtilling is thus; Let the Furnace be full of coals wel kindled, then ca≈øt on your matter, and ≈øtop your Furnace clo≈øe: This Furnace needs no Retort, or other ve≈ø≈øels to ≈øet into it, neither can you doe any hurt by too much or too little fire, and you may fini≈øh your operation when you plea≈øe, and in one hour try divers experiments. It ≈øaveth very much time and co≈øt, and in one hour will doe as much as can be done in another Furnace in 24. In one hour you may make a pound of ≈øpirit of Salt with four or five pound of coals, and as much flower of Antimony in a like ≈øpace of time, and with as few coals.

If your materials be vegetables, or horn, or bones, cut them ≈ømall; If hard Minerals, let them be powdered very ≈ømall; if
≈øalts, let them fir≈øt be di≈ø≈øolved in water, which water mu≈øt be imbibed with red hot coals until all the liquor be imbibed: then ca≈øt in tho≈øe coals into the Furnace.
If you would by this means procure the ≈øpirit of hard Minerals, as of Antimony, &c. you mu≈øt take them as they come from the Mine before they have pa≈ø≈øed the fire.
By this Furnace you may make the ≈øpirits of ≈øuch things which will not yeeld them in any other way.
Note that ≈øuch oyls and ≈øpirits as are drawne by this Furnace mu≈øt be rectified in ≈øpirit of Salt, as I have above ≈øhewed.

div.head: Ros Vitrioli is made thus.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt Dan≈øick Vitriall, as much as you plea≈øe, uncalcined, put it into a gla≈øs gourd and di≈øtill it in the ≈øand, and there will come over a water ≈øomewhat ≈øharpi≈øh.
This Water or Ros is of greater u≈øe then the ≈øpirit or oyl thereof.
It helpeth all inward inflammations, as of the Liver, Kidneys, Stomach, helps the ebullition of bloud, and all di≈øtempers that come from thence.
This is that flegm, which mo≈øt vapour away, but it is becau≈øe they know not the vertues thereof.

div.head: A ≈øweet green oyl of Vitriall is made thus.
div.p: Take as many Copperas ≈øtones as you plea≈øe, beat them ≈ømall, and lay them in a cool cellar, and in twenty or thirty days they will attract the air, and look black, and after fourteen days become whiti≈øh and ≈øweeti≈øh, then di≈ø≈øolve them in di≈øtilled rain water, then filter and evaporate the water, and they will ≈øhoot into green Cry≈øtals, which you may di≈ø≈øolve in a Cellar per deliquium, being fir≈øt beaten ≈ømall, and layed on a marble ≈øtone.
This liquor is that famous medicine of Paracel≈øus for the falling ≈øickne≈øs, a few drops thereof being taken in any appropriated liquor.
Take heed that it come at no ≈øtrong fire, for then ≈øaith Paracel≈øus it lo≈øeth its greenne≈øs, and as much as it lo≈øeth of that, ≈øo much al≈øo of its vertue.
A ≈øpirit may be drawn from hence by an ingenious Arti≈øt, that will ≈ømell like Musk, or Amber.

div.head: The Sulphur of Vitriall may with ≈øpirit of wine be extracted thus.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt Dan≈øick Vitriall half a pound, dry it by a gentle fire till it be whiti≈øh, then pour on it of the be≈øt rectified ≈øpirit of Wine thirty ounces: (Note that there mu≈øt come to it no other moi≈øture then the ≈øpirit of Wine, the gla≈øs al≈øo mu≈øt be very dry, el≈øe you labour in vain) then dige≈øt it in hor≈øe dung the ≈øpace of a month, then decant from the feces the ≈øpirit of Wine without any troubling of it, then in Balneo evaporate the ≈øpirit, and at the bottome you will have a yellow liquor of a mo≈øt wonderfull ≈øtipticity.
This liquor is a famous Anodynum, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing all noxious vapours what≈øoever and cau≈øing re≈øt.
A few drops there may be taken in any ≈øpecifical Liquor.

div.head: A Sudorificall Water to be u≈øed outwardly.
div.p: Take of ≈øublimed Mercury very finely powdered an ounce and half, of Euphorbium powdered a ≈øcruple, ≈øpirit of Wine well rectified, and Ro≈øewater, of each a pound, dige≈øt them two or three hours in a gentle Balneo, the neck of the ve≈ø≈øell which mu≈øt be very long being wel ≈øtopt, then let them boll a quarter of an hour: when the liquor is cold pour it from the feces, and keep it in a gla≈øs.

If the back bone be bathed with this Water, or the wri≈øt of tho≈øe that be weak, it cau≈øeth ≈øweat pre≈øently, if it be done in the bed. By which means di≈øea≈øes that require ≈øweat may be cured. Al≈øo any pained place by being bathed with this Water is in a little time ea≈øed.
Note that you mu≈øt not bathe any place above three or four times with it, for by being too often u≈øed it contracts the skin.

div.head: How to rectifie Oyls and Spirits of Minerals.
div.p: Put the Liquor that is di≈øtilled from Minerals into the Retort, to which give fire by degrees, and the ≈øpirit wil ri≈øe up into the upper Receiver, and the heavy oyl wil go into the middle Receiver which is the bigge≈øt of all; and into the little Receiver annexed to the end of the middle, wil pa≈øs ≈øome of the ≈øpirit, which though it pa≈ø≈øeth into the middle Receiver, wil not ≈øtay there, but goeth beyond it becau≈øe it finds vent.

div.head: Waters, Spirits, and Oils, ≈øimple and compound out of Animals.
Oyl and Water out of Bloud is made tbus.
div.p: TAke of bloud as much as you plea≈øe, let it ≈øtand in putrefaction in a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øell clo≈øe covered the ≈øpace of forty days, then di≈øtil it in a≈øhes, and there wil come forth a water and oyl; extract the ≈øalt out of the feces with the ≈øaid water, calcine the ≈øalt in a crucible, and then di≈ø≈øolve it in the ≈øaid water, and then di≈øtil off the water (which will be a good rectifying of the water) and dry the ≈øalt very well, which then mix with the fore≈øaid oyl being fir≈øt rectified, and dige≈øt them both together for the ≈øpace of a month.

div.head: To make the Magi≈øtery of bloud.
div.p:
Take of the pure≈øt bloud as much as you plea≈øe, put it into a
Pelican, that three parts of four may be empty, and dige≈øt it a month in hor≈øe dung (in which time it will ≈øwell and become as much more as it was when it was put in) then di≈øtil off the flegm in Balneo, and in the bottome will remain the magi≈øtery of bloud, which mu≈øt be di≈øtilled, and cohobated nine times in a Retort in a≈øhes, and then it is perfected.
This Magi≈øtery is of excellent vertue, which being taken inwardly and applyed outwardly, cureth mo≈øt di≈øea≈øes, and ea≈øeth pain, being very bal≈øamicall.

div.head: E ‚Ä¢ ixir of Mummie is made thus.
div.p: Take of Mummy (viz. of mans fle≈øh hardened) cut ≈ømall four ounces, ≈øpirit of wine terebinthinated ten ounces, put them into a glazed ve≈ø≈øell, (three parts of four being empty) which ≈øet in hor≈øe dung to dige≈øt for the ≈øpace of a month, then take it out and expre≈øs it, let the expre≈ø≈øion be circulated a month, then let it run through Manica Hippocratis, then evaporate the ≈øpirit till that which remains in the bottome be like an oyl, which is the true Elixir of Mummy.
This Elixir is a wonderful pre≈øervative again≈øt all infections, al≈øo very bal≈øamicall.

div.head: The e≈ø≈øence of mans brains.
div.p: Take the brains of a young man that hath dyed a violent death, together with the membranes, arteries, veins, nerves, al the pith of the back, brui≈øe the≈øe in a ≈øtone mortar til they become a kind of pap, then put as much of the ≈øpirit of wine, as will cover it three or four fingers breadth: then put it into a large gla≈øs that three parts of four be empty, being hermetically clo≈øed, then dige≈øt it half a year in hor≈øe dung, then take it out and di≈øtill it in Balneo, and cohobate the water til the greate≈øt part of the brains be di≈øtilled off.
A ≈øcruple or two of this e≈ø≈øence taken in ≈øome ≈øpecificall water once in a day, is a mo≈øt infallible medicine again≈øt the falling ≈øickne≈øs.

div.head: A famous ≈øpirit made out of Cranium humanum.
div.p: Take of Crannium humanum as much as you plea≈øe, break it into ≈ømal pieces, which put into a gla≈øs. Retort well coated, with a large Receiver well luted, then put a ≈øtrong fire to it by degrees continuing of it till you ≈øee no more fumes comes forth; and you ≈øhal have a yellowi≈øh ≈øpirit, a red oyl, and a volatile ≈øalt.
Take this ≈øalt and the yellow ≈øpirit and dige≈øt them by circulation two or three months in Balneo, and thou ≈øhalt have a mo≈øt excellent ≈øpirit.
This ≈øpirit is of affinity with, if not the ≈øame as that famous ≈øpirit of Dr. Goddards in Holborn.
It helps the falling ≈øickne≈øs, gout, drop≈øie, infirm ≈øtomach, and indeed ≈øtrengthens all weak parts, and openeth all ob≈øtructions, and is a kinde of Panacea.

div.head: Another excellent ≈øpirit made out of Cranium, Harts horn, or Ivory.
div.p: Take of either of the≈øe, (if you take Cranium it need not be brui≈øed at all, only broke into little pieces; if Harts horn or Ivory, you mu≈øt cut them in thin pieces) lay it piece by piece upon a net ≈øpread upon any ve≈ø≈øell being almo≈øt full of water, cover this net with another ve≈ø≈øel very clo≈øe, then make the water boyl, and keep it boyling three dayes and three nights, and in that time the bones or horns, will be as ≈øoft as chee≈øe; then pound them, and to every pound thereof put half a pound of Hungarian vitrial uncalcined, and as much ≈øpirit of wine as wil make them into a thin pa≈øte. This pa≈øte dige≈øt in a ve≈ø≈øell hermetically ≈øeald the ≈øpace of a month in Balneo, then di≈øtil it in a Retort in ≈øand till all be dry, and you ≈øhall have a mo≈øt excellent ≈øpirit.
This ≈øpirit is of wonderful u≈øe in the Epilep≈øie, Convul≈øions, all Feavers putrid or pe≈øtilential, pa≈ø≈øions of the heart, and is a very excellent Sudorifick.
This ≈øpirit may be taken from the quantity of half an ounce to an ounce in ≈øome ≈øpecificall liquor.

div.head: A Water and Oyl made out of Hair.
div.p: Fill an earthen Retort with hair cut ≈ømall, ≈øet it over the fire, and fit a Receiver to it, and there will come over a very ≈øtinking Water and Oyl.

This water and Oyl is u≈øed in Germany to be ≈øprinkled upon fences and hedges to keep wild and hurtfull Cattle from coming to do harm in any place, for ≈øuch is the ≈øtink of this liquor that it doth affright them from coming to any place near it.

div.head: Water of Milk is made thus.
div.p: Take of what Milk thou plea≈øe≈øt a gallon, in it di≈ø≈øolve half a pound of ≈øalt, and put to it two handful of Plantain, and an ounce of Licori≈øh ≈øliced, then di≈øtil it in a hot Stil with a gentle fire.
This water is of excellent u≈øe in hot di≈øtempers of the Lungs and Kidneys.
You may put in other ingredients according to the u≈øe you would have it for.

div.head: An excellent compound water of Milk for any inflammations in the eyes.
div.p: Let inflamed eyes be wa≈øhed three or four times in a day with this water, and it helpeth them wonderfully.

div.head: Spirit of ∆≤rine is made thus.
div.p:
Take of the Urine of a young man drinking much wine, as much as you plea≈øe, let it ≈øtand in gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øels in putrefaction 40 dayes, then pouring it from its feces di≈øtil it in a gla≈øs gourd in ≈øand, til all be dry, then cohobate the ≈øaid ≈øpirit on the Caput Mortuum three times, then di≈øtill it in a gourd of a long neck, and there will a≈øcend be≈øides the ≈øpirit a cry≈øtalline ≈øalt,
which thou maye≈øt either keep by it ≈øelf, being called the volatile ≈øalt of Urine, or mix it with its ≈øpirit which will thereby become very penetrating, if they be dige≈øted for ≈øome days together.
Note that the pipe of the head mu≈øt be wide, or el≈øe the volatile ≈øalt will ≈øoon ≈øtop it.
Note that this ≈øalt is ≈øo penetrating that it penetrateth the body of the gla≈øs.
This Spirit by rectification may be made ≈øo pure and ≈øubtle, that it will burn as fire, and di≈ø≈øolve gold and precious ≈øtones.
This being often applyed to any place pained with the gout, ea≈øeth it pre≈øently, it al≈øo quickens any part that is benummed.
The ≈øalt volatile is Helmonts famous Medicine for the Jaundies.

div.head: A compound Spirit of ∆≤rine.
div.p: Take of Hungarian Vitriall a pound, the Urine of a Boy that is healthy, four pints: put the≈øe into a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel well clo≈øed that three parts of four may be empty; dige≈øt them in Balneo for the ≈øpace of a month, then di≈øtil them in a≈øhes til all be dry.
This ≈øpirit is of great vertue in the Epilep≈øie, Gout, Drop≈øie, Convul≈øions, being taken from two drams to half an ounce in ≈øome ≈øpecifical Liquor.

div.head: To make a ≈øpirit of Honey.
div.p: Take good ≈øtrong ≈øtale Mead, otherwi≈øe called Metheglin, as much as thou plea≈øe≈øt, di≈øtil it in a Copper Stil or Alembick, with its refrigeratory, and it wil yeeld a ≈øpirit like Aqua vitae.

div.head: The quinte≈ø≈øence of honey is made thus.
div.p:
Take of the pure≈øt Honey two pound, of Fountain water one pound; boyl the≈øe together til the water be boyled away, taking off all the ≈øcum that ri≈øeth, then take the Honey
and put it into a gla≈øs, four parts of five being empty, clo≈øe it well, and ≈øet in dige≈øtion a whole year, and thou ≈øhalt have the e≈ø≈øence of Honey ≈øwimming on the top in form of an Oyle, being of as fragrant ≈ømel as any thing in the World; the flegm wil be in the middle, and the feculent matter in the bottome, of a dark colour, and ≈øtinking ≈ømel.

div.head: Some make the quinte≈ø≈øence of Honey after this manner.
div.p: Take as much Honey as thou plea≈øe≈øt, of the be≈øt, put it into a gourd of gla≈øs, fir≈øt di≈øtil off the flegm in Balneo, then extract the tincture out from what remains, with the ≈øaid water, then calcine the remaining feces and extract from thence the ≈øalt with the fore≈øaid water being di≈øtilled off from the tincture, calcine the ≈øalt and melt it in a crucible, then let it di≈ø≈øolve in a cellar; then again evaporate it away, and thou ≈øhalt have a mo≈øt white ≈øalt, which let imbibe as much of the tincture as it will; dige≈øt them for three months, and thou ≈øhalt have an e≈ø≈øence of Honey.

div.head: An e≈ø≈øence of Honey may be made thus.
div.p: Take of Honey wel de≈øpumated as much as you plea≈øe, pour upon it as much of the be≈øt rectified ≈øpirit of Wine as will cover it five or ≈øix fingers breadth, dige≈øt them in a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel wel clo≈øed (the fourth part only being ful) in a temperate Balneo the ≈øpace of a fortnight, or til the ≈øpirit be very wel tinged, then decant off the ≈øpirit and put on more til all the tincture be extracted, then put all the≈øe tinctures together, and evaporate the ≈øpirit till what remains begin to be thicki≈øh at the bottome and of a golden colour.
This is a very excellent e≈ø≈øence of Honey, and is of ≈øo plea≈øant an odour that ≈øcarce any thing is like to it.
It is ≈øo cordial that it even revives the dying if two or three drops thereof be taken in ≈øome cordial water.

div.head: A mo≈øt ≈øtrong Spirit of the Vinegar of Honey.
div.p: Take a pound of Honey, put to it of the be≈øt White wine vinegar ≈øix pints, an ounce of white Pepper brui≈øed ≈ømal, of the ≈øtronge≈øt Mu≈øtard-≈øeed brui≈øed three ounces, put the≈øe into a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel that three parts of four may be empty, dige≈øt them in a temperate Balneo, or ≈øet the ve≈ø≈øell in the ≈øunne for the ≈øpace of a fortnight, then di≈øtil them in Balneo, and thou ≈øhalt have a ≈øpirit farre ≈øharper then the common ≈øpirit of Vinegar.
This ≈øpirit is ≈øtronger, and better then any common di≈øtilled Vinegar for the di≈ø≈øolving of hard things, and extracting the tinctures out of things.

div.head: Oyl or quinte≈ø≈øence of Wax.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt Wax a pound, as much of pure ≈øand well wa≈øhed from al its impurity, and again dryed; Fir≈øt melt the wax, and then mix the ≈øand with it very exactly, then put them into a gla≈øs Retort well coated, fit a ≈øtrong Receiver to it, and ≈øet it in ≈øand, give it fire by degrees, continuing it four days, which at la≈øt mu≈øt be very ≈øtrong, and there wil come off a ≈øpirituous oyl, which mu≈øt be rectified ≈øeven times in a gla≈øs Retort, every time changing the Retort, and you ≈øhal have a ≈øubtle oyl of a golden colour.

This oyl extracts the vertues out of all flowers pre≈øently, being ≈øet in the ≈øun, it is wonderful Bal≈øamical for the cure of wounds or ulcers both inward and outward, it al≈øo being applyed outwardly ea≈øeth all pains, quickens any deaded member, as in the palfie.

div.head: Water is made out of any fle≈øh thus.
div.p:
Take what fle≈øh you plea≈øe, the bloudie≈øt part thereof, unwa≈øhed, being cut very ≈ømal, and then brui≈øed (or if it be a feathered fowl, take it being cha≈øed up and down until it be wearyed, and then ≈øuddenly ≈øtrangled, the feathers being plucked off without
out putting of it into water; and being thus plucked bare, and the bowels taken out, cut the fle≈øh, bones, gizard, liver, heart,) and pour upon it as much water as will be ≈øufficient, with what ≈øpices and hearbs thou plea≈øe≈øt, then ≈øet it over a gentle fire in an earthen ve≈ø≈øel glazed the ≈øpace of 24 houres, then put the head upon it and lute it clo≈øe, and there wil di≈øtil off a comfortable re≈øtorative water.

div.head: Water or Liquor is made out of fle≈øh thus.
div.p: Take of what fle≈øh you plea≈øe, or feathered fowl prepared as before, brui≈øe it ≈ømal, and put it into a copper ve≈ø≈øell tinned within ≈øide, without any water being put to it, put a cover to it and lute it clo≈øe, and ≈øet it in Balneo, or over the vapour of ≈øeething water, and if the fle≈øh be tender it will be turned into a clear liquor the ≈øpace of 12 hours, if harder it will require a longer time: You may put in what ≈øpices or hearbs you plea≈øe to give it a good reli≈øh and odour; after all is done you may ≈øtrain it and keep it for u≈øe being very re≈øtaurative and good for weak ≈øtomachs that cannot concoct hard meat.
If this be dige≈øted in a Pelican, or bolt head a fortnight, it will be far better.

After this manner may be pre≈øerved
Snails
Worms, and ≈øuch like:
which are very medicinable.

div.head: A very excellent re≈øtorative Liquor.
div.p:
Take of the heart, lungs, and liver of a Calf, the ≈øame parts of a Fox new killed, cut them ≈ømal, put to them a quart of Shel Snails wel ≈øcoured in ≈øalt water; let them be put into a copper ve≈ø≈øel tinned within ≈øide, and covered clo≈øe that no vapour come forth, ≈øet this ve≈ø≈øel over the vapour of ≈øeething water, and in 24 hours or thereabouts, they wil be for the mo≈øt part of them turned into a Liquor of them≈øelves; then take out this Liquor and put it into a large Pelican, or Bolt-head, putting to them a quart of old Mallago wine, Ro≈øemary flowers,
Betony flowers, Marygold flowers, Mar≈øh wallow-flowers, of each a handful, half a pound of Rai≈øins of the Sun ≈øtoned, Mace and Nutmeg of each two drams: dige≈øt all the≈øe together the ≈øpace of a fortnight, then pour off that which is clear from the feces and ≈øweeten it with ≈øugar, or ≈øyrup of Gilly flowers, and let the Patient thereof five or fix ≈øpoonfuls, three or four times in a day.

This Liquor recovereth the decaying ≈øtrength wonderfully; they that by rea≈øon of their weakne≈øs, can neither eat or dige≈øt any manner of common meat, will in a ≈øhort time be ≈øen≈øibly ≈øtrengthened if they drink a quarter of a pint of this morning and evening.
It is very good in con≈øumptions, and repairs the radical moi≈øture marvellou≈øly.

div.head: A Bal≈øame made of Bears fat.
div.p: Take of Bears fat a pound, di≈øtil it in a Retort, and rectifie it three or four times: to this thus rectified put the tincture of Ro≈øemary and Sage made with ≈øpirit of Wine, of each three ounces, mix them wel together, in the≈øe infu≈øe Cloves, Cinnamon, Saffron, Nutmegs, of each three drams, in warm a≈øhes the ≈øpace of a night, then ≈øtrain them and put to the oyl four ounces of the be≈øt wax melted, and mingled wel together.
This is a mo≈øt incomparable bal≈øame for the Gout, and Pal≈øie.

div.head: The Oyl of Snakes and Adders.
div.p: Take Snakes or Adders when they are fat, which will be in June or July, cut off their heads and take off their skins, and unbowel them, and put them into a gla≈øs gourd; and pour on ≈øo much of the pure ≈øpirit of Wine wel rectified, that it may cover them four or five fingers breadth; ≈øtop the gla≈øs wel, and ≈øet it in Balneo til all their ≈øub≈øtance be turned into an oyl, which keep wel ≈øtopt for your u≈øe.
This oyl doth wonderfull cures in recovering hearing in tho≈øe that be deaf, if a few drops thereof be put warm into the ears.
A Noble man of Germany that was famous for curing the deaf u≈øed this as his chiefe≈øt medicine, by which they ≈øay he cured tho≈øe that were born deaf.

div.head: The Quinte≈ø≈øence of Snakes, Adders, or Vipers.
div.p: Take of the bigge≈øt and fatte≈øt Snakes, Adders, or Vipers, which you can get in June or July, cut off their heads, take off their skins, and unbowel them, then cut them into ≈ømal pieces, and put them into a gla≈øs of a wide mouth, and ≈øet them in a warm Balneo, that they may be well dryed, which wil be done in three or four days. Then take them out, and put them into a bolt head, and pour on them of the be≈øt alcolizated Wine as much as wil cover them ≈øix or eight fingers breadth. Stop the gla≈øs hermetically, and dige≈øt them fifteen days in Balneo, or ≈øo long til the Wine be ≈øufficiently covered, which pour forth; then pour on more of the fore≈øaid ≈øpirit of Wine til all the quinte≈ø≈øence be extracted: Then put all the tinged ≈øpirits together: and draw off the ≈øpirit in a gentle Balneo, til it be thick at the bottome, on this pour ≈øpirit of Wine Caryophyllated, and ≈øtir them wel together, and dige≈øt them in a Circulatory ten days, then ab≈øtract the ≈øpirit of Wine, and the quinte≈ø≈øence remaineth at the bottome perfect.

This quinte≈ø≈øence is of extraordinary vertue for the purifying of the bloud, fle≈øh, and skin, and con≈øequently of all di≈øea≈øes therein. It cures al≈øo the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, and ≈øtrengthens the brain, ≈øight, and hearing, and pre≈øerveth from Gray hairs, reneweth Youth, pre≈øerveth Women from Abortion, cureth the Gout, Con≈øumption, cau≈øeth ≈øweat, is very good in, and again≈øt pe≈øtilential infections.

div.head: Viper wine is made thus.
div.p: Take the be≈øt fat Vipers, cut off their heads, take off their skins, and unbowel them, then put them into the be≈øt Canary Sack; four or ≈øix according to their bigne≈øs, into a gallon: Let them ≈øtand two or three months, then draw off your wine as you drink it.

Some put them alive into the Wine, and there ≈øuffocate them, and afterwards take them out, and cut off their heads, take off their skins, and unbowel them, and then put them into the ≈øaid Wine again, and doe as before.
This Wine hath the ≈øame vertue as the foregoing quinte≈ø≈øence, it al≈øo provoketh to Venery, and cures the Lepro≈øie, and ≈øuch like corruption of bloud.

div.head: Kunrath's famous Water, called Aqua Magnanimitatis.
div.p: Take of Pi≈ømires or Ants (the bigge≈øt, that have a ≈øowri≈øh ≈ømel, are the be≈øt) two hand≈øuls, ≈øpirit of wine a gallon, dige≈øt them in a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel clo≈øe ≈øhut the ≈øpace of a month, in which time they wil be di≈ø≈øolved into a Liquor, then di≈øtil them in Balneo til all be dry. Then put the ≈øame quantity of Ants as before, dige≈øt and di≈øtil them in the ≈øaid Liquor as before: doe this three times, then aromatize the ≈øpirit with ≈øome Cinnamon.

This ≈øpirit is of excellent u≈øe to ≈øtir up the Animal ≈øpirit: in ≈øo much that John Ca≈øimire Pal≈øgrave of the Rhene and Seyfrie of Collen, Generall again≈øt the Turks, did always drink of it when they went to fight, to encrea≈øe magnanimity and courage, which it did even to admiration.
This ≈øpirit doth al≈øo wonderfully irritate them that are ≈ølothfull to Venery.

This oyl doth be≈øides what is ≈øpoken of the ≈øpirit, help deafne≈øs exceedingly, two or three drops being dropped into the ear after it is wel ≈øyringed, once in a day, for a week together.

div.head: Another-Aqua Magnanimitatis is made thus.
div.p: Take of Ants or Pi≈ømires a handful, of their Eggs two hundred, of Millepedes i. e. div.p: Take of Doves dung dryed as much as you plea≈øe, to every pound put a pint of Rheni≈øh wine, in which let it ≈øteep all night in a gentle Balneo, then di≈øtil it in a gla≈øs gourd in a≈øhes: Cohobate this Liquor three times, if there be any volatile ≈øalt mix it with the water.

Take of the dung of a hor≈øe that is fed in the ≈øtable as much as you plea≈øe, let it ≈øtand two days out of the Sun, and out of the wet, to every pound of this pour a pint of white wine, let them
≈øtand in a warm Balneo a fortnight; then di≈øtil them in a gla≈øs gourd in ≈øand, cohobate this three or four times; if there be any volatile ≈øalt, mix it with the water.

div.p: Take of the young buds of Harts horn, while≈øt they are ful of bloud and moi≈øt; brui≈øe them into a pa≈øte, then mix as much Canary wine as will make a very thin pa≈øte, di≈øtil them in a≈øhes till they be very dry.
This is an excellent Sudorifick in all burning Feavers and Epidemical di≈øea≈øes; if a ≈øpoonful be taken by it ≈øelf, or in any appropriated Liquor.

div.p: Take of what bones you plea≈øe, reduce them to a gro≈øs powder, put them into a Retort, putting a ≈øtrong fire by degrees thereunto; and there will come forth an oyl, and volatile ≈øalt, both which thou maye≈øt mix together, and dige≈øt them into an e≈ø≈øence, the oyl being fir≈øt rectified with ≈øpirit of wine.

div.head: The Water of Swallows again≈øt the Falling ≈øickne≈ø≈øe.
