Take of Swallows, cut them into pieces without ≈øeparating any thing from them, ≈øix ounces, of Ca≈øtoreum cut ≈ømall an ounce, mix them together, infu≈øe them 12 hours in half a pin ‚Ä¢
of Canary wine, then put them into a gla≈øs gourd and di≈øtill them in ≈øand till all be dry, then cohobate the Liquor three times.
This water being drank to the quantity of two ≈øpoonfull every morning, cureth them that have the Falling ≈øickne≈øs.

div.head: Oyl out of Egs is made thus.
div.p: Take of the yelks of egs boyled very hard, rub them in pieces with your fingers, then fry them in a pan over a gentle fire, continually ≈øtirring them with a ≈øpoon til they become red, and the oyl be re≈øolved, and flow from them; then put them into a hair cloth, and ≈øo pre≈ø≈øe forth the oyl.
This oyl clean≈øeth the skin from any filthine≈ø≈øe contracted by heat; it cureth pu≈øtles, chaps, excoriations, ring-worms, but e≈øpecially all burnings.

div.head: A Water of the whites of Eggs that will cure a wound without any vi≈øible ≈øcarre.
div.p: Take as many eggs as you plea≈øe, boyl them very hard, then cut them in the middle and take out the yelks, filling up the cavities with ≈øome of tho≈øe whites being fir≈øt brui≈øed into a pa≈øte, then put both ≈øides of the egg together as before, and tye them together with a thread, and with a ≈øtring hang them in the middle of a gourd gla≈øs that they touch not the ≈øides, ≈øtop this gla≈øs very clo≈øe and ≈øet it in Balneo, and you ≈øhall ≈øee tho≈øe whites which were brui≈øed drop down into a Liquor: which you mu≈øt gather up out of the bottome of the gla≈øs, and keep.
You will have very little of this Liquor.
This Liquor applyed to any green wound with a feather cures it pre≈øently where≈øoever it be, without any vi≈øible ≈øcar. It cures mo≈øt wonderfully all wounds in the eyes.

div.head: A Water of Crabs is made thus.
div.p:
Take Crabs or Craw-fi≈øh, as many as you plea≈øe, break them to pieces, then macerate them in water of Sengreen for
the ≈øpace of a day, then di≈øtil them, cohobate the water three times.
This Water is of ≈øingular vertue in all manner of inflammations inward and outward.

div.head: An Oylor Liquor is made out of Crabs eyes thus.
div.p: Take of Crabs eyes very finely powdered five parts, oyl of Tartar Per Deliquium ≈øix parts (This oyl of Tartar mu≈øt be made of ≈øalt of Tartar after it hath flowed in the fire) dige≈øt them in hor≈øe dung the ≈øpace of a month, then coagulate the Liquor and make an extraction with the be≈øt rectified ≈øpirit of Wine that can be made (or el≈øe you lo≈øe your labour) then evaporate the ≈øpirit of Wine, and there remaines an oyl at the bottome.
This oyl is of wonderful vertue in all putrid Feavers, and ≈øuch like di≈øtempers, al≈øo in all ob≈øtructions, e≈øpecially of the Kidneys.

div.head: Water of Spawn of Frogs is made thus.
div.p: Take of the Spawn of Frogs gathered in March, as much as you plea≈øe, put a handful of Salt to every quart, and put them into a common cold Still and with a gentle fire di≈øtil off the water till no more will di≈øtill.

div.head: A compound water of the Sperm of Frogs.
div.p: Take of the ≈øperm of Frogs gathered in March about the new of the Moon, four pound, of Cow dung fre≈øh, ≈øix pound, mix them well together, and let them ≈øtand the ≈øpace of a day, then di≈øtil them in a≈øhes.
This water allays all hot pains both inward, and outward, e≈øpecially of the Gout.

div.head: Another compound water of the ≈øperm of Frogs.
div.p: Take of the Sperm of Frogs gathered in March, two pound, and half, the Urine of a young man three pints, new Treacle two ounces and a half, white Vitrial, Salt, Allum, of each four ounces, then di≈øtil them, and put to the water an ounce and half of the Salt of Vitriall, Camphire, and Saffron, of each an ounce.
This water being applyed outwardly helpeth all pains, e≈øpecially of the Gout, and ≈øuch like, al≈øo allayeth hot or cold ≈øwellings; It al≈øo ≈øtancheth bleeding.

div.head: A Mi≈øcellany of Spagyricall Experiments and Curio≈øities.
BOOK V.
The Spagyricall Anatomie of Water.
div.p:
WAter ≈øeems to be a body ≈øo very Homogeneall, as if neither Nature or Art could di≈øcover any Heterogeneity in the parts thereof: thus indeed it ≈øeems to the eye of the vulgar, but to that of a Philo≈øopher far otherwi≈øe, as I ≈øhall endeavor to make credible by pre≈øenting to your con≈øideration a twofold proce≈øs of the di≈øcovering the di≈ø≈øimilary parts thereof; whereof the one is naturall only, and the other artificiall; But before I ≈øpeak of either, it mu≈øt be premi≈øed, that in the element of Water there is great plenty of the ≈øpirit of the World, which is more predominant in it then in any other element, for the u≈øe and benefit of univer≈øall nature; and that this ≈øpirit hath three di≈øtinct ≈øub≈øtances, viz. Salt, Sulphur, and
Mercury. Now by ≈øalt we mu≈øt under≈øtand a ≈øub≈øtance very dry, vitall, and radicall, having in it the beginning of corpori≈øication, as I may ≈øo call it: by Sulphur, a ≈øub≈øtance ful of light and vital heat, or vivifying fire, containing in it ≈øelf the beginning of motion: by Mercury, a ≈øub≈øtance abounding with radical moi≈øture, with which the Sulphur of life, or vital fire, is cheri≈øhed and pre≈øerved. Now the≈øe ≈øub≈øtances which are in the Spirit of the World make all Fountaines, and Waters, but with ≈øome difference, according to the predominancy of either. This ≈øeveral predominancy therefore is the ground of the variety of productions; I ≈øay, of productions, becau≈øe all things are produced out of Water: for Water is both the Sperme, and the Men≈øtruum of the World; the former, becau≈øe it includes the ≈øeed of every thing; the latter, becau≈øe the Sperme of Nature is put refied in it, that the ≈øeed included in it ≈øhould be actuated, and take upon it the divers Formes of things; and becau≈øe by it the ≈øeed it ≈øelf, and all things produced of ≈øeed grow, and are encrea≈øed: Now this being premi≈øed, I ≈øhall ≈øhew you what the naturall proce≈ø≈øe is, which I ≈øhal make plain by in≈øtancing in three ≈øeveral productions, viz. of the ≈øpawn of Frogs, of Stones, and of Vegetables.

The Spawne of Frogs is produced after this manner, viz. The Sulphur which is in the Water, being by the heat of the Sun re≈øolved, and di≈ø≈øolved, is greedily, and with delight conceived by the Element of Water, even as the Sperme of a Male is by the Matrix of the Female, and that upon this account. The Water wants ≈øiccity, which the Sulphur hath, and therefore exceedingly de≈øiring it, doth greedily attract it to it ≈øelf: Sulphur al≈øo wants humidity, and therefore attracts the humidity of the Water: Moreover the humidity of the Water hath the humidity of the Salt laid up occultly in it: al≈øo the Sulphur cheri≈øheth the humidity of the fire, and de≈øires nothing more then the humidity of the Salt, that is in the Water. Sulphur al≈øo contains the ≈øiccity of the Salt, whence it is that Salt requires a ≈øiccity from the Sulphur. And thus do the≈øe attractive vertues mutually act upon each others ≈øubject.
Now by this means there is a conception made in the water which now begins to be turgid, puffed up, and troubled, as al≈øo to be gro≈ø≈øer, and more ≈ølimie, until out of the ≈øpermatick ve≈ø≈øels the ≈øpermes be ca≈øt upward, in which ≈øpermes after a while appeare black ≈øpecks, which are the ≈øeed of the Frogs, and by the heat of the Sun, are in a ≈øhort time turned into the ≈øame; by which it appears there are di≈ø≈øimilary parts in Water.

2 Stones are produced out of Water that hath a Mucilaginous Mercury, which the Salt, with which it al≈øo abounds, fixeth into Stones. This you may ≈øee cleared by putting ≈øtones into the water, for they wil after a time contract a mucilaginous ≈ølimy matter, which being taken out of the water and ≈øet in the Sun, becomes to be of a ≈øtony nature. And whence come tho≈øe ≈øtones, gravel, and ≈øand which we ≈øee in Springs? they are not wa≈øhed down out of the Mountains and Hils (as ≈øome think) from whence the waters ≈øpring, neither were they in the earth before the Springs brake forth, (as ≈øome imagine) and now appear by wa≈øhing away of the earth from them; for if you dig round about the ≈øprings, even beyond the heads of them, you ≈øhal find no ≈øtones at all in the earth, only in the veins thereof through which the water runs; Now the rea≈øon of the ≈ømalne≈ø≈øe of the≈øe ≈øtones, is the continual motion of the water, which hinders them from being united into a continued bigne≈ø≈øe. I ≈øhall make a further confirmation of this in the artificial proce≈ø≈øe of manife≈øting the Heterogeneity of Water. I ≈øhal here only adde the a≈ø≈øertion of He ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ont, ≈øaying that with his Altahe≈øt all ≈øtones, and indeed all things may be turned into Water? If ≈øo, then you know what the Maxime is, viz. All things may be re≈øolved into that from whence they had their beginning.

3 Vegetables are produced out of Water, as you may clearly ≈øee by the Waters ≈øending forth Plants that have no roots fixed in the bottome; of which ≈øort is the Heart called Duck-weed, which putteth forth a little ≈øtring into the Water, which is as it were the root thereof. For the confirmation of this, that this Heart may be produced out of meer
Water, there is a Gentleman at this time in the City, of no ≈ømall worth, that ≈øaith he had fair water ≈øtanding in a gla≈øs divers yeares, and at la≈øt a Plant ≈øprang out of it. Al≈øo if you put ≈øome Plants, as Water-mint, &c. into a gla≈øs of fair water, it wil germinate, and ≈øhoot out into a great length, and al≈øo take root in the Water, which root will in a ≈øhort time be ≈øo encrea≈øed, and extended, as to fill up the gla≈øs: but you mu≈øt remember that you put fre≈øh water into the gla≈ø≈øe once in two or three dayes. Hereunto al≈øo may be added the experiment of Helmont, concerning the growth of a tree; For (≈øaith he) I took two hundred pound weight of earth dryed in an oven, and put it into a ve≈ø≈øel, in which I ≈øet a Willow tree which weighed five pound, which by the addition of water to the earth, did in five yeares time grow to ≈øuch a bigne≈ø≈øe, as that it weighed one hundred ≈øixty nine pound; at which time I al≈øo dryed and weighed the earth, and within two ounces it retained its former weight. Be≈øides, the ancients have ob≈øerved that ≈øome Hearbs have grown out of ≈ønow being putrefied: and do not we ≈øee that all Vegetables are nouri≈øhed, and increa≈øed with an in≈øipid water, for what el≈øe is their juice? If you cut a Vine in the month of March, it wil drop divers gallons of in≈øipid water, which water if it had remained in the trunk of the Vine, would in a little time have been dige≈øted into leaves, ≈øtalks, and grapes, which grapes al≈øo by a further maturation would have yeelded a Wine, out of which you might have extracted a burning ≈øpirit; Now I ≈øay although this in≈øipid water be by the ≈øpecificall Sulphur and Salt of the Vine fixed into the ≈øtalks, leaves, and grapes of the vine, yet the≈øe give it not a corporificative matter, for that it had before, and an aptitude and potentiality to become what afterwards it proves to be: for indeed ≈øtalks, leaves, and grapes were potentially in it before, all which now it becomes to be actually, by vertue of the Sun, and of the afore≈øaid Sulphur and Salt, whereof the two latter were originally in the ≈ømal ≈øeed, and therefore as I ≈øaid could not adde any bulk to them.

Moreover doe not we ≈øee that when things are burnt and
putrefied, they a≈øcend up into the air by way of vapour, and fume, and then de≈øcend by way of in≈øipid dew, or rain? Now what do all the≈øe ≈øignifie but that from water are all things produced, and in it are di≈ø≈øimilary parts?

2 The artificiall proce≈ø≈øe is this: take of what water you plea≈øe, whether Well water, Fountaine, River, or Raine water, as much as you plea≈øe, let it ≈øettle three or four houres, untill the ≈ølime thereof ≈øeparates it ≈øelfe: then dige≈øt it the ≈øpace of a month; after which time evaporate the fourth part, by a very gentle heat, and ca≈øt it away being but the flegm, then di≈øtil off the remainder of the water till the feces only be left, which feces will be a ≈ølimy ≈øalti≈øh ≈øub≈øtance: this middle ≈øub≈øtance di≈øtill again as before, ca≈øting away every time the fourth part, as flegme, and keeping the feces by them≈øelves for a further u≈øe; and this doe ≈øeven times. Note that after the fourth or fifth di≈øtillation the water will di≈øtil over like milke, colouring the head of your Still ≈øo that it can hardly be wa≈øhed or ≈øcoured off. This pure water after the ≈øeventh di≈øtillation will leave no feces behind: and if you dige≈øt it three months it will be coagulated into Stones and Cry≈øtals, which ≈øome magnifie very much for the cure of inward, and outward putrefactions, out of which al≈øo may be made a di≈ø≈øolving ≈øpirit. Note that as this water ≈øtands in dige≈øtion you may ≈øee divers curious colours. Now as for the feces which I ≈øpake of (which indeed all waters even the ≈øweete≈øt leave at the bottome) being as I ≈øaid a ≈øalti≈øh ≈ølime, and in ta≈øte as it were a Medium betwixt Salt, and Nitre; take them and di≈øtill them in a Retort in ≈øand, and there will fir≈øt come forth a white fume, which being conden≈øed de≈øcendeth in a ≈øtraight line to the bottome, next will come over a red Oyl of great efficacy, exceeding the vertues of the ≈øpirit of Salt or Nitre. For confirmation of part of this proce≈ø≈øe, take May dew gathered in a morning (when it hath not rained the night before) and put it into a gla≈øs ve≈ø≈øel, covered with a parchment pricked full of holes, and ≈øet it in the heat of the Sun for the ≈øpace of four months, and there will ≈øtore of green feces fall to the bottome, the re≈øidue of
the water being white and clear. Now by all this you may conclude what manner of di≈ø≈øimilarity there is in the parts of water. I ≈øhall adde but one ob≈øervation more, and ≈øo conclude this ≈øubject.

Take a ≈ølint out of River water, and put it into a gourd gla≈ø≈øe, poure upon it as much River Water as will fill the gla≈ø≈øe, evaporate this water till the flint be drye, then poure on more fre≈øh water, doe this ≈øo long till the flint will fill up the gla≈øs, (for in a little time it will fill it up, and become to be of the forme or figure of the gla≈ø≈øe) for it attracts to it ≈øelfe the mucilaginou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the water, which indeed is a ≈ølimy ≈øalti≈øh matter, and the true matter of Stones. And thus thou ≈øhalt have that done by Art in few dayes, which Nature would have been perfecting many yeares, and indeed ju≈øt ≈øuch a flint as is produced in the Rivers. Any one that ≈øhould ≈øee this flint in the gla≈ø≈øe would wonder how it ≈øhould come in there. You may break your gla≈ø≈øe and take out the flint.

There are divers ≈øuch proce≈ø≈øes which may be u≈øed, but in effect they demon≈øtrate but little more concerning the potentiall Heterogeneity of water, and therefore to avoid tediou≈øne≈ø≈øe, I ≈øhall here end with the Anatomy of Water, concerning which if any one can make a further illu≈øtration, let him be candid and impart it, and I ≈øhall be glad to learn of him, and in the meane time let him accept of the≈øe my endeavours.

div.head: The Spagyricall Anatomy of Wine.
div.p: I Shall not ≈øpeak here of the juice of grapes as being naturally divided into Wine, Tartar, and Lees, but of Wine as artificially divided into pure Spirit, Flegm, and Feces.

1 The ≈øpirit is that hot, ≈øubtle, pure, clear, cordiall, and bal≈øamicall ≈øub≈øtance, which ari≈øeth with a ≈ømall heat after four or five di≈øtillations, being indeed but the twentieth part of the Wine. This ≈øpirit is not that inebriating ≈øub≈øtance of the Wine as mo≈øt think, for a man may drink the ≈øpirit that is extracted out of ten pints of Wine without di≈øtempering of his br ‚Ä¢ in at all, when as perhaps he would be di≈øtempered with drinking a pint or two of the Wine.

Now this ≈øpirit contains in it a ≈øubtle Armoniack, and e≈ø≈øentiall Sulphur in≈øeparably conjoined, which indeed are the life of the ≈øpirit, and may be ≈øeparated from the Mercuriall or watery part thereof, which after ≈øeparation of them remains in≈øpid, but yet of wonderfull ≈øubtility. They may be ≈øeparated thus: Fir≈øt rectifie the ≈øpirit as high as you can the ordinary way: then rectifie it once or twice in th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe following ve≈ø≈øels.

Note that if there be any flegm remaining in the ≈øpirit, it wil go no further then the middle Receiver, e≈øpecially the ≈øecond time. By this means thou ≈øhalt have ≈øo ≈øubtle a ≈øpirit, that unle≈øs it be kept in a ve≈ø≈øell clo≈øe ≈øtopt, it will flye away in the air. Then take of this ≈øpirit two ounces, and poure it upon ≈øix ounces of calcined Tartar before the ≈øalt be extracted, and mingle them well together; then di≈øtill it in Balneo, and there will
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ me over an in≈øipid water, which as I ≈øaid before is very ≈øubtle,
then put on a like quantity of the ≈øaid ≈øpirit, as before, and di≈øtil it off, and thus do ≈øo long til the water that comes over is not in≈øipid, but the ≈øpirit comes over again hot as it was poured on: for by this time the fixed matter is glutted with the ≈øalt Armoniack, and Sulphur of the ≈øpirit. Then put this dryed matter into a gla≈ø≈øe ≈øublimatory, and put fire to it, and there will ≈øublime a Salt from thence even as Camphire is ≈øublimed. This ≈øalt is the true e≈ø≈øence of Wine indeed, and its vertues are wonderful, for there is no di≈øea≈øe whether inward or outward that can with≈øtand it. This is that e≈ø≈øence of Wine of the Philo≈øophers, which is ≈øo penetrating, ≈øo wonderful cordial and bal≈øamical, which if thou doe≈øt once obtain, thou ≈øhalt need but few other medicines.

Now this ≈øpirit or Aqua vitae, is in all Vegetables, as you may ≈øee in Malt, and Vegetables that are put refied before they be di≈øtilled, which then yeeld a burning ≈øpirit; yet it is in Wine more then in any other Liquors: I ≈øay Liquors, for if you take eight gallons of Sack, and as much Wheat, which is a ≈øolid body, the Wheat being malted, will yeeld more Aqua vitae then the Sack.

2 The flegm is that which remains after the ≈øpirit is di≈øtilled off, and is a putrid, in≈øipid, cold, narcotick, and inebriating Liquor, debilitating the ≈øtomach and offending the head. A few ≈øpoonfuls of this will pre≈øently make a man drunk, nay the flegm of half a pint of Wine will make a man drunk, when as two pints of Wine it ≈øelfe would hardly doe it: whence you may collect what a great corrector of Malignant ≈øpirits, and vapours the ≈øpirit of Wine is; which, while≈øt it is mixed with the flegm before di≈øtillation, doth temper and correct this inebriating quality thereof, and as it doth thus, ≈øo al≈øo being given (I mean the pure deflegmated ≈øpirit) to them that are already inebriated, doth much allay their di≈øtemper. This flegm therefore being of ≈øo narcotick a quality is the cau≈øe of Pal≈øies, and ≈øuch like di≈øtempers.

Moreover it is to be ob≈øerved that when this flegm is to be di≈øtilled off, there remains at the bottom a vi≈øcous corro≈øive matter, which by rea≈øon of its vi≈øco≈øity is the cau≈øe of ob≈øtructions, and by rea≈øon of its corro≈øivene≈ø≈øe the cau≈øe of the gout, colick, ≈øtone, &c.
3 This feces being di≈øtilled yeelds a ≈øharp ≈øpirit, and fetid oyl, which leave behind them a ≈øalti≈øh ≈øub≈øtance, out of which when the ≈øalt is extracted, there remains an in≈øipid earth.

Now if any ≈øhall object again≈øt what I have a≈ø≈øerted, and ≈øay that Aqua vitae, or ≈øpirit of Wine are inebriating, the cau≈øes of Palfie, ≈øtone, gout, colick, weak ≈øtomachs, and ≈øuch like: as we ≈øee by dayly experience in tho≈øe that are given to the drinking of the≈øe Liquors: to which I an≈øwer it is true: but then I mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh of Aqua vitae, and ≈øpirit of Wine, for there is a common Aqua vitae, and ≈øpirit of Wine, of which al≈øo they make Ani≈øeed water by putting a few Ani≈øeeds thereunto, and other ≈øuch like waters, as Clove, Angelica, Lemmon, &c. With which this Nation is mo≈øt abominably cheated, and their health impaired. But the≈øe are not rectified throughly, but three parts of four of them are an in≈øipid Narcotick flegm, containing in it the feces I ≈øpake of, all which I can in a day ≈øeparate from the true pure ≈øpirit, which ≈øpirit rather prevents then cau≈øes ≈øuch di≈øtempers: And the truth is, all the goodne≈ø≈øe of the Wine is from this pure ≈øpirit.

div.head: The famous Arcanum, or re≈øtorative Medicament of Paracel≈øus, called his Homunculus.
div.p: FIr≈øt we mu≈øt under≈øtand that there are three acceptions of the word Homunculus in Paracel≈øus, which are the≈øe.
1 Homunculus is a ≈øuper≈øtitious image made in the place or name of any one, that it may contain an A≈øtrall and invi≈øible man; wherefore it was made for a ≈øuper≈øtitious u≈øe.

2 Homunculus is taken for an artificiall man, made of SpermÃÑa humamum Ma≈øculinum, dige≈øted into the ≈øhape of a man, and then nouri≈øhed and encrea≈øed with the e≈ø≈øence of mans bloud; and this is not repugnant to the po≈ø≈øibility of Nature and Art. But is one of the greate≈øt wonders of God which he ever did ≈øuffer mortall man to know. I ≈øhall not here ≈øet down the full proce≈ø≈øe becau≈øe I think it unfit to be done, at lea≈øt to be divulged: be≈øides, neither this nor the former is for my pre≈øent purpo≈øe.

3 Homuncu ‚Ä¢ us is taken for a mo≈øt excellent Arcanum or Medicament extracted by the ≈øpagyricall Art, from the chiefe≈øt ≈øtaffe
of the naturall life in man, and according to this acception I ≈øhall here ≈øpeak of it: But before I ≈øhew you the proce≈ø≈øe I ≈øhall give you an account why this Medicament is called Homunculus; and it is this.

No wi≈øe man will deny that the ≈øtaffe of life is the nutriment thereof, and that the chiefe≈øt nutriment is Bread and Wine, being ordained by God and Nature above all other things for the ≈øu≈øtentation thereof. Be≈øides Paracel≈øus preferred this nutriment for the generation of the bloud and ≈øpirits, and the forming thence the Sperm of this Homunculus. Now by a ≈øutable allu≈øion the nutriment is taken for the life of man, and e≈øpecially becau≈øe it is tran≈ømuted into life: and again the life is taken for the man, for unle≈ø≈øe a man be alive he is not a man, but the carca≈ø≈øe only of a man, and the ba≈øe≈øt part thereof, which cannot perfectly be taken for the whole man, as the noble≈øt part may. In as much therefore as the nutriment, or aliment of life may be called the life of man, and the life of man be called man; this nutriment extracted out of Bread and Wine, and being by dige≈øtion exalted into the highe≈øt purity of a nutritive ≈øub≈øtance, and con≈øequently becoming the life of man, being ≈øo potentially, may Metaphorically be called Homunculus.

The proce≈ø≈øe, which in part ≈øhall be ≈øet down allegorically is thus: Take the be≈øt Wheat and the be≈øt Wine, of each a like quantity, put them into a gla≈ø≈øe, which you mu≈øt hermetically clo≈øe: then let them putrefie in hor≈øe dung three days, or until the Wheat begin to germinate, or to ≈øprout forth, which then mu≈øt be taken forth and brui≈øed in a Mortar, and be pre≈ø≈øed through a linnen cloth, and there will come forth a white juice like milk; you mu≈øt ca≈øt away the feces: Let this juice be put into a gla≈ø≈øe, which mu≈øt not be above half full; ≈øtop it clo≈øe and ≈øet it in hor≈øe dung as before, for the ≈øpace of fifty days. If the heat be temperate, and not exceeding the naturall heat of a man, the matter will be turned into a ≈øpagyricall bloud, and fle≈øh, like an Embryo. This is the principal, and next matter, out of which is generated a twofold ≈øperm, viz. of the father and mother, generating the Homunculus, without which there can be made no generation, whether humane, or animall.

From the bloud, and fle≈øh of this Embryo let the water be
≈øeparated in Balneo, and the air in a≈øhes, and both be kept by them≈øelves. Then to the feces of the latter di≈øtillation let the water of the former di≈øtillation be added, both which mu≈øt (the gla≈ø≈øe being clo≈øe ≈øtopt) putrefie in Balneo the ≈øpace of ten days, after this di≈øtill the water the ≈øecond time, (which is then the vehiculum of the fir≈øt) together with the fire, in a≈øhes, then di≈øtill off this water in a gentle Balneo, and in the bottom remains the fire which mu≈øt be di≈øtilled in a≈øhes. Keep both the≈øe a part. And thus you have the four Elements ≈øeparated from the Chaos of the Embryo.

The feculent earth is to be reverberated in a clo≈øe ve≈ø≈øel for the ≈øpace of four dayes: In the interim di≈øtil off the fourth part of the fir≈øt di≈øtillation in Balneo, and ca≈øt it away; the other three parts di≈øtill in a≈øhes, and pour it upon the reverberated earth, and di≈øtill it in a ≈øtrong fire; cohobate it four times, and ≈øo you ≈øhall have a very clear water, which you mu≈øt keep by it ≈øelf: Then pour the air on the ≈øame earth, and di≈øtil it in a ≈øtrong fire, and there will come over a clear, ≈øplendid, odoriferous water, which mu≈øt be kept apart: After this pour the fire upon the fir≈øt water, and putrefie them together in Balneo the ≈øpace of three days, then put them into a Retort and di≈øtil them in ≈øand, and there will come over a water ta≈øting of the fire: let this water be di≈øtilled in Balneo, and what di≈øtils off keep by it ≈øelf, as al≈øo what remains in the bottome, which is the fire, keep by it ≈øelf. This la≈øt di≈øtilled water pour again upon its earth, and let them be macerated together in Balneo for the ≈øpace of three dayes, and then let all the water be di≈øtilled in ≈øand, and let what will ari≈øe be ≈øeparated in Balneo, and the re≈øidence remaining in the bottome be re≈øerved with the former re≈øidence. Let the water be again poured upon the earth, be ab≈øtracted, and ≈øeparated as before, untill nothing remain in the bottom, which is not ≈øeparated in Balneo. This being done, let the water which was la≈øt ≈øeparated be mixed with the re≈øidue of its fire, and be macerated in Balneo three or four dayes, and all be di≈øtilled in Balneo, that can a≈øcend with that heat, and let what remains be di≈øtilled in a≈øhes from the fire, and what ≈øhall be elevated is aeriall; and what remains in the bottome is fiery. The≈øe two la≈øt Liquors are a≈øcribed to the two fir≈øt principles, the former to
Mercury, and the latter to Sulphur, and are accounted by Paracel≈øus, not as Elements, but their vitall parts, being as it were the natural ≈øpirits and ≈øoul, which are in them by nature. Now both are to be rectified, and reflected into their center with a circular motion, that this Mercury may be prepared with its water being kept clear, and odoriferous in the upper place, but the Sulphur by it ≈øelf. Now it remains that we look into the third principle: let the reverberated earth being ground upon a marble imbibe its owne water, which did above remain after the la≈øt ≈øeparation of the Liquors made in Balneo, ≈øo that this be the fourth part of the weight of its earth, and be congealed by the heat of a≈øhes into its earth, and let this be done ≈øo oft, the proportion being ob≈øerved, untill the earth hath drunk up all its water. And la≈øtly let this earth be ≈øublimed into a white powder, as white as ≈ønow, the feces being ca≈øt away. This earth being ≈øublimed and freed from its ob≈øcurity is the true Chaos of the Elements, for it contains tho≈øe things occult, ≈øeeing it is the ≈øalt of nature, in which they lye hid, being as it were reflected in their center. This is the third principle of Paracel≈øus, and the ≈øalt, which is the matrix, in which the two former ≈øperms, viz. of the man and woman, the parents of the Homunculus, viz. of Mercury and Sulphur, are to be put, and to be clo≈øed up together in a glazen womb ≈øealed with Hermes ≈øeals for the true generation of the Homunculus produced from the ≈øpagyricall Embryo: and this is the Homunculus or great Arcanum, otherwi≈øe called the nutritive Medicament of Paracel≈øus.

This Homunculus or nutritive Medicament, is of ≈øuch vertue that pre≈øently after it is taken into the body, it is turned into bloud, and ≈øpirits. If then di≈øea≈øes prove mortall becau≈øe they de≈øtroy the ≈øpirits, what mortal di≈øea≈øe can with≈øtand ≈øuch a medicine, that doth ≈øo ≈øoon repair, and ≈øo ≈øtrongly fortifie the ≈øpirits as this Homunculus being as the oyl to the flame, into which it is immediately turned, thereby renewing the ≈øame? By this Medicament therefore, as di≈øea≈øes are overcome, and expelled, ≈øo al≈øo youth is renewed, and gray hairs prevented.

div.head: An Artificiall way to make Fle≈øh.
div.p: TAke of the crums of the be≈øt wheaten bread a≈ø≈øoon as it comes forth out of the Oven being very hot, as much as you plea≈øe, put it into a gla≈ø≈øe ve≈ø≈øell, which you mu≈øt pre≈øently hermetically clo≈øe. Then ≈øet it in dige≈øtion in a temperate Balneo, the ≈øpace of two months, and it will be turned into a fibrous fle≈øh.

If any Arti≈øt plea≈øe to exalt it to a higher perfection according to the Rules of Art, he may find out, how great a nouri≈øher, and re≈øtorative Wheat is, and what an excellent medicine it may make.

div.head: Paracel≈øus his way for the rai≈øing of a dead bird to life, and for the generating many Serpents of one, both which are performed by putrefaction.
div.p: A Bird is re≈øtored to life thus, viz. Take a Bird, put it alive into a gourd gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øeal it up hermetically, burn it to a≈øhes in the third degree of fire, then putrefie it in hor≈øe dung into a mucilaginous flegm, and ≈øo by a continued dige≈øtion that flegm mu≈øt be brought to a further maturity (being taken out, and put into an ovall ve≈ø≈øell of a ju≈øt bigne≈ø≈øe to hold it) by an exact dige≈øtion, and will ≈øo become a renewed bird: which ≈øaith Pa ‚Ä¢ acel≈øus is one of the greate≈øt wonders in Nature, and ≈øhews the great vertue of putrefaction.

2 Cut a Serpent into ≈ømall pieces, which put into a gourd gla≈ø≈øe which you mu≈øt Hermetically ≈øeal up, then putrefie them in hor≈øe dung, and the whole Serpent will become living again in the gla≈ø≈øe, in the form either of worms or ≈øpawne of fi≈øhes; Now if the≈øe worms be in a fitting manner, brought out of putrefaction, and nouri≈øhed; many hundred Serpents will be bred out of one Serpent, whereof every one will be as big as the fir≈øt. And as it is ≈øaid of the Serpent, ≈øo al≈øo many other living creatures may be rai≈øed, and re≈øtored again.

div.head: To make an artificiall Mallago Wine.
div.p: Fir≈øt take a wine barrell well hooped and dre≈ø≈øed, with one end being open, to which a clo≈øe cover mu≈øt be well fitted, which mu≈øt be to take off and put on at plea≈øure. Set it in a warm place Winter or Summer, and fill it full with clear and pure water, to each three gallons, put ≈øix pound of the be≈øt Mallago Rai≈øins, which you mu≈øt brui≈øe in a ≈øtone Mortar, and then ≈øtrow upon the water, upon each twenty gallons of which you mu≈øt ca≈øt a handfull of Calxvive, then cover the ve≈ø≈øell clo≈øe with the cover, and ca≈øt clothes upon it to keep it warm, and let it ≈øtand four or five dayes to work as Wine or Beer doe when they be new: then ≈øee if the Rai≈øins be ri≈øen up to the top of the Water; if ≈øo, then put them down again, and cover it again as before; let them thus ≈øtand three weeks or a month together, the Rai≈øins being every fourth or fifth day put down in ca≈øe they ri≈øe up. Then put a tap into the ve≈ø≈øell three or four fingers above the bottome, and try if it be good, and ta≈øte like Wine; if not, let it ≈øtand a while longer, but if ≈øo, draw it off into another wine ve≈ø≈øell, and to every twenty gallons that you have drawn off, put a pint of the be≈øt Aqua vitae, two new laid Hen-egs, and a quart of Alligant beaten well together, and let it ≈øtand in a cellar as other wine doth, till it be clear and fit to be drunk.

div.head: To make an artificiall Claret wine.
div.p:
Take ≈øix gallons of water, two gallons of the be≈øt Cidar, put thereunto eight pound of the be≈øt. Mallago Rai≈øins brui≈øed in a Mortar, let them ≈øtand clo≈øe covered in a warm place the ≈øpace of a fortnight, every two days ≈øtirring them well together, then pre≈ø≈øe out the Rai≈øins and put the Liquor into the ≈øaid ve≈ø≈øell again: to which adde a quart of the juice of Ra≈øp-berries, and a pint of the juice of Black cherries, cover this Liquor with Bread ≈øpread thick with ≈øtrong Mu≈øtard, the Mu≈øtard ≈øide being downward, and ≈øo let it work by the fire ≈øide three or four days, then tun it up, and let it ≈øtand a week, & then bottle it up. And it will
ta≈øte as quick as bottle-beer, and indeed become a very plea≈øant drink, and indeed farre better, and whol≈øomer then our common Claret.

div.head: An artificiall Malm≈øey.
div.p: Take two gallons of Engli≈øh honey, put it into eight gallons of the be≈øt Spring water, ≈øet the≈øe in a ve≈ø≈øell over a gentle fire, when they have boyled gently an hour take them off, and when they be cold put them into a ≈ømal barrell or run let, hanging in the ve≈ø≈øell a bag of ≈øpices and ≈øet it in the cellar, and in half a year you may drink thereof.

div.head: To make an excellent aromaticall Hyppocras.
div.p: Take of Cinnamon two ounces, Ginger an ounce, Cloves and Nutmegs of each two drams, of white Pepper half a dram, of Cardamums two drams; of Musk Mallow ≈øeed, three ounces. Let all the≈øe be brui≈øed, and put into a bag and hanged in ≈øix gallons of Wine. Note that you mu≈øt put a weight in the bag to make it fink.
Some boyl the≈øe ≈øpices in Wine, which they then ≈øweeten with ≈øugar, and then let run through a Hyppocras bag, and afterwards bottle it up, and u≈øe when they plea≈øe.

div.head: A ≈øingle Hypocras bag, or Manica Hippocratis.
div.p: When you would have this or any other Liquor to be very clear, you may u≈øe the triple Hypocras bag, for what feces pa≈ø≈øeth the fir≈øt will ≈øtay in the ≈øecond, and what in the ≈øecond will ≈øtay in the la≈øt.

To make an excellent Hypocras Wine in an in≈øtant.
div.p: Take of Cinnamon two ounces, Nurmegs, Ginger, of each half an ounce, Cloves two drams brui≈øe the≈øe ≈ømall, then mix them with as as much Spirit of Wine as will make them into a pa≈øte, let them ≈øtand clo≈øe covered in a gla≈øs the ≈øpace of ≈øix days in a cold place then pre≈ø≈øe ou ‚Ä¢ the Liquor, and keep it in a gla≈øs.
A few drops of this Liquor put into any Wine giveth it a gallant reli≈øh, and odour, and maketh it as good as any Hypocras what≈øoever, and that in an in≈øtant.
Note that if the Wine be of it ≈øelfe har≈øh, it will not be ami≈ø≈øe to ≈øweeten it with Sugar, for thereby it is made far more gratefull.
This al≈øo being put into Beer will make it very plea≈øant, and aromaticall.

div.head: Another way to make Hypocras, or to make any Wine to ta≈øt of any vegetable in an in≈øtant.
div.p: Take what Wine you plea≈øe, and according as you would have it ta≈øt of this or that ≈øpice, or any other vegetable, of one or more together, you may drop a few drops of the di≈øtilled oil of the ≈øaid ≈øpices, or vegetables into the Wine, and brew them well together, and you may make in an in≈øtant all ≈øorts of Hypocras or other Wines: as for example, if you would have Wormwood Wine, two or three drops of oil of Wormwood put into good Rheni≈øh-wine, being well brewed together, will make a Wormword Wine exceeding any that you ≈øhall meet withall in the Rheni≈øh-wine hou≈øes.

div.head: To make a good Rasberry-wine.
div.p: Take a gallon of Sack, in which let two gallons of Ra≈øpberries ≈øtand ≈øteeping the ≈øpace of twenty four houres; then ≈øtrain them, and put to the Liquor three pound of Rai≈øins of the ≈øun ≈øtoned; let them ≈øtand together foure or five days, bring ≈øometimes ≈øtirred together: Then pour off the cleare≈øt, and put it up in bottles, and ≈øet it in a cold place, If it be not ≈øweet enough you may adde ≈øome Sugar to it.

div.head: Two other wayes to make it all the year at an in≈øtant.
div.p: Take of the juice of Ra≈øpberries, put it into a bottle, which you mu≈øt ≈øtop clo≈øe, and ≈øet in a cellar, and it will become clear, and keep all the year, and become very fragrant.

If you put two or three ounces of the Syrup of Ra≈øpes to a pint of Wine it will doe as well, but then you need u≈øe no other Sugar, for that will ≈øweeteen it ≈øufficiently.

div.head: To make Mead or Metheglin that it ≈øhall ta≈øt ≈øtale and quick within a fortnight and be fit to drink.
div.p: To every three gallons of water, put one gallon of the pure≈øt Honey, put what hearbs and ≈øpices you plea≈øe, boyl it, and skim it well, now and then putting in ≈øome water. When it is ≈øufficiently boyled take it off, and when it is almo≈øt cold, put it into a wooden ve≈ø≈øell, and ≈øet it by the ≈øire ≈øide, cover it over with Bread ≈øpread thick with the ≈øtronge≈øt Mu≈øtard, the Mu≈øtard ≈øide being downwards, and ≈øo let it ≈øtand three dayes, and it will worke, only put a cloth over it: Then tunne it up, and after a week draw it forth into bottles, and ≈øet it into a cellar, and after a week more you may drink of it, for it will ta≈øte as quick as bottle beer that is a fortnight old, and indeed as ≈øtale as other Mead will in half a year.

div.head: To make a Spirit of Amber-gry≈øe that a few drops thereof ≈øhall perfume a pint of Wine mo≈øt richly.
div.p: Take of Amber-gry≈øe 2. drams, of Musk a dram, cut them ≈ømall, and put them into a pint of the b ‚Ä¢ ≈øt rectified Spirit of Wine, clo≈øe up the gla≈ø≈øe Hermetically, and dige≈øt them in a very gentle heat till you perceive they are di≈ø≈øolved. Then you may make u≈øe of it.

div.head: An excellent ≈øweet Water.
div.p:
Take a quart of Orenge-flower water, as much Ro≈øe-water, adde thereto of Musk-mallow ≈øeeds gro≈ø≈øely brui≈øed four ounces, of B ‚Ä¢ njamin two ounces, of Storax an ounce, of Labdanum ≈øix drams, of Lavender flowers two pugills, of ≈øweet Marjoram
as much, of Calamus Aromaticus a dram, di≈øtill all the≈øe in a Gla≈ø≈øe Still in Balneo, the ve≈ø≈øels being very well clo≈øed that no vapour breath forth.

div.head: To purifie and give an excellent ≈ømell, and tast unto oil Olive that they that loath it may delight to eat it.
div.p: Take of a good ≈øort of oil Olive though not of the be≈øt, put the ≈øame into a ve≈ø≈øell of earth or copper, that hath a little hole in the bottome thereof, which you may ≈øtop with wax or a cork to open at your plea≈øure. In this ve≈ø≈øell for every quart of oil adde four quarts of fair water, and with a wood ‚Ä¢ n ≈øpatle or ≈øpoon, beat them well together for a quarter of an houres ≈øpace, and when you have ≈øo done, op ‚Ä¢ n the hole in the bottome, and let out the water, for the oil doth naturally fleet above, as being the lighter body‚ñ™ and a≈ø≈øoon as the water is pa≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ d away, ≈øtop the hole, and put in other cold water, and begin a new agitation as before, and worke in the like manner divers times as you did at the fir≈øt, till in the end the oil be well clean≈øed and clarified. If the la≈øt time you work it with Ro≈øe-water it will be ≈øo much the better then hang in the mid≈øt of the oil a cour≈øe bag full of Nutmegs ≈øliced, and Cloves brui≈øed, and the rinds of Orenges and Lemons cut ≈ømall, and ≈øet the ve≈ø≈øell in Balneo for two or three hou ‚Ä¢ es, and I ≈øuppo≈øe he that loaths oil will be ea≈øily by this meanes drawn to a liking of it.

div.head: Another way.
div.p: Set oil Olive in the ≈øunne in ≈øummer-time untill there ≈øettle good ≈øtore of foule, and gro≈ø≈øe Lees, from the which by declination poure out the clear oil, and keep it till the next winter, and after the ≈øame hath been congealed with ≈øome fro≈øty weather, the oil will be mo≈øt ≈øweet, and delectable to the ta≈øt.

div.head: To purifie Butter that it ≈øhall keep fre≈øh and ≈øweet a long time, and be mo≈øt wonderfull ≈øweet in ta≈øt.
div.p: Di≈ø≈øolve butter in a clean glazed or ≈øilver ve≈ø≈øell and in a pan or kettle of water with a ≈ølow, and gentle fire, then pour the ≈øame ≈øo di≈ø≈øolved into a ba≈øon that hath ≈øome faire water therein, and when it is cold, take away the curds, and the whay that remain in the bottome. And if you will be at the charge thereof, you may the ≈øecond time for it mu≈øt be twice di≈ø≈øolved) di≈ø≈øolve the Butter in Ro≈øe-water, working them well together: the Butter thus clarified will be as ≈øwe ‚Ä¢ t in ta≈øt as the marrow of any bea≈øt, by rea≈øon of the great impurity that is removed by this manner of handling the fift pa ‚Ä¢ t thereof being dro≈ø≈øe, which makes the Butter many times offen≈øive to the ≈øtomach.

div.p: When the Butter is taken out of the cherne and well worked from the ≈øer ‚Ä¢ us part thereof, mix with the ≈øaid Butter as much of the oil o ‚Ä¢ that vegetable which you like be≈øt, till the ≈øame be ≈øtrong enough in ta≈øt to your liking, then temper them well together.

div.p: You may mix the di≈øtilled oil of what vegetable you would have the Chee≈øe ta≈øt of, with the curd, before the whay be pre≈ø≈øed out; but be ≈øure you mix them very well that all places may ta≈øt alike of it; you may make it ta≈øt ≈øtronger, or weaker of it as you plea≈øe by putting in more or le≈ø≈øe of the oil.

div.head: To purifie and refine Sugar.
div.p: Make a ≈øtrong Lixiuium of Calx vive, whereing di≈ø≈øolve as much cour≈øe Sugar as the Livivium will beare, then put in the white of Egges (of 2 to every part of the Liquor) being beaten into an oil, ≈øtir them well together, and let them boyl a little, and there will ari≈øe a ≈øcum which mu≈øt be taken off as lo ‚Ä¢ g as any will ari≈øe, then poure all the Liquor through a great Wollen cloth bag, and ≈øo the feces will remain behinde in the bag, then boyl the Liquor again ≈øo long till ≈øome drops of it being put upon a cold plate will, when they be cold, be congealed as hard as ≈øalt. Then pour out the Liquor into pots, or moulds made for that purpo≈øe, having a hole in the narrower end thereof, which mu≈øt be ≈øtopped for one night after, and after that night be opened, and there will a moi≈øt ≈øub≈øtance drop forth which is called Molo≈ø≈øes, or Treakle, then with potters clay cover the ends of the pot, & as that clay ≈øinketh down by rea≈øon of the ≈øinking of the Sugar, fill them up with more clay, repeating the doing thereof till the Sugar ≈øhrink no more. Then take it out till it be hard, and dryed, then bind it up in papers.

div.head: To make a vegetabl ‚Ä¢ grow and become more glorious then any of its ≈øpecies.
div.p: Reduce any vagetable into its three fir≈øt principles, and then joyne them together again being well purified, and put the ≈øame into a rich earth, and you ≈øhall have it produce a vegetable far more glorious then any of its ≈øpecies.

div.head: To make a Plant grow in two or three houres.
div.p:
Take the a≈øhes of Mo≈ø≈øe, moi≈øten them with the juice of an old dunghill being fir≈øt pre≈ø≈øed forth, and ≈øtreined, then dry them a little, and moi≈øten them as before, do this four or five times, put this mixture being neither very dry, nor very moi≈øt, into ≈øome earthen, or metalline ve≈ø≈øell; and in it ≈øet the ≈øeeds of Lettice,
Pur≈ølain or Par≈øly (becau≈øe they will grow ≈øooner then other Plants) being fir≈øt in pregnated with the e≈ø≈øence of a vegetable of its own ≈øpecies, (the proce≈ø≈øe whereof you ≈øhall find Book 1. page 32, 33.) till they begin to ≈øprout forth, then I ≈øay, put them in the ≈øaid earth with that end upwards which ≈øprouts forth: Then put the ve≈ø≈øell into a gentle heat, and when it begins to dry, moi≈øten it with ≈øome of the ≈øaid joyce of dung.
Thou maie≈øt by this meanes have a Sallet grow while≈øt ≈øupper is making ready.

div.head: To make the Idea of any Plant appear in a gla≈ø≈øe, as if the very plant it ≈øelfe were there.
div.p: The proce≈ø≈øe of this thou mai≈øt ≈øee, pag. 32. and therefore I need not here again repeat it, only remember that if you put the flame of a candle to the bo ‚Ä¢ tome of the gla≈ø≈øe where the e≈ø≈øence is, by which it may be made hot, you wil ≈øee that thin ≈øub≈øtance which is like impalpable a≈øhes or ≈øalt ≈øend forth from the bottome of the gla≈ø≈øe the manife≈øt forme of a vegetable, vegetating and growing by little, and little, and putting on ≈øo fully the forme of ≈øtalkes, leaves, and flowers in ≈øuch perfect, and naturall wi≈øe in apparent ≈øhew, that any one would believe verily the ≈øame to be naturally corporall, when as in truth it is the ≈øpirituall Idea, endued with a ≈øpirituall e≈ø≈øence; which ≈øerveth for no other purpo≈øe, but to be matched with its fitting earth, that ≈øo it may take unto it ≈øelf a more ≈øolid body. This ≈øhadowed figure a≈ø≈øoon as the ve≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ll is taken from the fire, returnes to its a≈øhes again and vani≈øheth away, becoming a Chaos, and confu≈øed matter.

div.head: To make Firre-trees appear in Turpentine.
div.p:
Take as much Turpentine as you plea≈øe, put it into a Retort, di≈øtill it by degrees, when all is di≈øtilled off‚ñ™ keep the Retort ≈øtill in a rea≈øonable heat, that what humidity is ≈øtill remaining may be evaporated, and it become dry: Then take this off from the fire and hold your hand to the bottome of the Retort, and the Turpentine that is dried (which is called Colophonia) will
crack a≈øunder in ≈øeverall places, and in tho≈øe crackes or chaps you ≈øhall ≈øee the perfect effigies or Firre-trees which will there continue many moneths.

div.head: To make Harts-horn ≈øeemingly to grow in a gla≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take Harts-horn broken into ≈ømall pieces, and put them into a gla≈ø≈øe Retort to be di≈øtilled, and you ≈øhall ≈øee the gla≈ø≈øe to be ≈øeemingly full of horns, which will continue there ≈øo long till the volatile ≈øalt come over.

div.head: To make golden mountains as it were appeare in a gla≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take of Adders egges half a pound, put them into a gla≈ø≈øe Retort, di≈øtill them by degrees, when all is dry, you ≈øhall ≈øee the feces at the bottome turgid, and puffed up, and ≈øeem to be as it were golden mountains, being very glorious to behold.

div.head: To make the repre≈øentation of the whole World in a Cla≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take of the pure≈øt ≈øalt Nitre as much as you plea≈øe, of Tin half ≈øo much, mix them together, and calcine them Hermetically, then put them into a Retort, to which ann ‚Ä¢ x a gla≈ø≈øe receiver, and l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e them well together, let there be leaves of gold put into the bottome thereof, then put fire to the R ‚Ä¢ tort, untill vapours ari≈øe that will cleave to the gold: a ‚Ä¢ gment the fire till no more fumes a≈øcend, then take away the Receiver, and clo≈øe it Hermetically, and make a lamp fire under it, and you will ≈øee pre≈øented in it the Sun, Moone, Stars, Fountains Flowers, Trees, fruits, and indeed even all things, which is a glorious ≈øight to behold.

div.head: To make four Elements appear in a gla≈ø≈øe.
div.p:
Take of the ≈øubtle powder of Jet an ounce and half, of the oil of Tartar made per Deliquium (in which there is not one drop of water be≈øides what the Tartar it ≈øelf contracted) two ounces, which you mu≈øt colour with a light green with Vardegrea≈øe,
of the pure≈øt Spirit of Wine ringed with a light blew with Indico, 2. ounces of the be≈øt rectified Spirit of Turpentine coloured with a light red with Madder 2. ounces. Put all the≈øe into a gla≈ø≈øe, and ≈øhake them together, and you ≈øhall ≈øee the Jet which is heavy and black fall to the bottome and repre≈øent the earth; next, the oil of Tartar made green repre≈øenting the element of water, falls: upon that ≈øwims the blew ≈øpirit of Wine which will not mix with the oil of Tartar; and repre≈øents the element of air: uppermo≈øt will ≈øwim the ≈øubtle red oil of Turpentine which repre≈øents the element of fire.

It is ≈øtrange to ≈øee how after ≈øhaking all the≈øe together they will be di≈øtinctly ≈øeparated the one from the other. If it be well done, as it is ea≈øie enough to do, it is a mo≈øt glorious ‚Ä¢ ight.

div.head: To make a perpetuall motion in a gla≈ø≈øe.
div.p: Take ≈øeven ounces of Quick≈øilver, as much Tin, grinde them well together with fourteen ounces of Sublimate di≈ø≈øolved in a cellar upon a Marble the ≈øpace of foure dayes, and it will become like oil Olive, which di≈øtill in ≈øand, and there will ≈øublime a dry ≈øub≈øtance, then put the water which di≈øtills off back upon the earth, in the bottome of the Still, and di≈ø≈øolve what you can, filter it, and di≈øtill it again, and thi ‚Ä¢ do foure or five times, and then that earth will be ≈øo ≈øubtle, that being put into a viall the ≈øubtle atomes ‚Ä¢ hereof will move up and down for ever.
Note that the viall or gla≈ø≈øe mu≈øt be clo≈øe ≈øtopt, and kept in a dry place.

div.head: To make a Luminous Water that ≈øhall give light by night.
div.p: Take the tailes of Glo-wormes, put them into a gla≈ø≈øe Still, and di≈øtill them in Balneo, pour the ≈øaid water upon more fre≈øh tailes of Glo-wormes, do this four or five times, and thou ≈øhalt have a mo≈øt Luminous Water, by which thou mai≈øt ≈øee to read in the dark night.

Some ≈øay this Water may be made of the Skins of Herring; and for ought I know it may be probable enough: for I have heard that a ≈øhole of Herrings coming by a ≈øhip in the night have given a great light to all the ≈øhip.
It were worth the while to know the true rea≈øon why Glowormes, and Herring and ≈øome other ≈øuch like things ≈øhould be luminous in the night.

div.head: To make a vapour in a chamber that he that enters into it with a candle ≈øhall thinke the room to be on fire.
div.p: Di≈ø≈øolve Camphire in rectified Aqua vitae, and evaporate them in a very clo≈øe chamber where no air can get in, and he that fir≈øt enters the chamber with a lighted candle will be much a≈øtoni≈øhed, for the chamber will ≈øeem to be full of fire, very ≈øubtle, but it will be of little continuance.
You mu≈øt note that it is the combu≈øtible vapour, with which the chamber is filled, that takes flame from the candle.

Divers ≈øuch like experiments as this may be done, by putting ≈øuch a combu≈øtible vapour into a box, or cubboard or ≈øuch like, which will‚ñ™ a≈ø≈øoon as any one ≈øhall open them having a candle in his hand, take fire, and burne.

div.head: To make a powder that by ≈øpitting upon ≈øhall be inflamed.
div.p: Take a Load-≈øtone, powder it, and put it into a ≈øtrong calcining pot, cover it all over with a powder made of Calx vive, and Colophonia, of each a like quantity, put al≈øo ≈øome of this powder under it: when the pot is full cover it, and lute the clo≈øures with potters earth, put them into a furnace, and there let them boyl, then take them out and put them into another pot, and ≈øet them in the furnace again, and this doe till they become a very white and dry Calx. Take of this Calx one part, of ≈øalt Nitre being very well purified foure parts, and as much Camphire, Sulphur vivum, the oil of Turpentine, and Tartar, grind all the≈øe to a ≈øubtle powder and ≈øear≈øe them, and put them into a gla≈ø≈øe ve≈ø≈øell, then put as much Spirit of wine well rectified, as will cover them two fingers breadth, then clo≈øe them up and ≈øet the ve≈ø≈øell in hor≈øedung three moneths, and in that time they will all become an uniforme pa≈øte: evaporate all the humidity, untill the whole ma≈ø≈øe become a very dry ≈øtone: then take it out and powder it, and keep it very dry.
If you take a little of this powder and ≈øpit upon it, or pour ≈øome water upon it, it will take fire pre≈øently, ≈øo that thou mai≈øt light a match, or any ≈øuch thing by it.

div.head: To fortifie a Load-≈øtone that it ≈øhall be able to draw a naile out of a piece of wood.
div.p: Take a Load-≈øtone, and heat it very hot in coales, but ≈øo that it be not fired, then pre≈øently quench it in the Oil of Crocus Martis made of the be≈øt ≈øteele, that it may imbibe as much as it can.

Thou ≈øhalt by this means make the Load-≈øtone ≈øo very ≈øtrong and powerfull, that thou mai≈øt pull out nailes out of a piece of wood with it, and do ≈øuch wonderfull things with it that the common Load-≈øtone can never do.
Now the rea≈øon of this (as Paracel≈øus ≈øaith) is becau≈øe the Spirit of Iron is the life of the Load-≈øtone, and this may be extracted from, or increa≈øed in the Load-≈øtone.

div.head: To make Quick-≈øilver Malleable in ≈øeven houres.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt lead, and melt it, and poure it into a hole, and when it is almo≈øt congealed make a hole in it, and pre≈øently fill up the hole with quick-≈øilver, and it will pre≈øently be congelated into a friable ≈øub≈øtance, then beat it into a powder, and put it again into a hole of fre≈øh melted lead as before, do this 3, or 4, times, then boyl it being all in a piece in Lin≈øeed oil the ≈øpace of ≈øix houres; then take it out and it will become malleable.
Note that after this, it may by being melted over the fire be reduced into quick-≈øilver again.
A thin plate of the ≈øaid Mercury laid upon an inveterate Ulter takes away the malignity of it in a great mea≈øure, and renders it more curable then before.
A plate of the ≈øaid Mercury laid upon tumours would be a great deal better repercu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ive then plates of lead, which Chirurgeons u≈øe in ≈øuch ca≈øes.
The powder of the friable ≈øub≈øtance of Mercury before it be boyled in the oil is very good to be ≈øtrewed upon old ulcers, for it doth much correct the virulency of them.

div.head: To reduce Gla≈ø≈øe into its fir≈øt principles, viz. ≈øand and ≈øalt.
div.p: Take bits or powder of Gla≈ø≈øe as much as you plea≈øe, as much of the Salt which Gla≈ø≈øemen u≈øe in the making of Gla≈ø≈øes: melt the≈øe together in a ≈øtrong fire: Then di≈ø≈øolve all the melted ma≈ø≈øe in warme water, then pour off the water and you ≈øhall ≈øee no Gla≈ø≈øe, but only ≈øand in the bottome, which ≈øand was that which was in the gla≈ø≈øe before.
This con ‚Ä¢ utes the vulgar opinion, viz. that the fu≈øion of Gla≈ø≈øe is the la≈øt fu≈øion, and beyond all reduction.

div.head: To write or engrave upon an egge, or peble, with wax or grea≈øe.
div.p: Make what letters or figures you plea≈øe with wax, or grea≈øe, upon an egge or peble, put them into the ≈øtronge≈øt Spirit of Vinegar, and there let them lye 2. or 3. dayes, and you ≈øhall ≈øee every place about the letters or figures eaten or con≈øumed away with the ≈øaid Spirit, but the place where the wax or grea≈øe was, not at all touched: the rea≈øon whereof is becau≈øe that the Spirit would not operate upon the ≈øaid oleaginous matter.

div.head: To make artificiall Pearle, as glorious as any orientall.
div.p:
Di≈ø≈øolve mother of Pearle in Spirit of vinegar, then precipitate it with Oil of Sulphur per Campanam, (and not with Oil of Tartar, for that takes away the ≈øplendour of it) which addes a lu≈øtre to it: when it is thus precipitated, dry it, and mix it with whites of egges, and of this ma≈ø≈øe you may make Pearles of what
‚Ä¢ igne≈ø≈øe or fa≈øhion you plea≈øe: before they be dryed you may make holes through them, and when they be dryed they will not at all, or very hardly be di≈øcerned from true, and naturall Pearles.

div.head: To make a Minerall perfume.
div.p:
Di≈ø≈øolve Antomony, or Sulphur in the Liquor or Oil of flints or pebles, or Cry≈øtalls, or ≈øand, coagulate the ≈øolution
into a red ma≈ø≈øe, pour thereon the Spirit of urine, and dige≈øt them till the Spirit be tinged, then poure it off, and pour more on, till all the tincture be extracted, put all the tinctures together, and evaporate the Spirit of urine in Balneo, and there will remain a bloud red Liquor at the bottome, upon which pour Spirit of wine, & you ≈øhal extract a purer tincture, which ≈ømeleth like garlick, dige≈øt it three or four weeks, and it will ≈ømell like balme, dige≈øt it longer, and it will ≈ømell like Muske or Amber-gry≈øe.
Be≈øides the ≈ømell that it hath, it is an excellent Sudorifick, and cures all di≈øea≈øes that require ≈øweat, as the plague, putrid feavers, lues venerea, and ≈øuch like.

div.head: The Oil or Liquor of ≈øand, flints, pebles, or Cry≈øtalls, for the afore≈øaid preparation is thus made.
div.p: Take of the be≈øt ≈øalt of Tartar being very well, by two or three di≈ø≈øolutions, and coagulations, purified, and powdered in a hot mortar, one part, of flints, pebles, or cry≈øtals being powdered, or ≈ømall ≈øand well wa≈øhed, the fourth part, mingle them well together, put as much of this compo≈øition as will fill an egge≈øhell into a Crucible ≈øet in the earthen Furnace, (expre≈ø≈øed page 83.) and made red hot, and pre≈øently there will come over a thick, and white ≈øpirit, this doe till you have enough, then take out of the Crucible while≈øt it is glowing hot, & that which is in it is like tran≈øparent gla≈ø≈øe, which keep from the aire.
The Spirit may be rectified by ‚Ä¢ and in a gla≈ø≈øe Retort.

This Spirit is of excellent u≈øe in the gou ‚Ä¢ , ≈øtone, pti≈øick, and indeed in all ob≈øtructions, provoketh ‚Ä¢ weat, and urine, and clean≈øeth the ≈øtomack, and by con≈øequence effectuall in mo≈øt di≈øea≈øes.
It being applyed externally cleareth the skin, and makes it look very faire.

Take that which remaines at the bottome in the crucible, and beat it to powder, and lay it in a moi≈øt place, and ≈øo it di≈ø≈øolveth into a thick fat Oil: and this is that which is called the Oil of ≈øand, of flints, pebles, or cry≈øtalls.
This Oil is of wonderfull u≈øe in medicine, as al≈øo in the preparation of all ≈øorts of Mineralls.
This oil being taken inwdarly in ≈øome appropriated Liquor di≈ø≈øolves tartarous coagulations in the body, and ≈øo opens all ob≈øtructions.
It precipitates metals, and makes the calx thereof more weighty, then oil of Tartar doth.
It is of a golden nature: it extracts colours from all metals, is fixed in all fires, maketh fine Cry≈øtals, and Borax, and maturifieth imperfect metals into gold.
If you put it into water there will precipitate a mo≈øt fine white earth, of wch you may make as clear ve≈ø≈øels as are China-di≈øhes.

Note that all ≈øand, flints, and pebles, even the white≈øt, have in them a golden ≈øulphur, or tincture, and if a prepared lead be for a time dige≈øted in this oil it will ≈øeem as it were gilded, becau≈øe of the gold that will hang upon it, which may be wa≈øhed away in water. Gold al≈øo is found in ≈øand and flints, &c. and if you put Gold into this oil it will become more ponderous thereby.

div.head: To make Steele grow in a gla≈ø≈øe like a tree.
div.p: Di≈ø≈øolve Steele in a rectified Spirit of ≈øalt, ≈øo ≈øhall you have a green and ≈øweet ≈øolution, which ≈ømels like brim≈øtone, filter it, and ab≈øtract all the moi≈øture in ≈øand with a gentle heat, and there will di≈øtil over a Liquor as ≈øweet as rain-water (for Steele by rea≈øon of its dryne≈ø≈øe detaines the coro≈øivene≈ø≈øe of the Spirit of ≈øalt, which remaineth in the bottome like a bloud red ma≈ø≈øe, which is as hot on the tongue as fire, di≈ø≈øolve this red ma≈ø≈øe in oil of flints, or of ≈øand, and you ≈øhall ≈øee it grow up in two or three houres, like a tree with a ≈øtemm, and branches; prove this tree at the te≈øt, and it yeeldeth good gold, which this tree hath drawn from the afore≈øaid oil of ≈øand, or flints, which hath a golden ≈øulphur in it.

div.head: To melt any metall in ones hand without burning of the hand.
div.p: Take a little calcining pot in your hand, make in it a lane or cour≈øe of the powder of any metall, then upon it lay a lane of Sulphur, Salt-peter and Saw-du≈øt, of each a like quantity, mixed together, put a coal of fire to it, and forthwith the metall will be melted into a ma≈ø≈øe.

div.head: An ob≈øervation upon the beams of the Sun and heat of the fire, how they adde weight to Minerall, and Metalline bodies.
div.p: 1. Take any Minerall Liquor and ≈øet it in an open ve≈ø≈øell in the ≈øun for a good ≈øpace, and it will be augmented in quantity, and weight. But ≈øome will ≈øay that this proceedeth from the air: to the which I an≈øwer and demand, whether the air had not this impregnation from the ≈øun, and what the air hath in it ≈øelf that proceedeth not from the ≈øun and ≈øtars.

2. Put this liquor in a cold cellar, or in a moi≈øt air, and you ≈øhall find that it increa≈øeth not in weight, as it doth in the ≈øun, or in the fire (which hath in this re≈øpect ≈øome analogie with the ≈øun) I do not ≈øay but haply it might attract ≈øome little moi≈øture which is ≈øoon exhaled by any ≈ømall heat:

3. Di≈ø≈øolve any ≈øulphurous, and imperfect metall, as Iron, Copper, or Zinke, in Aqua fortis, or any other acid ≈øpirit, then ab≈øtract the Spirit from it, make it glowing hot, yet not too hot, that the Spirit may only vapour away, then weigh this metalline Calx, and ≈øet it in a crucible over the fire, but melt it not, only let it darkly glow, let it ≈øtand ≈øo 3, or 4, weeks, then take it off, and weigh it again, and you ≈øhall find it heavier then before.

4. Set any ≈øulphurous metall, as Iron, or Copper, with ≈øixteen or eighteen parts of Lead on a te≈øt made with a≈øhes of wood, or bones in a probatory furnace: fir≈øt weigh the te≈øt, copper and lead before you put them into the furnace, let the iron or copper fly away with the lead, yet not with too ≈øtrong a heat, then take the te≈øt out, and weigh it, and you ≈øhall finde it (though the metals are gone) when it is cold to be heavier then it was when it was put into the furnace with the metals. The que≈øtion is now whence this heavine≈ø≈øe of all the afore≈øaid Minerals and metals proceeded, if that the heat of the fun, and fire through the help of the Mineralls and metals be not fixed into a palpable Minerall, and Metalline body?

5. Set a te≈øt with lead, or copper in the ≈øun, and with a concave gla≈ø≈øe unite the beames of the ≈øun, and let them fall on the center of the metall, hold the concave gla≈ø≈øe in your hand, and let your te≈øt never be cold, and this will be as well done in the
≈øun, as in the fire. But this concave mu≈øt be two foot in Diameter, and not too hollow or deep, but about the eighteenth or twentieth part of the circle, that it may the better ca≈øt its beams forth, and it mu≈øt be very well poli≈øhed.
6. Calcine Antimony with a burning gla≈ø≈øe, and you ≈øhall ≈øee it ≈ømoak, and fume, and be made dryer then before, yet weigh it and it will be heavier then before.

I ≈øhall take in, for the confirmation of all this, a relation of Sir Kenelme Digby concerning the precipitating of the ≈øun beams. I remember (≈øaith he) a rare experiment that a Noble man of much ≈øincerity, and a ≈øingular friend of mine, told me he had ≈øeen, wch. was, that by means of gla≈ø≈øes made in a very particular manner, and artificially placed one by another, he had ≈øeen the ≈øun beames gathered together, and precipitated down into a browni≈øh, or purpli≈øh red powder. There (≈øaith he) could be no fallacy in this operation. For nothing what≈øoever, was in the gla≈ø≈øe, when they were placed, and di≈øpo≈øed for this intent; and it mu≈øt be in the hot time of the yeare, el≈øe the effect would not follow. And of this magi≈øtery he could gather ≈øome dayes neer 2. ounces in a day, and it was of a ≈øtrong volatile vertue, and would impre≈ø≈øe it ≈øpirituall quality into gold it ≈øelfe (the heavie≈øt and mo≈øt fixed body we conver≈øe withall) in a very ≈øhort time.
I leave it now to the reader to judge whether the beames of the ≈øun, and heat of the fire adde weight to Minerals, and Metals.

div.head: To extract a white Milkie ≈øub≈øtance from the raies of the Moone.
div.p: Take a concave gla≈ø≈øe and hold it again≈øt the Moon when ≈øhe is at the full in a cleare evening, and let the raies thereof being united fall upon a ≈øponge, and the ≈øponge will be full of a cold Milkie ≈øub≈øtance, which you may pre≈ø≈øe out with your hand, and gather more. De-La-Bro≈ø≈øe is of opinion that this ≈øub≈øtance is of the ≈øub≈øtance of the Moon: but I cannot a≈ø≈øent to him in that, only this I ≈øay, if this experiment were well pro≈øecuted, it might produce for ought I know, ≈øuch a di≈øcovery which might be the key to no ≈ømall ≈øecrets.

div.head: To conden≈øe the aire in the heat of ≈ømmer and in the heat of the day, into water.
div.p: Fill an earthen ve≈ø≈øell unglazed, made pointed downward, and fill it with ≈ønow-water (which mu≈øt be kept all the year) in which is di≈ø≈øolved as much Nitre as the water would di≈ø≈øolve: Let the ve≈ø≈øell be clo≈øe ≈øtopt. Hold this ve≈ø≈øell again≈øt the ≈øun and the air will be ≈øo conden≈øed by the coldne≈ø≈øe of the ve≈ø≈øell that it will drop down by the ≈øides thereof.

div.head: How two ≈øorts of volatile ≈øalts will be fixed by joyning them together.
div.p: Take a ≈øtrong Lixivium made of un≈ølaked lime, and evaporate it, and whereas you would expect to find a ≈øalt at the bottome there is none, for all the ≈øalt in the Lixivium is vapored away, and the more the Liquor is evaporated the weaker the Lixivium becomes, which is contrary to other Lixiviums: Al≈øo if you take Spirit of vinegar, and evaporate it, you ≈øhall finde no ≈øalt at the bottome. Now if you take the clear Lixivium of Lime, and Spirit of vinegar, of each a like quantity, and mix them together, and evaporate the humidity thereof, you ≈øhall find a good quantity of ≈øalt at the bottome, which ta≈øts partly hot, and partly acid.

This ≈øalt being ≈øet in a cold cellar on a marble ≈øtone, and di≈ø≈øolved into an oil, is as good as any Lac virginis to clear, and ≈ømooth the face, and dry up any hot pu≈øtles in the skin, as al≈øo again≈øt the Itch, and old ulcers to dry them up.

div.head: To make an unguent that a few graines thereof being applied outwardly will cau≈øe vomiting or loo≈øne≈ø≈øe as you plea≈øe.
div.p: Take Lapis infernalis, mix therewith of di≈øtilled oil of Tobacco as much as will make an ointment: Keep it in a dry place.
If you would provoke vomiting, anoint the pit of the ≈øtomach with five or ≈øix graines thereof, and the party will pre≈øently vomit, and as much as with taking of a vomit.
If you would provoke to loo≈øne≈ø≈øe anoint about the navell therewith, and the patient will pre≈øently fall into a loo≈øne≈ø≈øe.
Note that you mu≈øt give the patient ≈øome warme ≈øuppings all the time this medicine is working.
Note al≈øo, and that e≈øpecially, that you let not the ointment lye ≈øo long as to cauterize the part to which it is applyed.

div.head: To make a medicine that halfe a graine thereof being taken every morning will keep the body ≈øoluble.
div.p: Take of the di≈øtilled oil of Tobacco, of which let the e≈ø≈øentiall ≈øalt of Tobacco imbibe as much as it can. Then with this compo≈øition make ≈øome Lozenges by adding ≈øuch things as are fitting for ≈øuch a forme of medicine: Note that you put but ≈øuch a quantity of this oily ≈øalt as half a grain only may be in one Lozenge.
One of the≈øe Lozenges being taken every morning, or every other morning, keepeth the body ≈øoluble, and is good for them as are apt to be very co≈øtive in their bodies.
Note that you may put ≈øome aromaticall ingredient into the Lozenges that may qualifie the offen≈øive odour of the oil, if there ≈øhall be any.

div.head: To make a Cordiall, ≈øtomachicall, and purgative tincture.
div.p: Make a tincture of Hiera picra with Spirit of wine well rectified, and aromatized with Cinnamon or Cloves.

Two or three ≈øpoonfulls of this tincture being taken in a morning twice in a week wonderfully helps tho≈øe that have weak and foul ≈øtomacks, it openeth ob≈øtructions, and purgeth vi≈øco≈øities of the ≈øtomach and bowells, cureth all inveterate head-ach killeth wormes, and indeed leaveth no impurities in the body, and is very cordiall: for it exceedingly helps them that are troubled with faintings. There is nothing offen≈øive in this medicine but the bitterne≈ø≈øe thereof, which the other extraordinary vertues will more then ballance.

div.head: Another.
div.p: Di≈ø≈øolve Scammony in Spirit of Wine, evaporate the one moity, then precipitate it by putting Ro≈øe-water to it: and it will become mo≈øt white, for the black and fetid matter will lye on the top of the precipitated matter which you mu≈øt wa≈øh away with Ro≈øe-water. Then take that white gum being very well wa≈øhed, and dry it (if you plea≈øe you may powder it and ≈øo u≈øe it, for indeed it hath neither ≈ømell nor ta≈øt, and purgeth without any offence, and may be given to children or to any that di≈øta≈øt phy≈øick, in their milk or broth without any di≈øcerning of it, and indeed it doth purge without any manner of gripings. I was wont to make it up into pills with oil of Cinamon or Cloves which gave it a gallant ≈ømel, and of which I gave a ≈øcruple which wrought moderately and without any manner of gripings) then di≈ø≈øolve it again in Spirit of Wine being aromatized with what ≈øpices you plea≈øe, and this keep.

This tincture is ≈øo plea≈øant, ≈øo gentle, ≈øo noble a purgative that there is ≈øcarce the like in the world, for it purgeth without any offence, is taken without any nau≈øeating, and purgeth all manner of humours, e≈øpecially choler, and melancholy, and is very Cordiall.
It may be given to tho≈øe that abhor any medicine, as to children or tho≈øe that are of a nau≈øeous ≈øtomach.
The do≈øe is from half a ≈øpoonfull to two or three.
Note it mu≈øt be taken of it ≈øelf, for if it be put into any other Liquor, the Scammony will precipitate and fall to the bottome.
After this manner you may prepare Jollap by extracting the gum therefore, and then di≈ø≈øolving it in Spirit of wine.
By this meanes Jollap would not be ≈øo offen≈øive to the ≈øtomach, as u≈øually it is, for it is the gum that is purgative, and the earthline≈ø≈øe that is ≈øo nau≈øeous.
Jollap being thus prepared is a mo≈øt excellent medicine again≈øt all hydropick di≈øea≈øes, for it purgeth water away without any nau≈øeou≈øne≈ø≈øe or griping at all.

div.head: To reduce di≈øtilled Turpentine into its body againe.
div.p: Take the oil of Turpentine, and the Colophonia thereof (which is that ≈øub≈øtance which remaines in the bottome after di≈øtillation) which you mu≈øt beat to powder. Mix the≈øe together and dige≈øt them, and you ≈øhall have a Turpentine of the ≈øame con≈øi≈øtency as before, but of a fiery ≈øubtle nature.
Pills made of this Turpentine, are of excellent u≈øe in ob≈øtructions of the brea≈øt, kidneyes and the like.

div.head: To make the di≈øtilled Oil out of any hearb, ≈øeed or flower in an in≈øtant without any furnace.
div.p: You mu≈øt have a long pipe made of tin, which mu≈øt have a bowle in the middle with a hole in it as big as you can put your finger into it: by which you mu≈øt put your matter that you would have the Oil of. Set this matter on fire with a candle or coal of fire, then put one end of the pipe into a ba≈øon of fair water, and blow at the other end, and the ≈ømoak will come into the water, and there will an oil ≈øwim upon the water: which you may ≈øeparate with a tunnell.

div.head: To make water, and the tincture of any vegetable at the ≈øame time, which is an excellent way to draw out the vertue thereof.
div.p: This mu≈øt be performed by the≈øe following ve≈ø≈øels.
A, Signifies the Furnace it ≈øelfe.
B, The Retort which stands in water or ≈øand, wherein the matter to be di≈øtilled is put, instead whereof, if you plea≈øe you may put a gourd gla≈ø≈øe with a head to it.
C, The pipe.
D, Another ve≈ø≈øell where is more fre≈øh matter out of which the tincture is to be drawne, and which ≈øtands upon a≈øhes with a fire under it.
E, The furnace with a pan of a≈øhes.
F, The receiver.
