div.head: A way to ≈øeparate fre≈øh water from ≈øalt without a furnace or much trouble.
div.p:
Take a Caldron with a great and high cover having a beake or no≈øe, ≈øet it upon a trefoot, and under it put fire: let this be filled with ≈øalt water, and there will pre≈øently di≈øtill
off a good quantity of fre≈øh water into a receiver, which mu≈øt be joyned to the no≈øe of the afore≈øaid cover.

This is of good u≈øe for Sea-men that want fre≈øh water, for by this meanes they may di≈øtill a good quantity in 24. houres, e≈øpecially if they have any con≈øiderable number of the afore≈øaid ve≈ø≈øels, a figure whereof is this which followes.

div.head: A way to purge and purifie troubled and muddie waters.
div.p: Fill a great pot with pudled water, put a ≈øoft and gentle fire under it, lay ≈øome ≈øticks acro≈ø≈øe on the pot brims, and upon the ≈øticks lay clean wool or a ≈øpunge well wa≈øhed: Now the wool drinkes up the vapours that a≈øcend, which then you mu≈øt wring out, and lay on the wool again, and this you may doe till you have as much clean water as you de≈øire. The manner of this di≈øtillation is de≈øcribed thus.
A, Signifies the pot.
B, The fire.
C, The ≈øtickes.
D, The wooll.
This is of u≈øe for them that can come at no other waters but what are troubled, as it falls out many times in ≈øome places.

div.head: Another way to purifie any thicke, muddie or feculent Liquor.
div.p: This is performed by ≈øhreds of any white woollen cloth in ve≈ø≈øells as you ≈øee hereafter expre≈ø≈øed.
A, Signifies the ve≈ø≈øels.
B, The ≈øhreds.
Note that the ≈øhreds mu≈øt be fir≈øt wet in fair water, and the feculent matter be put into the uppermo≈øt ve≈ø≈øell.
Note al≈øo whereas here be two receivers, that in many ca≈øes one may be ≈øufficient.

This way ≈øerves for the purifying of decoctions, juices, or di≈ø≈øolutions of ≈øalts from their feculency, for that which is di≈øtilled by the ≈øhreds is as clear as Cry≈øtall, when what remains is very feculent.

div.head: To keep fire in a gla≈ø≈øe, that while≈øt the gla≈ø≈øe is ≈øhut will not burne, but a≈øsoone as it is opened will be inflamed.
div.p: Fir≈øt extract the burning ≈øpirit of the ≈øalt of tin in a gla≈ø≈øe Retort well coated; when the Retort is cold, take it out and break it, and a≈ø≈øoone as the matter in it, which remains in the bottome thereof after di≈øtillation, comes into the air, it will pre≈øently be inflamed. Put this matter into a gla≈ø≈øe viall, and keep it clo≈øe ≈øtopt.
This fire will keep many thou≈øand yeares and not burne unle≈ø≈øe the gla≈ø≈øe be opened: but at what time ≈øoever that is opened it will burne.

It is conceived that ≈øuch a kind of fire as this was found in vaults when they were opened, which many conceived to be a perpetuall burning Lamp, when as indeed it was inflamed at the opening the vault, and the letting in air thereby which before it lacked, and therefore could not burn. For it is to be conceived that there is no fire burnes longer then its matter endures, and there is no combu≈øtible matter can endure for ever.
There may be many u≈øes of ≈øuch a fire as this, for any man may carry it about him, and let it burn on a ≈øuddain when he hath any occa≈øion for fire.

div.head: A Lamp Furnace is made thus.
div.p: A, Signifies the Candle≈øtick, which mu≈øt be hollow, and full of water.
B, The top of the candle≈øtick which mu≈øt he wide to containe good ≈øtore of water for to fill up the Candle≈øtick as the candle ri≈øeth up.
C, The candle, which mu≈øt be as long as the Candle≈øtick.

D, The ve≈ø≈øell that contains either wat ‚Ä¢ r, ≈øand, or a≈øhes for any ve≈ø≈øell to
be ≈øet into; al≈øo to containe any matter it ≈øelfe that is to be di≈øtilled, or dige≈øted.
E, A gla≈ø≈øe ve≈ø≈øell ≈øtanding in dige≈øtion.
F, A narrow mouthed ≈øtopple to be put into the candle≈øtick to keep the candle upright, and that mu≈øt be made of tin, with holes in it.
G, The cover for the ve≈ø≈øell D, which is to be put upon it when any thing is decocted, or kept warme in it.
H, A Still head to put upon the ve≈ø≈øell D, when you would di≈øtill any thing in it.
Note that if you make all the≈øe ve≈ø≈øells large you may do many con≈øiderable things without much labour, or trouble.

In the ve≈ø≈øell D, if it be large, you may ≈øtew meat, which if you put in at night and cover it clo≈øe, you may have it ready for your breakfa≈øt in the morning, and ≈øo according to the time you put it in you may have it for dinner or ≈øupper. Al≈øo you may keep any thing warme in the night, and at all times, and divers ≈øuch u≈øes as the≈øe it may be u≈øed for.
Note that the candle will ≈øtill ri≈øe up till it be quite burned out, and an ordinary candle will la≈øt twice as long this way as it will out of the water.

If you would have one candle la≈øt a long time as twelve or twenty hours, you mu≈øt either make your candle≈øtick very long that it may containe a long candle, or make your candle big and the wiek ≈ømall, or make your candle of ≈øuch matter as will not pre≈øently be con≈øumed.
Note al≈øo that if you would have a great heat, your candle mu≈øt be great, and al≈øo the wiek thereof great; but if gentle, let your candle be ≈ømall.

div.head: Another Lamp furnace.
div.p: There is another ≈øort of Lamp furnaces with three candles after this manner.

The u≈øe of this is when you would have a con≈øtant fire that ≈øhould give a ≈øtronger heat then one candle in the former furnace. And the truth is, that if your candles be big (as you may make them as big as you will) you may have as ≈øtrong a heat this way as by a≈øhes in an ordinary furnace.

div.head: To make a Candle that ≈øhall la≈øt long.
div.p: Take un≈ølaked lime, powder it and mix it with your tallow, and ≈øo make your candle of that, or el≈øe you may make candles of Ca≈øtle-≈øope which will ≈øerve for ≈øuch u≈øes as the≈øe, viz. to burne in ≈øuch a Lampe furnace.
Note that it is the ≈øalt that is in the lime, and ≈øope that pre≈øerves the tallow from burning out ≈øo fa≈øt as otherwi≈øe it would.

div.head: To make a lasting and durable Oil.
div.p: Take un≈ølaked lime, Bay-≈øalt, oil Olive of each a like quantity, mix them well together, and di≈øtill them in ≈øand, cohobate the oil upon the ≈øame quantity of fre≈øh lime, and ≈øalt: and this do foure or five times. By this means will the oil be clear and impregnated with what ≈øalt was volatile in the lime, and ≈øalt.
Now that ≈øaline impregnation is that which gives a durablene≈ø≈øe to the oil.

Note that this oil while≈øt it is di≈øtilling is of a mo≈øt fragrant ≈ømell: I have ≈øome of it which I di≈øtilled ≈øeven times, and it is as pure, ≈øubtle and odori≈øerous as many common di≈øtilled oiles of vegetables.
This oil be≈øides the durablene≈ø≈øe of it is al≈øo good again≈øt any inveterate ach in the limbs.
A Lampe made with this oil will continue burning ≈øix times as long as a Lamp made of other oil, as al≈øo it burnes very ≈øweet.
There mu≈øt be a great deal of care u≈øed in making of it, or el≈øe you will quickly break your gla≈ø≈øes: al≈øo you mu≈øt take very ≈øtrong lime, ≈øuch as the dyers u≈øe, and call cauke.

div.head: Philo≈øophicall Bellowes.
div.p: There be here ≈øet downe three figures of the≈øe kindes of in≈øtruments, which belong to ≈øeverall u≈øes.
A, Signifies that which blowes a fire for the melting of any metall or ≈øuch like operation, and it blowes mo≈øt forcibly with a terrible noi≈øe.
B, That which blowes a Candle to make the flame thereof very ≈øtrong for the melting of gla≈ø≈øes, and nipping them up.
C, That which any one may hold in his hand to blow the fire ≈øtrongly upon any occa≈øion.

Now the manner of the u≈øing them in this: you mu≈øt fir≈øt heat them very hot, then put the no≈øes thereof (which mu≈øt have a very ≈ømall hole in them, no bigger then that a pins head may go in) into a ve≈ø≈øell of cold water, and they will pre≈øently ≈øuck in the water, of which then being full turne the no≈øes thereof towards the candle or fire wch you would have blown.
As for the figure C, it mu≈øt have a mouth drawne up round and hanging out an inch from the face, which mouth (the whole compa≈ø≈øe of the face being heated fir≈øt) you mu≈øt dip in cold water, and it will ≈øuck in water as the no≈øes of the former did. This then you mu≈øt hold-clo≈øe to the fire that it may be heated, and it will blow exceedingly, as otherwi≈øe it will not, viz. if it be cold.
If you put ≈øweet water into ≈øuch a ve≈ø≈øell you may perfume a chamber exceedingly, for a little quantity thereof will be a long time breathing forth.
Note that the≈øe kindes of ve≈ø≈øels mu≈øt be made of copper, and be exceeding well clo≈øed, that they may have no vent but by their no≈øes.

div.head: An excellent invention to make a fire.
div.p: Take three parts of the be≈øt New-ca≈øtle coales beaten ≈ømall, one part of loame, mix the≈øe well together into a ma≈ø≈øe with water, make thereof balls, which you mu≈øt dry very well.

This fire is durable, ≈øweet, not offen≈øive by rea≈øon of the ≈ømoake or cinder as other coale fires are, beautifull in ≈øhape, and is not ≈øo co≈øtly as other fire, burnes as well in a chamber even as Char-coal.
This fire may either ≈øerve for ≈øuch di≈øtillations as require a ≈øtrong, and la≈øting heat, or for ordinary u≈øes either in the Kitchen, or chambers.

div.head: A new invention for Bathes.
div.p: Seeing by bathing and ≈øweating mo≈øt di≈øea≈øes are cured, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as proceed from wind, hot and di≈øtempered humours or cold and congealed humours; becau≈øe all the≈øe are rarified, and evaporated by tran≈øpiration in ≈øweating, or bathing, I thought it a thing much conducing to mans health to ≈øet downe ≈øuch a way of bathing and ≈øweating that might be very effectuall, and appropriated to any particular di≈øea≈øe or di≈øtemper.
I ≈øhall therefore here commend to you a way of bathing by di≈øtillation, the manner of which you may ≈øee by the≈øe en≈øuing ve≈ø≈øels.

A, Signifies a hot ≈øtill with two pipes going into two wooden ve≈ø≈øels; In this Still you may put either hearbs, ≈øpices, with water, or with Spirits, and di≈øtill them, by which meanes they that are in the ve≈ø≈øels will pre≈øently be forced into a ≈øweat by vertue of the ≈øubtlety of the vapours. And this indeed is as good and effectuall a way for ≈øweating as any can be invented: You may by this meanes appropriate your ingredients to the nature of the di≈øea≈øes.

B, A ve≈øsell wherein a man ≈øits in the bath. Now this ve≈ø≈øell hath in it a door for the ea≈øier going into it, which fa≈øhion is farre better, and more convenient, then to be open only at the top.
C, A long ve≈ø≈øell where a man that is weak, and not able to fit up, lies and is bathed.

Now you mu≈øt note that the≈øe vapours mo≈øt not be hotter then the patient can beer: al≈øo if the vapour come forth too hot upon the body of the patient, he may by putting a pipe upon the end of the pipe that comes into the ve≈ø≈øell, divert the hot vapour from his body, and ≈øo it will not offend him that way.

Note that the patient, a≈ø≈øoon as he begins to be faint, mu≈øt come forth or el≈øe he will ≈øuffer more prejudice, then good by his bathing; and al≈øo to prevent him from fainting let him take ≈øome Cordiall, or cold Beer, which will much revive him, and make him endure his bathing longer, as al≈øo make him ≈øweat the more.

A≈ø≈øoon as the patient comes forth, let him goe into a warm bed, and ≈øweat as he is able to beare it, and take ≈øome po≈ø≈øet drink, or broth or ≈øuch like warme ≈øuppings, as al≈øo ≈øome good Cordiall if he be very faint.
The patient may according as his ≈øtrength will bear, and his di≈øea≈øe require, bathe, more ≈øeldome or oftner.

div.head: An artificiall hot Bath, from the ≈øame principles as the naturall Bath is.
div.p:
Before I ≈øet down the proce≈ø≈øe of making an artificiall hot Bath, I ≈øhall premi≈øe ≈øome things concerning the true nature and originall of a hot Bath. Now the cleare≈øt and be≈øt account that I ever heard or read, of the cau≈øe of the heat in Bathes is that
which is given by Moun≈øier de Rochas, and that in a demon≈øtrative way; His words are the≈øe. As I was (≈øaith he) with ≈øome of my companions wandring in Savoy, I found in the valley of Luzerne betwixt the Alps a hot ≈øpring; I began to con≈øider the cau≈øe of this heat, and whereas the vulgar opinion is, that the heat of fountains is from mountains fired within, I ≈øaw rea≈øon to think the contrary, becau≈øe I ≈øaw ≈ønow upon a mountaine from whence this hot ≈øpring came, unmelted, which could not po≈ø≈øibly but have been di≈ø≈øolved by the hot fumes of the mountains, had they been fired. Whereupon being un≈øatisfied I with my companions and other labourers (whom I could very hardly per≈øwade to undertake ≈øuch a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe by rea≈øon they were affraid that fire would thereupon breake forth out of the ground and con≈øume us) got tools and ≈øet upon digging to find out the true cau≈øe of the heat of this fountain. After we had digged 15. dayes (having before perceived the water to be hotter and hotter by degrees as we came neerer to the ≈øource) we came to the originall of the heat, where was a great ebullition: In three houres more we digged beyond this place of ebullition and perceived the water to be cold, yet in the ≈øame continued ≈øtream with the other that was hot: upon this I began to wonder much at the rea≈øon of the≈øe things. Then I carryed to my lodging ≈øome of this hot water (which was both ≈øalti≈øh and acid) and evaporated it, and of forty ounces I had in the bottome five drams of ≈øalti≈øh matter, which I then yet farther purified, and extracted thence three drams of pure nitrous Hermetick ≈øalt; the other two ounces being a ≈ølimie ≈øulphurous ≈øub≈øtance. Yet with this I was not ≈øatisfied, but with my labourers went again to the place, and digged twelve days more, and then we came to a water which was in≈øipid as ordinary fountain Water, yet ≈øtill in a continued ≈øtream with the ≈øalti≈øh and hot water. At this I wondered much, whereupon I digged up ≈øome of the earth where the cold, and ≈øalti≈øh ≈øtream runned, & carried it home with me, and our of a hundred weight thereof, I extracted a good quantity of nitrous ≈øalt, which was almo≈øt fluxile. When I had extracted as much as I could, I laid the earth a≈øide, and in 24. houres it was all covered over with ≈øalt, which I extracted, and out of a hundred weight of
this earth which I call virgin earth, I had four pound of this kind of ≈øalt which is contracted in the afore≈øaid 24. houres: and ≈øo it would doe con≈øtantly. Now this ≈øatisfied me concerning one doubt: for before I was un≈øatisfied how there could be a con≈øtant ≈øupply of that ≈øalt which made the water ≈øalti≈øh, ≈øeeing there was but a little di≈øtance betwixt the in≈øipid water and the hot water, and the con≈øtant ≈øtream of water wa≈øhed away the ≈øalt which was in that little ≈øpace: for I perceived that this kind of earth attracts this univer≈øall ≈øalt of the world partly from the aire in the cavities of the earth, and partly from the vapours that con≈øtantly pa≈ø≈øe through the earth. After this I tooke ≈øome of that earth where the ebullition was, and carried it home, and proved it, and I perceived it to be a ≈øulphur mine, into which the former acid ≈øalti≈øh water penetrating cau≈øed an ebullition, as doe ≈øalt of Tartar, and Spirit of Vitriall being mixed together, and al≈øo water poured on un≈ølaked lime. After this I began to que≈øtion how it was that this ≈øulphur mine was not con≈øumed, ≈øeeing ≈øo much matter pa≈ø≈øeth from it daily: but when I began to under≈øtand how all things in the earth did a≈ø≈øimilate to them≈øelves what≈øoever was of any kind of affinity to them, as Mines convert the tooles of miners into their owne ≈øub≈øtance in a little time, and ≈øuch like experiments of that nature, I was ≈øatisfied. And after all this I under≈øtood how this univer≈øall ≈øalt of the world was to be had, and I could at any time mix it with water, and pour that water upon ≈øulphur, and ≈øo make an artificiall hot bath as good as any naturall bath what≈øoever. Note that no ≈øalt in the world but this nitrous ≈øalt will do it, as I often tryed: And this ≈øalt is to be found in all hot bathes, and to be prepared artificially. Thus farre Moun≈øeur de Rochas. Something like unto this Helmont ≈øeems to hold forth, ≈øaying that there is a Primum ens ≈øalium, or ≈øemina ≈øalium, which are all ≈øeated in waters and vapours and give them an acidity, but as yet have no ≈øaline ta≈øt, untill they meet with ≈øuch principles, and be received into certain matrixes in the earth which may make them put forth this potentiall ≈øaltne≈ø≈øe into act: and according to this diver≈øity of places that this water or vapours, being impregnated with tho≈øe ≈øeeds of ≈øalt, goe
through, ari≈øeth the diver≈øity of ≈øalts, as Alum, ≈øea-≈øalt, Nitre, &c. Then upon this account the earth through which the cold, acid, ≈øalti≈øh water above≈øaid run through, did ≈øpecificate that potentiall ≈øalt which was both in the water, and vapours, into a nitrous ≈øalt, (by which meanes was that kind of ≈øalt in that place) but whether this primum ens ≈øalium be ≈øo un≈øpecificated, or quid Hermaphroditicum as he a≈ø≈øerts, or no, it matters not much to my purpo≈øe; it ≈øufficeth if that earth through which that acid nitrous water runs, attracts and multiplies an acid nitrous ≈øalt, with which the water being impregnated, and running through a ≈øulphurous mine cau≈øeth an ebullition. All this being premi≈øed, I ≈øhall now endeavor to illu≈øtrate how nature may in this be imitated, as that an artificiall hot bath may be made by ≈øuch like principles, as the naturall hot bath con≈øi≈øts of, being artificially prepared.

Now the≈øe principles are the ≈øulphur mine, and the acid nitrous ≈øalt; the former requires no further preparation (as ≈øaith Moun≈øeur de Rochas,) if it be pure: the latter is to be prepared two manner of wayes: for either it is to be extracted, as ≈øaith the afore≈øaid author, out of the waters of the bath by evaporating them away, or by conden≈øing the nitrous aire (for indeed as many judicious philo≈øophers are of opinion, the air is wholly nitrous, as it appears by the conden≈øation of it in cold places into Nitre) which his virgins earth did doe, into a ≈øalt, which was acid, and almo≈øt fluxil. Now when I ≈øay that the nitrous ≈øalt is to be thus prepared, I do not ≈øay that this is the full preparation thereof, for indeed it is yet further to be prepared, and that is by giving it a greater acidity. I que≈øtion much whether or no the ≈øalt being prepared after the afore≈øaid wayes do retaine that acidity which is required for that ebullition I ≈øpake of, and which the nitrous acid water had before it came to the Mine of Sulphur. For indeed the afore≈øaid author when he affirmed that he could at any time make an artificiall hot bath, did not ≈øay he u≈øed the ≈øalt prepared only after the 2. former wayes, viz. by extracting it out of the waters of the bath, and making it with his virgin earth which did attract, and conden≈øe the nitrou≈øne≈ø≈øe of the aire, but withall by making it ≈øo acid that it might cau≈øe an ebullition when it
came to be joyned with a ≈øulphur Mine. Now then how to give this Nitre a ≈øufficient acidity is the great que≈øtion. For the better effecting of this we mu≈øt con≈øider whence that nitrous water (above mentioned) in the earth had the greate≈øt part of its acidity. As to that, it mu≈øt be remembred that the virgin earth through which the acid nitrous water did run, did conden≈øe the nitrous air or vapours into a nitrous ≈øalt, and withall it is to be con≈øidered that before this nitrous aire or vapour, before it be conden≈øed, even when it is neer unto conden≈øation is acid, and part of it before conden≈øation is mixed with the water, and ≈øo renders it acid. Now that waters have great part of their acidity from the acid vapours of acid Mineralls both Henricus ab Heers, and Jordan upon Minerall waters affirme: and that ≈øalts unbodied, are far more acid then when they have a≈ø≈øumed a body, is clearly manife≈øt in this, viz. that ≈øpirits of ≈øalts, which I call ≈øalts unbodied becau≈øe they have lo≈øt their body, are become very acid becau≈øe unbodied; if ≈øo in Spirits that have lo≈øt their bodies, why not after ≈øome proportion in tho≈øe that have not yet a≈ø≈øumed a body, as vapours of Nitre, or nitrous air being neer to congelation, and bodying, and impregnant with Spirits of Nitre?

Now I ≈øay that nitrous vapours, or nitrous air being a ≈øalt unbodied, are not ≈øo acid as Spirits of Nitre, becau≈øe they are more phlegmatick and crude, which flegme they lo≈øe by being congealed into a ≈øalt: yet for all this, they are far more acid then the body of ≈øalt: and this is that which Helmont under≈øtands, when he ≈øaith that the e≈øurine ≈øalt being incorporificated is far more active, in giving ta≈øt and odour then when it hath received its body by becoming a ≈øpecificated ≈øalt. Furthermore how Nitre ≈øhall become ≈øufficiently acid for the afore≈øaid operation is the great matter to be required into. We mu≈øt therefore con≈øider which way we may unbody Nitre (≈øeeing it is ≈øcar≈øe po≈ø≈øible to get it before it hath received its body) and that is done two wayes, either by forcing of it into a mo≈øt ≈øharp Spirit, which is too acid for our inten≈øion, or by dige≈øting the whole ≈øub≈øtance of Nitre into a Liquor moderately acid, which indeed ≈øerves for our purpo≈øe, and the proce≈ø≈øe is this.

Take the pure≈øt Nitre you can get, di≈ø≈øolve it in rain water
≈øo as that the water imbibe as much of it as it can. Then put this nitrous water into a common earthen ve≈ø≈øell unglazed, which you mu≈øt ≈øet in a cellar. You ≈øhall ≈øee this ve≈ø≈øell in a ≈øhort time to be white all over on the out≈øide as with a hoar fro≈øt, which whitene≈ø≈øe is partly the flowers of the Nitre being the pure≈øt part thereof penetrating the ve≈ø≈øell, and partly the nitrous aire conden≈øed into Nitre by the coldne≈ø≈øe of the ve≈ø≈øell, as al≈øo a≈ø≈øimilated to the Nitre that penetrated the ve≈ø≈øell. I ≈øaid by the coldne≈ø≈øe of the ve≈ø≈øel, becau≈øe ≈øuch is the coldne≈ø≈øe of an earthen ve≈ø≈øell wherein is Nitre, di≈ø≈øolved in water, that it will being ≈øet in ≈ønow by the fire ≈øide forthwith be freezed. This Nitre you mu≈øt ≈øtrike off with a feather, and when you have a ≈øufficient quantity thereof, as three or four pound, put this, or the nitrous ≈øalt extracted from bath-waters into a bolt head of gla≈ø≈øe, (a pound in each bolt head) that two parts of three be empty, nip it up, and ≈øet it in a≈øhes, and give it a rea≈øonable ≈øtrong fire, viz. that the upper part of the boul of the bolt head be as hot, as that you can but well ≈øuffer your hand upon it, and you ≈øhall ≈øee that the Nitre will be di≈ø≈øolved every day a little, and in 2. or 3. moneths time be wholly di≈ø≈øolved, and become acid, but not ≈øo acid as the Spirit thereof; then put it into a gla≈ø≈øe gourd with a head, and di≈øtill it off, and in the bottome you ≈øhall find an acid nitrous ≈øalt almo≈øt fluxil, not unlike the ≈øalt which Moun≈øeur de Rochas found in the evaporating of this water. Then pour the di≈øtilled Nitre water upoÃÑ the ≈øaid ≈øalt, & then it is for your u≈øe.

The u≈øe of the≈øe principles or ingredients is this, viz. make fountaine water ≈øufficiently acid with this nitrous Liquor, then pour it upon a ≈øufficient quantity of the be≈øt Sulphur Mine, or Sulphur vivum in a large wooden ve≈ø≈øell where the patient is to be bathed, and you will ≈øee the water pre≈øently heated ≈øo hot as the patient is able to beare.

The inward u≈øe of the≈øe bath-waters is by rea≈øon of the Nitre in them, to di≈ø≈øolve gro≈ø≈øe humours, open ob≈øtructions, clean≈øe the kidneys and bladder, and by rea≈øon of the ≈øulphur to dry, mollifie, di≈øcu≈ø≈øe, and glutinate, and to help all uterine effects proceeding from cold and windy humours.
Note that they mu≈øt be drunk warme, and in a good quantity, or el≈øe they will do more hurt then good.

The outward u≈øe of this is for ≈øuch ill effects as are in the habit of the body, and out of the veines, as of pal≈øies, contractions, rheumes, cold humors, affects of the skin and aches, for they re≈øolve, di≈øcu≈ø≈øe, clean≈øe, mollifie, &c.

Now for the manner of bathing I ≈øhall not pre≈øcribe any thing, but leave this to the di≈øcretion of the phy≈øitian, who is to give order and directions for all the circum≈øtances about it: for indeed every one is not to bath when, and how he plea≈øeth, but mu≈øt apply him≈øelfe to an able phy≈øitian, and ≈øubmit him≈øelf to his judgement and experience, or el≈øe may receive either prejudice, or no benefit thereby.

div.head: An artificiall Tunbridge, and Ep≈øa me Water.
div.p:
It is granted by all, that Tunbridge Water proceeds from an iron mine, but how it attracts that acidity and that ironi≈øh and vitriolated ta≈øt and odour, ≈øeeing upon evaporation thereof, there remains little or no vitriall or ≈øalt of iron at the bottome, is the great que≈øtion; Now for the ≈øolution of this, we mu≈øt con≈øider how many wayes a ≈øubterraneall minerall, or metall may communicate its acidity to waters, and that ≈øaith Henricus ab Heers, upon Spaw-waters, it doth three wayes: one, when the water pa≈ø≈øing through the mines, carryeth along with it ≈øome of the di≈ø≈øoluble parts of the mine, to which is con≈øonant the ≈øaying of Ari≈øtotle: Such are waters, as is the nature of tho≈øe Mines through which they pa≈ø≈øe, as al≈øo of Galen when he ≈øaith, that pure water pa≈ø≈øing through Minerall Mines carry with them ≈øome of the ≈øubstance of the Mines. The ≈øecond way is when the vapours ari≈øing from ≈øermented Mineralls and Metalls, are mixed with waters. Now that vapours retain the odour, and ta≈øt of tho≈øe things, from whence they are rai≈øed, Ari≈øtotle in his fourth Book Sublimium affirms, and al≈øo Helmont when he ≈øaith that ≈øome parts of the iron Mines being by fermentation turned into a vapour retain the odor and ta≈øt of the Mine by vertue of the acid e≈øurine ≈øalt, and are not pre≈øently reduced into a body, and al≈øo artificiall vapours of the iron Mines have more vertue, & activity, (I mean tho≈øe parts that are rai≈øed by a ≈øtrong fire in a furnace from the Mine of iron) then iron it ≈øelfe when it is melted. The third is, when a great quantity of vapours ari≈øing from the
afore≈øaid fermented Mines is elevated, and by the coldne≈ø≈øe of the ambient earth is turned into an acid water, which as it pa≈ø≈øeth through the earth meeteth with ≈øome ≈øprings of water, and mixing with them gives them a plea≈øant acidity. And this is the be≈øt of all acid wtaers being clear and very pure.

Take of the Mine, or ore of iron, beat it very ≈ømal, and put it into the furnace expre≈ø≈øed page 83. and there will come forth an acid Spirit, and flowers, which you mu≈øt mix together till the acid Spirit extracts the ≈øalt out of the flowers, then decant off the clear liquor which will have a ≈øtrong ta≈øt and ≈ømel of iron.
A few drops of this Liquor put into a gla≈ø≈øe full of fountaine water give it the odour and ta≈øt of Tunbridge water, and communicates the ≈øame operations to it.

It openeth all ob≈øtructions, purgeth by urine, clean≈øeth the kidneys, and bladder, helpeth the pi≈ø≈øing of bloud, the ≈øtopping of the urine, and difficulty of making water, it allayeth all ≈øharp humors, cureth inward ulcers, and impo≈øtumes, clean≈øeth and ≈øtrengtheneth the ≈øtomach, and liver &c.

Note that fountaine water being made moderately acid with this acid ironi≈øh Liquor may be taken from a pint to ≈øix pints, but by degrees, and after the taking of it moderate exerci≈øe is to be u≈øed, and fa≈øting to be ob≈øerved till all the water be gone out of the body, which will be in ≈øeven or eight houres.

Ep≈øome water is made artificially thus. Take of the mine of allom, or allom ≈øtones, powder it very ≈ømal, and di≈øtil it in the furnace expre≈ø≈øed page 83. and there will di≈øtill over a certain acid allumini≈øh water, which mu≈øt be mixed with a double quantity of Niter water (the preparation whereof is ≈øet down in the proce≈ø≈øe of making the artificiall hot bath). Now you mu≈øt know that Ep≈øome water hath a certain kind of acid ta≈øt which is partly alluminous and partly nitrous; which procedeth from nitrous air, and vapours ari≈øing from the fermentation of alluminous Mines, being fir≈øt mixed together, and then mixed with the fountaines pa≈ø≈øing through the earth.

If you put a few drops of this Liquor into a gla≈ø≈øe full of
fountaine water it will give it the odour, and ta≈øt of Ep≈øome water, that you ≈øhall ≈øcarce di≈øcerne them a≈øunder either by that odour, or operation.

This water is purgative, and indeed purgeth e≈øpecially all ≈øharp burning humours, cools an inflamed, and opens an ob≈øtructed body; clean≈øeth the kidneys and bladder, cureth inward ulcers, and impo≈øtumes, is a very good pre≈øervative again≈øt the con≈øumption, &c.

Fountaine water made acid with this Liquor may be taken from a pint to ≈øix or eight, but by degrees, and after it moderate exerci≈øe mu≈øt be u≈øed, and fa≈øting till the water be out of the body, only ≈øome thin warme ≈øuppings may be taken to helpe the working thereof. Some take this water warm.

div.head: To make artificiall precious ≈øtones of all ≈øorts of colours.
div.p: Take Cry≈øtalline white pibble-≈øtones that are very white throughout and have no mixture of any other colour, which you ≈øhal find in fountaines and on the ≈øands of the ≈øea. Put them into a crucible, make them glowing hot (covering the crucible) then ca≈øt them into cold water, by which means they will crack, and be ea≈øily reduced into a powder; Take the powder thereof, and put the like quantity of pure ≈øalt of Tartar thereto, which ≈øalt mu≈øt not be made in any metalline but gla≈ø≈øe ve≈ø≈øells, that it may have no mixture of any other colour. To this mixture you may adde what colour you plea≈øe, which mu≈øt be of a minerall or a metalline nature, then put them into a very ≈øtrong crucible which mu≈øt be but half full, and then covered, and there melt them in a ≈øtrong fire till they become like gla≈ø≈øe. Note that when this mixture is in melting you mu≈øt put an iron rod into it and take up ≈øome of it, & if there appear no cornes of gravell in it, it is enough; If otherwi≈øe, you mu≈øt melt it longer. The e≈øpeciall mineralls and metalls that give colours are the≈øe, viz. Copper, iron, ≈øilver, gold, Wi≈ømut, Magne≈øia, and granats.

Common copper makes a ≈øea-green; copper made out of iron a gra≈ø≈øe-green; granats, a ≈ømaragdine-green; iron yellow, or a Hyacinth colour; ≈øilver, white, yellow, green, and granat colour; gold a fine skie colour; Wi≈ømut common blew; magne≈øia,
an amethy≈øt colour: And if you will mix two or three of the≈øe together, they will give other colous. For copper and ≈øilver mixed together give an amethy≈øt colour: copper, and iron a pale green; Wi≈ømut, and magne≈øia, a purple colour; ≈øilver and magne≈øia divers colours like as an Opall. If you would have this ma≈ø≈øe not to be tran≈øparent but opac, you may adde the calx of tin to it when it is in melting: as if you would make Lapis lazuli; then ‚Ä¢ o your mixture coloured with Wi≈ømut adde the calx of tin, and this mixture when it is almo≈øt ready to congeal ca≈øt into a mould where ≈øome powder of gold hath been ≈øcattered, and by this means it wil become full of golden veins very like true lapis lazuli, which is very plea≈øant to behold. You may by the≈øe fore≈øaid preparations ca≈øt what formes or figures you plea≈øe, of what colour you plea≈øe.
The Metals, and Minerals for the making of colours ought to be thus prepared, viz.

Plates of copper mu≈øt be made red hot, and then quenched in cold water, of which then take five or ≈øix graines, and mix them with an ounce of the afore≈øaid mixture, and melt them all together, and they will colour it ≈øea-green.
Iron mu≈øt be made into a Crocus in a reverberatory fire, and then eight or ten grains thereof will tinge the mixture into a yellow, or hyacinth colour.
Silver is to be di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua fortis and precipitated with Oil of flints, then dulcified with water, and afterward dryed, of this five or ≈øix graines give a mingled colour.

Gold mu≈øt be di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua regis, and precipitated with the Liquor of flints, then ≈øweetened, and dryed, and five or ≈øix grains thereof giveth the fine≈øt ≈øaphir colour to an ounce of the mixture
If gold be melted with regulus martis nitro≈øus, five or ≈øix graines thereof give to an ounce of the ma≈ø≈øe a mo≈øt incomparable rubine colour.
Magne≈øia may be powdred only, and then ten or twelve grains thereof make an amethy≈øt colour.

Wi≈ømut mu≈øt be di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua regis, and precipitated with Liquor of flints, then ≈øweetened, and dryed; and then of this foure or five graines turne an ounce of the ma≈ø≈øe into a ≈øaphir colour, but not ≈øo naturall as gold doth.
Granata may be powder only, and then ten or fifteen grains thereof tinge an ounce of the ma≈ø≈øe into a fine green colour not unlike to the naturall Smaragdine.

div.head: To prove what kinde of metall there is in any Ore, although you have but a very few graines thereof, ≈øo as that you cannot make proofe thereof the ordinary way with lead.
div.p: Take two or foure graines (if you have no greater quantity) of any Ore that you have, put it to halfe an ounce of Venice-gla≈ø≈øe, and melt them together in a crucible, (the crucible being covered) and according to the tincture that the gla≈ø≈øe receiveth from the Ore, ≈øo may you judge what kinde of metall there is in the Ore; for if it be a copper Ore, then the gla≈ø≈øe will be tinged with a ≈øea-green colour.
If copper and iron, a gla≈ø≈øe-green.
If iron, a darke yellow.
If tin, a pale yellow.
If ≈øilver, a whiti≈øh yellow.
If gold, a fine skie colour.
If gold and ≈øilver together, a Smaragdine colour.
If gold, ≈øilver, copper, and iron together, an amethy≈øt colour.

div.head: A pretty ob≈øervation upon the melting of Copper and Tin together.
div.p: Fir≈øt make two bullets of red copper of the ≈øame magnitude, make al≈øo two bullets of the pure≈øt tin in the ≈øame mould, as the others were made: weigh all four bullets, and ob≈øerve the weight well: then melt the copper bullets fir≈øt, upon them being melted put the two tin bullets, and melt them together, but have a care that the tin fume not away. Then ca≈øt this molten mixture in the ≈øame moulds as before, and it will ≈øcarce make three bullets, but yet they weigh as heavy as they did before they were melted together.
I ≈øuppo≈øe the copper conden≈øeth the body of the tin, which before was very porous, which conden≈øation rather addes then dimini≈øheth the weight thereof.

div.head: A remarkable ob≈øervation upon the melting of Salt Armoniack, and Calx vive together.
div.p: Take Salt armoniack, and Calx vive, of each a like quantity, mix, and melt them together. Note that Calx of it ≈øelfe will not melt in le≈ø≈øe then eight houres with the ≈øtronge≈øt fire that can be made, but being mixed with this ≈øalt melts in half an houre, and le≈ø≈øe, like a metall, with an indifferent fire.

This mixture being thus melted becomes a hard ≈øtone, out of which you may ≈øtrike fire as out of a flint, which if you di≈ø≈øolve again in water, you ≈øhall have the Salt armoniack in the ≈øame quantity as before, but fixed.
Note that hard things have their congelation from Salt armoniack, as hornes, bones and ≈øuch like; for little fixed ≈øalt can be extracted from them, only volatile and armoniack.
An ounce of any of the≈øe volatile ≈øalts, (as of hornes, bones, amber, and ≈øuch like) reduced into an acid Liquor by di≈øtillation, conden≈øeth, and indurateth a pound of Oily matter.

div.head: An ea≈øie and cheap powder like unto aurum fulminans.
div.p: Take of ≈øalt Tartar one part, Salt-peter three parts, Sulphur a third part, grind the≈øe well together, and dry them. A few graines of this powder being fired will give as great a clap as a musket when it is di≈øcharged.

div.head: To make an Antimoniall cup, and to cast divers figures of Antimony.
div.p: Take the be≈øt crude antimony very well powdered, Nitre, of each a po ‚Ä¢ nd, of crude Tartar finely powdered two pound, mix them well together, and put them into a crucible, cover the crucible, and melt them, and the regulus will fall to the bottome, and be like a melted metall, then pour it forth into a bra≈ø≈øe mortar, being fir≈øt ≈ømeared over with Oil.

Or,
Take two parts of powdered Antimony, and four parts o ‚Ä¢
powder of crude Tartar, melt the≈øe as afore≈øaid.

This regulus you may (when you have made enough of it) melt again and ca≈øt it into what moulds you plea≈øe, you may either make cups, or what pictures you plea≈øe, and of what figures you plea≈øe. You may ca≈øt it into formes of ≈øhillings or halfe-crowns, either of which if you put it into two or three ounces of wine in an earthen glazed ve≈ø≈øell, or gla≈ø≈øe, and infu≈øe in a moderate heat all night, you may have a Liquor in the morning which will cau≈øe vomit: of which the do≈øe is from two drams to two ounces and half.
Note that in the Wine you may put a little Cinamon to correct and give a more gratefull reli≈øh to it.

It is the cu≈øtome to fill the Antimoniall cup with Wine, and to put as much Wine round about betwixt that and the little earthen cup where it ≈øtands, and ≈øo infu≈øe it all night, and then drink up all that Wine: but I fear, that ≈øo much Wine will be too much as being three or four ounces when as we ≈øeldome exceed the quantity of two ounces of the infu≈øion of Antimony.

The≈øe cups, or pictures will la≈øt for ever, and be as effectuall after a thou≈øand times infu≈øion as at fir≈øt: and if they be broken at any time, (as ea≈øily they may being as brittle as gla≈ø≈øe) they may be ca≈øt again into what formes you plea≈øe.

Note that he that ca≈øts them mu≈øt be skilfull in making his ≈øpawde, as al≈øo in ≈øcouring of them, and making them bright afterwards: for if they be carefully handled they will look even as bright as ≈øilver.

div.head: The Spagyricall Anatomy of Gold, and Silver, together with the Curio≈øities therein, and chiefest preparations thereof.
div.p:
I Shall fir≈øt endeavour to ≈øhew whence Gold had its originall, and what the matter thereof is. As Nature (≈øaith Sandivogius) is in the will of God, and God created her: ≈øo nature made for her ≈øelfe a ≈øeed, (i.) her will in the elements. Now ≈øhe indeed is one, yet ≈øhe brings forth divers things; but ≈øhe operates nothing without a Sperme: what≈øoever the Sperme will, nature operates, for ≈øhe is as it were the in≈øtrument of any artificers. The Sperme therefore of every thing is better, and more profitable then nature her ≈øelf: for thou ≈øhalt from nature without a Sperme, doe as much as a gold≈ømith without fire, or a husband without grain or ≈øeed. Now the Sperme of any thing is the Elixir, the bal≈øame of ≈øulphur, and the ≈øame as Humidum Radicale is in metalls: but to
proceed to what concernes our purpo≈øe. Four elements generate a Sperme, by the will of God, and imagination of nature: For as the Sperme of a man hath its center, or the ve≈ø≈øell of its ≈øeed in the kidneys: ≈øo the foure elements by their inde≈øinent motion (every one according to its quality) ca≈øt forth a Sperme into the center of the earth, where it is dige≈øted, and by motion is ≈øent abroad. Now the center of the earth is a certaine empty place, where nothing can re≈øt: and the four elements ≈øend forth their qualities into the circumference of the center. As a male ≈øends forth his ≈øeed into the womb of the female, which after it hath received a due portion ca≈øts out the re≈øt, ≈øo it happens in the center of the earth, that the magnetick powder of a part of any place attracts ≈øomething convenient to it ≈øelfe for the bringing forth of ≈øomething, and the re≈øt is ca≈øt forth into ≈øtones and other excrements. For every thing hath its originall from this fountain, and there is nothing in the world produced but by this fountaine: as for example, ≈øet upon an even table a ve≈ø≈øell of water, which may be placed in the middle thereof, and round about it ≈øet divers things, and divers colours, al≈øo ≈øalt, &c. every thing by it ≈øelfe: then poure the water into the middle; and you ≈øhall ≈øee the water to run every way, and when any ≈øtreame toucheth the red colour, it will be made red by it, if the ≈øalt, it will contract the ta≈øt of ≈øalt from it, and ≈øo of the re≈øt; Now the water doth not change the places, but the diver≈øity of places changeth the water. In like manner the ≈øeed or ≈øperme being ca≈øt forth by the foure elements from the center of the earth unto the ≈øuperficies thereof pa≈ø≈øeth through various places, and according to the nature of the place is any thing produced: if it come to a pure place of earth, and water, a pure thing is made.

The ≈øeed, and ≈øperme of all things is but one, and yet it generates divers things, as it appears by the former example. The ≈øperme while≈øt it is in the center is indifferent to all forms, but when it is come into any determinate place, it changeth no more its forme. The ≈øperme while≈øt it is in the center can as ea≈øily produce a tree, as a metall, and an hearb as a ≈øtone, and one more precious then another according to the
purity of the place. Now this ≈øperme is produced of elements thus. The≈øe foure elements are never quiet but by rea≈øon of their contrariety mutually act one upon another; and every one of its ≈øelfe ≈øends forth its own ≈øubtilty, and they agree in the center. Now in this center is the Archaeus, the ≈øervant of nature, which mixing tho≈øe ≈øpermes together ≈øends them abroad, and by di≈øtillation ≈øublimes them by the heat of a continuall motion unto the ≈øuperficies of the earth: For the earth is porous, and this vapour (or wind, as the philo≈øophers call it) is by di≈øtilling through the pores of the earth re≈øolved into water, of which all things are produced. Let therefore as I ≈øaid before, all ≈øons of Art know that the ≈øperme of metals is not different from the ≈øperme of all things being, viz. a humid vapour. Therefore in vain do Arti≈øts endeavour the reduction of metals into their fir≈øt matter, which is only a vapour. Now ≈øaith Bernard Trevi≈øan when philo≈øophers ≈øpeak of a fir≈øt matter they did not meane this vapour, but the ≈øecond matter which is an unctuous water, which to us is the fir≈øt, becau≈øe we never find the former. Now the ≈øpecification of this vapour into di≈øtinct metals is thus. This vapour pa≈ø≈øeth in its di≈øtillation through the earth, through places either cold, or hot; if through hot, and pure where the fatne≈ø≈øe of ≈øulphur ≈øticks to the ≈øides thereof, then that vapour (which philo≈øophers call the Mercury of philo≈øophers) mixeth, and joyneth it ≈øelf unto that fatne≈ø≈øe, which afterward it ≈øublimes with it ≈øelfe, and then it becomes, leaving the name of a vapour, and unctuo≈øity, which afterwards coming by ≈øublimation into other places, which the antecedent vapour did purge, where the earth is ≈øubtle, pure, and humid, fils the pores thereof, and is joyned to it; and ≈øo it becomes gold: and where it is hot, and ≈øomething impure, ≈øilver. But if that fatne≈ø≈øe come to impure places, which are cold, it is made lead: and if that place be pure and mixed with ≈øulphur, it becomes copper: for by how much the more pure and warm the place is, ≈øo much the more excellent doth it make the metalls.

Now this fir≈øt matter of metals is a humid, vi≈øcous, incombu≈øtible, ≈øubtle ≈øub≈øtance, incorporated with an earthy ≈øubtilty, being equally, and ≈øtrongly mixed per minima in the caverns of
the earth. But as in many things there is a twofold unctuo≈øity (whereof one is as it were internall, retained in the center of the thing le≈øt it ≈øhould be de≈øtroyed by fire, which cannot be without the de≈øtruction of the ≈øub≈øtance it ≈øelfe wherein it is: the other as it were externall, feculent and combu≈øtible) ≈øo in all metalls except gold, there is a twofold unctuo≈øity: the one which is externall, ≈øulphurous, and inflamable, which is joyned to it by accident, and doth not belong to the totall union with the terre≈øtrial parts of the thing: the other is internall, and very ≈øubtle, incombu≈øtible, becau≈øe it is of the ≈øub≈øtantiall compo≈øition of Argent vive, and therefore cannot be de≈øtroyed by fire, unle≈ø≈øe with the de≈øtruction of the whole ≈øub≈øtance, whence it appeares what the cau≈øe is that metalls are more or le≈ø≈øe durable in the fire: For tho≈øe which abound with that internall unctuo≈øity are le≈ø≈øe con≈øumed, as it appears in ≈øilver, and e≈øpecially in gold. Hence Ro≈øarius ≈øaith, the philo≈øophers could never by any meanes find out any thing that could endure the fire; but that unctuous humidity only which is perfect, and incombu≈øtible. Geber al≈øo a≈ø≈øerts the ≈øame, when he ≈øaith that imperfect bodies have ≈øuperfluous humidities, and ≈øulphureity generating a combu≈øtible blackne≈ø≈øe in them, and corrupting them; they have al≈øo an impure, feculent and combu≈øtible tere≈øtriety ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe, as that it hinders ingre≈ø≈øion, and fu≈øion: but a perfect metall, as gold, hath neither this ≈øulphurous or terre≈øtriall impurity; I mean when it is fully maturated and melted, for while≈øt it is in concoction it hath both joyned to it, as you may ≈øee in the golden Ore, but when they doe not adhere to it ≈øo, but that it may be purified from them, which other metalls cannot, but are both de≈øtroyed together if you attempt to ≈øeparate the one from the other: Be≈øides gold hath ≈øo little of the≈øe corruptible principles mixed with it, that the inward ≈øulphur or metalline ≈øpirit doth ≈øometimes and in ≈øome places overcome them of it ≈øelfe, as we may ≈øee in the gold which is found very pure ≈øometimes in the ≈øuperficies of the earth, and in the ≈øea ≈øands, and is many times as pure as any refined gold.

Now this gold which is found in ≈øands and rivers, is not generated there, as ≈øaith Gregorius Agricola in his third book de
Re Metallica, but is wa≈øhed down from the mountains with fountaines that run from thence. There is al≈øo a flaming gold found (as Paracel≈øus ≈øaith) in the tops of mountaines, which is indeed ≈øeparated of it ≈øelfe from all impurities, and is as pure as any refined gold what≈øoever. So that you ≈øee, that gold although it had an extrin≈øecall ≈øulphur and earth mixed with it, yet it is ≈øometimes ≈øeparated from it of it ≈øelfe, viz. by that fiery ≈øpirit that is in it. Now this pure gold (as ≈øaith Sandivogius) nature would have perfected into an elixir but was hindred by the crude air, which crude air is indeed nothing el≈øe but that extrin≈øecall ≈øulphur which it meets with and is joyned to in the earth, and which fills with its violence the pores thereof, and hinders the activity of the Spirit thereof; and this is that pri≈øon which the ≈øulphur (as ≈øaith the afore≈øaid author) is locked up in, ≈øo that it cannot act upon its body, viz. Mercury, and concoct it into the ≈øeed of gold; as otherwi≈øe it would doe: and this is that darke body (as faith Penotus) that is interpo≈øed betwixt the philo≈øophicall Sunne and Moone, and keeps off the influences of the one from the other. Now if any skilfull philo≈øopher could wittily ≈øeparate this adventitious impurity from gold while≈øt it is yet living, he would ≈øet ≈øulphur at liberty, and for this his ≈øervice he would be gratified with three kingdomes, viz. Vegetable, Animall, and Minerall, I mean he could remove that great ob≈øtruction which hinders gold from being dige≈øted into the Elixir. For, as ≈øaith Sandivogius, the Elixir, or Tincture of philo≈øophers, is nothing el≈øe but gold dige≈øted into the highe≈øt degree: for the gold of the vulgar is as an hearb without ≈øeed, but when gold (i.) living gold (for common gold never can by rea≈øon that the Spirits are bound up, and indeed as good as dead and not po≈ø≈øibly to be reduced to that activity which is required for the producing of the ≈øperme of gold) is ripened it gives a ≈øeed, which multiplies even ad infinitum. Now the rea≈øon of this barrenne≈ø≈øe of gold that it produceth not a ≈øeed is the afore≈øaid crude aire, viz. impurities: You may ≈øee this illu≈øtrated by this example.

We ≈øee that Orenge-trees in Polonia doe grow like other trees, al≈øo in Italy, and el≈øewhere, where their native ≈øoyle
is, and yeeld fruit, becau≈øe they have ≈øufficient heat, but in the≈øe colder colder countreys they are barren and never yeeld any fruit, becau≈øe they are oppre≈ø≈øed with cold: but if at any time nature be wittily and ≈øweetly helped, then Art can perfect what nature could not. After the ≈øame manner it is in metalls; for gold would yeeld fruit, and ≈øeed in which it might multiply it ≈øelfe, if it were helped by the indu≈øtry of the skilfull arti≈øt, who knew how to promote nature, (i.) to ≈øeparate the≈øe ≈øulphurous and earthly impurities from gold. For there is a ≈øufficient heat in living gold, which if it were ≈øtirred up by extrin≈øecall heat, to dige≈øt it into a ≈øeed. By extrin≈øecall heat I doe not mean the heat of the cele≈øtiall Sun, but that heat which is in the earth and ≈øtirres up the ≈øeed, (i.) the living ≈øpirit that is in all ≈øubteraneall ≈øperms to multiply, and indeed makes gold become gold. Now this is a heat of putrefaction occa≈øioned by acid ≈øpirits fermenting in the earth, as you may ≈øee by this example related by Albertus Magnus, but to which the rea≈øon was given by Sandivogius. There was ≈øaith the former author, certaine graines of gold found betwixt the teeth of a dead man in the grave: wherefore he conceived there was a power in the body of man to make and ‚Ä¢ ixe gold: but the rea≈øon is farre otherwi≈øe, as ≈øaith the latter authour: for ≈øaith he, Argent vive was by ≈øome phy≈øitian conveyed into the body of this man when he was alive, either by unction, or by turbith, or ≈øome ≈øuch way, as the cu≈øtome was; and it is the nature of Mercury to a≈øcend to the mouth of the patient, and through the excoriation of the mouth to be avoided with the flegme. Now then if in ≈øuch a cure the ≈øickman dyed, that Mercury not having pa≈ø≈øage out remained betwixt the teeth in the mouth, and that carca≈ø≈øe became the naturall ve≈ø≈øell of Mercury, and ≈øo for a long time being ≈øhut up was congealed by its proper ≈øulphur into gold by the naturall heat of putrefaction, being purified by the corro≈øive flegme of the carka≈ø≈øe, but if the minerall Mercury had not been brought in thither, gold had never been produced there: And this is a mo≈øt true example that as mercury is by the proper ≈øulphur that is in it ≈øelfe, being ≈øtirred up and helped by an extrin≈øecall heat, coagulated into gold, unle≈ø≈øe it be hindred by
any accident, or have not a requi≈øite extrin≈øecall heat, or convenient place, ≈øo al≈øo that nature doth in the bowels of the earth produce of Mercury only gold and ≈øilver, and other metalls according to the di≈øpo≈øition of the place, and matrix; which a≈ø≈øertion is further cleared by the rule of reduction, for if it be true that all things con≈øi≈øt of that which they may be reduced into, then gold con≈øi≈øts of Mercury, becau≈øe (as mo≈øt grant, Paracel≈øus affirmes, and many at this day profe≈ø≈øe they can doe) it may be reduced into it. There is a way by which the tincture of gold which is the ≈øoule thereof, and fixeth it, may be ≈øo fully extracted that the remaining ≈øub≈øtance will be ≈øublimed like Ar≈øenick, and may be as ea≈øily reduced into Mercury as Sublimate. If ≈øo, and if all Mercury may be reduced into a tran≈øparent water, as it may (according to the proce≈ø≈øe ≈øet down page 75. and as I know how another better and ea≈øier way to turn a pound of Mercury of it ≈øelf into a clear water in halfe an houre, which is one of the greate≈øt ≈øecrets I know, or care to know, together with what may be produced thence, and ≈øhall crave leave to be ≈øilent in) why may not that water in ≈øome ≈øen≈øe, if it be well rectified, be called a kinde of living gold out of which you may perhaps make a medicine, and a men≈øtruum unfit for the vulgar to know. It appears now from what is premi≈øed that the immediate matter of gold is probably Mercury, and not certaine ≈øalts and I know not what as many dream of, and that the extrin≈øecall heat is from within the earth, and not the heat of the ≈øun, as ≈øome imagine (becau≈øe in the hotte≈øt countreys there is all, or almo≈øt all gold generated) who if they con≈øidered that in cold countreys al≈øo are, and as in Scotland were gold mines in King James his time, would be of another mind then to think that the cele≈øtiall ≈øun could penetrate, ≈øo as to heat the earth ≈øo deep as mo≈øt gold lies.

I now having in ≈øome mea≈øure di≈øcovered what the intrin≈ø ‚Ä¢
call, and extrin≈øecall heat, and the matter of gold is, I ≈øhall next endeavour to explaine what tho≈øe three principles are, viz. Salt, Sulphur, and Mercury, of which Argent vive, and gold con≈øi≈øt: Know therefore that after Nature had received from the mo≈øt High God the priviledge of all things upon the Monarchy
of this wourld, ≈øhe began to di≈øtribute places, and provinces to every thing, according to its dignity; and in the fir≈øt place did con≈øtitute the foure elements to be the princes of the world, and that the will of the mo≈øt High (in who≈øe will Nature is placed) might be fulfilled, ordained that they ≈øhould act upon one another ince≈ø≈øantly. The fire therefore began to act upon the aire, and produced ≈øulphur: The air al≈øo began to act upon the water, and produced Mercury: the water al≈øo began to act upon the earth, and produced ≈øalt. Now the earth not having whereoÃÑ to act produced nothing, but became the ≈øubject of what was produced. So then there were produced three principles, but our ancient philo≈øophers not ≈øo ≈øtrictly con≈øidering the matter de≈øcribed only two acts of the elements, and ≈øo named but two principles, viz. Sulphur and Mercury: or el≈øe they were willing to be ≈øilent in the other, ≈øpeaking only to the ≈øon of Art.

The Sulphur therefore of philo≈øophers, (which indeed is the ≈øulphur of metalls, and of all things) is not, as many think, that common combu≈øtible ≈øulphur which is ≈øold in ≈øhops, but is another thing farre differing from that, and is incombu≈øtible, not burning, nor heating, but pre≈øerving, and re≈øtoring all things which it is in, and it is the Calidum Innatum of every thing, the fire of nature, the created light, and of the nature of the fun, and is called the Sun; ≈øo that what≈øoever in any thing is fiery, and airy, is ≈øulphur, not that any thing is wholly ≈øulphureous, but what in it is mo≈øt thin, and ≈øubtle, having the e≈ø≈øence of the naturall fire, and the nature of the created light, which indeed is that ≈øulphur which wi≈øe philo≈øophers have in all ages with great diligence endeavoured to extract, and with its proper Mercury to fix, and ≈øo to perfect the great Magi≈øtery of nature. Now of all things in the world there is nothing hath more of this ≈øulphur in it then gold and ≈øilver, but e≈øpecially gold, in≈øomuch that oftentimes it is called ≈øulphur, (i.) becau≈øe ≈øulphur is the mo≈øt predominant, and excellent principle in it, and being in it more then in all things be≈øides.

Mercury is not here taken for common Argent vive; but it is the Humidum Radicale of every thing, that pure aqueous,
unctuous, and vi≈øcous humidity of the matter, and it is of the nature of the Moon, and it is called the Moone, and that for this rea≈øon, viz. becau≈øe it is humid, as al≈øo becau≈øe it is capable of receiving the influence and light of the Sun, viz. ≈øulphur.

Salt is that fixt permanent earth which is in the center of every thing that is incorruptible, and inalterable, and it is the ≈øupporter and nour≈øe of the Humidum Radicale, with which it is ≈øtrongly mixt. Now this ≈øalt hath in it a ≈øeed, viz. its Calidum Innatum, which is Sulphur, and its Humidum Radicale which is Mercury; and yet the≈øe three are not di≈øtinct or to be ≈øeparated, but are one homogeneall thing, having upon a different account divers names: for in re≈øpect of its heat, and fiery ≈øub≈øtance it is called Sulphur, in re≈øpect of its humidity, it is called Mercury, and in re≈øpect of its terre≈øtriall ≈øiccity it is called ≈øalt, all which are in gold perfectly united, depurated, and fixed.
Gold therefore is mo≈øt noble, and ≈øolid of all metalls, of a yellow colour, compacted of principles dige≈øted to the utmo≈øt hight, and therefore fixed.
Silver is in the next place of dignity to Gold, and differs from it in dige≈øtion chiefly, I ≈øaid chiefly, becau≈øe there is ≈øome ≈ømall impurity be≈øides, adhering to ≈øilver.

Now having given ≈øome ≈ømall account of the originall matter, fir≈øt, and ≈øecond, and manner of the growth of gold, I ≈øhall in the next place ≈øet downe ≈øome curio≈øities therein, and preparation thereof. The preparations are chiefly three, viz. Aurum potabile, which is the mixtion thereof with other Liquors: Oil of gold, which is gold liquid by it ≈øelfe without the mixture of any other Liquor: and the tincture, which is the extraction of the colour thereof.

div.head: Dr. Anthony's famous Aurum potabile, and Oil of gold.
div.p:
Di≈ø≈øolve pure fine gold in Aqua regis according to art (the Aqua regis being made of a pound of Aqua fortis, and foure ounces of ≈øalt Armo niack di≈øtilled together by Retort in ≈øand) which clear folution put into a large gla≈ø≈øe of a wide neck,
and upon it pour drop by drop Oil of Tartar made per deliquium, untill the Aqua regis which before was yellow become clear, and white, for that is a ≈øigne that all calx of gold is ≈øetled to the bottome: then let it ≈øtand all night, and in the morning pour off the clear Liquor, and wa≈øh the calx four or five times with common ≈øpring water, being warmed, and dry it with a mo≈øt gentle heat.

Note, and that wel, that if the heat be too great, the calx takes fire pre≈øently like Gun-powder and flies away to thy danger and lo≈ø≈øe, therefore it is be≈øt to dry it in the ≈øun, or on a ≈øtone, ≈øtirring it diligently with a wooden ≈øpatle. To this calx adde halfe a part of the powder of ≈øulphur, mix them together and in an open crucible let the ≈øulphur burne away in the fire, putting a gentle fire to it at the fir≈øt, and in the end a mo≈øt ≈øtrong fire for the ≈øpace of an houre, that the calx may in ≈øome manner be reverberated, and become mo≈øt ≈øubtle, which keep in a viall clo≈øe ≈øtopt for your u≈øe.

Then make a Spirit of urine after this manner, viz. Take the urine of a healthy man drinking Wine moderately, put it into a gourd, which you mu≈øt ≈øtop clo≈øe, and ≈øet in hor≈øedung for the ≈øpace of forty dayes, then di≈øtill it by Alembick in ≈øand into a large receiver, untill all the humidity be di≈øtilled off. Rectifie this Spirit by cohobation three times, that the Spirit only may ri≈øe. Then di≈øtill it in ≈øand by a gla≈ø≈øe with a long neck, having a large receiver annexed, and clo≈øed very well to it, and the Spirit will be elevated into the top of the ve≈ø≈øell like cry≈øtall without any aqueous humidity accompanying of it. Let this di≈øtillation be continued, untill all the Spirits be ri≈øen. The≈øe cry≈øtalls mu≈øt be di≈ø≈øolved in di≈øtilled rain-water, and be di≈øtilled as before, this mu≈øt be done ≈øix times, and every time you mu≈øt take fre≈øh rain-water di≈øtilled. Then put the≈øe cry≈øtalls into a gla≈ø≈øe bolthead, which clo≈øe Hermetically, and ≈øet in the moderate heat of a Balneum for the ≈øpace of fifteen dayes, that they may be reduced into a mo≈øt clear Liquor. To this Liquor adde an equall weight of Spirit of Wine, very well rectified, and let them be dige≈øted in Balneo the ≈øpace of twelve dayes, in which time they will be united.

Then take the calx of gold above≈øaid, and poure upon it of the≈øe united Spirits as much as will cover them three fingers breadth, and dige≈øt them in a gentle heat, untill the Liquor be tinged as red as bloud; decant off the tincture, and put on more of the afore≈øaid Spirits, and do as before till all the tincture be extracted, then put all the tincted Spirits together, and dige≈øt them ten or twelve dayes, after which time ab≈øtract the Spirit with a gentle heat, and cohobate it once; and then the calx will remain in the bottome like an Oil as red as bloud, and of a plea≈øant odour, and which will be di≈ø≈øolved in any Liquor. Whereof this Oil may be the Succedaneum of true gold. If you di≈øtill the ≈øame ≈øolution by Retort in ≈øand there will come over after the fir≈øt part of the men≈øtruum, the tincture with the other part thereof; as red as bloud, the earth which is left in the bottome of the ve≈ø≈øell being black, dry, ≈øpongious and light. The men≈øtruum mu≈øt be vapoured away, and the Oil of gold will remain by it ≈øelf, which mu≈øt be kept as a great trea≈øure: and this is Dr. Anthony's Aurum potabile.
Foure or eight graines of this Oil taken in what manner ≈øoever wonderfully refre≈øheth the Spirits, and workes ≈øeverall wayes, e≈øpecially by ≈øweat.

div.head: The true Oil of Gold.
div.p: Take an ounce of leafe-gold, di≈ø≈øolve it in foure ounces of the rectified water of Mercury expre≈ø≈øed page 75. dige≈øt them in hor≈øe-dung the ≈øpace of two moneths, then evaporate the Mercuriall water, and at the bottome you ≈øhall have the true Oil of gold, which is radically di≈ø≈øolved.

div.head: A Tincture of Gold.
div.p:
Di≈ø≈øolve pure gold in Aqua regis, precipitate it with the Oil of ≈øand into a yellow powder, which you mu≈øt dulcifie with warme water, and then dry it (this will not be fired as Aurum fulminans) This powder is twice as heavie as the gold

div.head: Another Tincture of Gold.
div.p: Take of the afore≈øaid yellow Calx of gold precipitated with Oil of ≈øand, one part, and three or foure parts of the Liquor of ≈øand, or of cry≈øtalls; mix them well together, and put them into a crucible in a gentle heat at fir≈øt, that the moi≈øture of the Oil may vapour away (which it will not do ea≈øily becau≈øe the dryne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øand retaines the moi≈øture thereof, ≈øo that it flyeth away like molten allum, or borax) when no more will vapour away, encrea≈øe your fire, till the crucible be red hot, and the mixture cea≈øe bubling: then put it into a wind furnace and cover it that no a≈øhes fall into it, and make a ≈øtrong fire about it for the ≈øpace of an houre, and the mixture will be turned into a tran≈øparent Rubie.
