div.head: Another tincture of Gold.
div.p: Hang plates of gold over the fume of Argent vive, and they will become white, friable, and fluxil as wax. This is called the Magne≈øia of gold, as ≈øaith Paracel≈øus, in finding out of which (≈øaith he) philo≈øophers, as Thomas Aquinas, and Rupe≈øci≈ø≈øa with their followers took a great deale of paines, but in vaine, and it is a memorable ≈øecret and indeed very ≈øingular for the melting of metals that are not ea≈øily fluxil. Now then gold being thus prepared, and melted together with the Mercury, is become a brittle ≈øub≈øtance, which mu≈øt be powdered and out of it a tincture may be drawn for the tran≈ømuting of metals.

div.head: Another Tincture.
div.p: Take halfe an ounce of pure gold, di≈ø≈øolve it in Aqua regis, precipitate it with Oil of flints, dulcifie the calx with warme water and dry it, and ≈øo it is prepared for your work. Then take Regulus Martis powdered, and mix it with three parts of ≈øalt Nitre, both which put into a crucible and make them glow gently at fir≈øt, then give a ≈øtrong melting fire, and then this mixture will become to be of a purple colour, which then take out, and beat to powder, and add to three parts of this, one part of the calx of gold prepared as before, put them into a wine furnace in a ≈øtrong crucible, and make them melt as a metall, ≈øo will the Nitrum antimoniatum in the melting take the calx of gold to it ≈øelfe, and di≈ø≈øolve it, and the mixture will become to be of an Amethy≈øt colour. Let this ≈øtand flowing in the fire till the whole ma≈ø≈øe be as tran≈øparent as a Rubine, which you may try by taking a little out and cooling of it. If the mixture do not flow well, ca≈øt in ≈øome more ≈øalt Nitre. When it is compleatly done ca≈øt it forth being flowing into a brazen mortar, and it wil be like to an orientall Rubine; then powder it before it be cold, then put it into a viall and with the Spirit of Wine extract the tincture.
This is one of the be≈øt preparations of gold, and of mo≈øt excellent u≈øe in medicine.

div.head: Another Tincture.
div.p: Fir≈øt make a furnace fit for the purpo≈øe, which mu≈øt be clo≈øe at the top and have a pipe to which a recipient with a flat bottome mu≈øt be fitted: When this furnace is thus fitted, put in three or foure graines, not above at once, of Aurum fulminans, which a≈ø≈øoon as the furnace is hot, flyeth away into the recipient through the pipe like a purple coloured fume, and is turned into a purple coloured powder, then put in three or four grains more, and doe as before, till you have enough flowers of gold (that which flyeth not away but remaineth at the bottome, may with borax be melted into good gold) then take them out and pour upon them rectified Spirit of Wine tartarizated, and dige≈øt them in a≈øhes till the ≈øpirit be coloured bloud red, which you mu≈øt then evaporate and at the bottome will be a bloud red tincture of no ≈ømall vertue.

div.head: Aurum fulminans.
div.p:
Take the pure≈øt gold you can get, pour on it four times as much Aqua regia, ≈øtop your gla≈ø≈øe with a paper, and ≈øet it in warme a≈øhes, ≈øo will the Aqua regia in an houre or two take up the gold, and become a yellow water, if it be ≈øtrong enough: (be ≈øure that your gold hath no copper in it, for then your labour will be lo≈øt) becau≈øe the copper will be precipitated with the gold, and hinder the firing thereof) then pour on this yellow water drop by drop pure Oil of Tartar made per deliquium, ≈øo will the gold be precipitated into a dark yellow powder, and the water be clear. Note that you pour not on more Oil of Tartar then is ≈øufficient for the precipitation, otherwi≈øe it will di≈ø≈øolve part of the precipitated gold to thy prejudice. Pour off the clear Liquor by inclination, and dulcifie the calx with di≈øtilled rain-water warmed. Then ≈øet this calx in the ≈øun, or ≈øome warme place to dry, but take great heed, and e≈øpeciall care that you ≈øet it not in a place too hot, for it will pre≈øently take fire, and fly away like thunder, not without ‚Ä¢ reat danger to the ≈øtanders by, if the quantity be
great. This is the common way to make Aurum fulminans, and it hath con≈øiderable difficulties in the preparation. But the be≈øt way is to precipitate gold di≈ø≈øolved in Aqua regis by the Spirit of ≈øalt Armoniack or of urine, for by this way the gold is made purer then by the other, and giveth a far greater crack and ≈øound. Note that the ≈øalt of the Spirits which is precipitated with the gold mu≈øt be wa≈øhed away, and the gold dulcified as before.

A few grains of this being fired give a crack and ≈øound as great as a musket when it is di≈øcharged, and will blow up any thing more forcibly, far then gunpowder, and it is a powder that will quickly and ea≈øily be fired.
This is of u≈øe for phy≈øick as it is in powder, but e≈øpecially it is u≈øed in making the foregoing tincture.

div.head: To make gold grow in a gla≈ø≈øe like a tree, which is called the golden tree of the Philo≈øophers.
div.p: Take of Oil of ≈øand as much as you plea≈øe, pour upon it the ≈øame quantity of Oil of Tartar per deliquium, ≈øhake them well together that they be incorporated and become as one Liquor of a thin con≈øi≈øtence, then is your Men≈øtruum or Liquor prepared. Then di≈ø≈øolve gold in Aqua regia, and evaporate the Men≈øtruum and dry the Calx in the fire, but make it not too hot, for it will thereby lo≈øe its growing quality, then take it out and break it into little bits, not into powder, put tho≈øe bits into the afore≈øaid Liquor (that they may lye a fingers breadth the one from the other) in a very clear gla≈ø≈øe. Keep the Liquor from the air, and you ≈øhall ≈øee that tho≈øe bits of the calx will pre≈øently begin to grow; fir≈øt they will ≈øwell, then they will put forth one or two ≈øtems, then divers branches and twigs ≈øo exactly, as that you can not chu≈øe but exceedingly to wonder. This growing is reall, and not imaginary only. Note that the gla≈ø≈øe mu≈øt ≈øtand ≈øtill, and not be moved.

div.head: Another way.
div.p: Calcine fine gold in Aqua regis, that it become a calx, which put into a gourd gla≈ø≈øe, and pour upon it good and fre≈øh Aqua regia, and the water of gradation, ≈øo that they cover the calx four fingers breadth, this Men≈øtruum ab≈øtract in the third degree of fire untill no more will a≈øcend. This di≈øtilled water pour on it again and ab≈øtract it as before, and this do ≈øo often till you ≈øee the gold ri≈øe in the gla≈ø≈øe, and grow in the forme of a tree having many boughs and leaves.

div.head: To make-Gold grow and be increa≈øed in the earth.
div.p: Take leaves of gold, and bury them in the earth which looks towards the Ea≈øt, and let it be often ≈øoiled with mans urine, and doves dung, and you ≈øhall ≈øee that in a ≈øhort time they will be increa≈øed.

The rea≈øon of this growth I conceive may be the golds attracting that univer≈øall vapour and ≈øperme that comes from the center through the earth (as hath been ≈øpoken in the anatomy of gold) and by the heat of putrefaction of the dung purifying and a≈ø≈øimilating it to it ≈øelfe.

div.head: A remarkable ob≈øervation upon a golden Marca≈øite.
div.p:
There is found a certaine ≈øtone in Bononia, which ≈øome call a golden Marca≈øite, ≈øome a ≈øolarie Magnes, that receives light from the ≈øun in the day time, and gives it forth in the dark. About this there have been much rea≈øoning among≈øt Philo≈øophers, as whether light be really a body, or any kinde of ≈øub≈øtance, or any accident only, and whether this ≈øtone had any gold in it or no, and what it did con≈øi≈øt of. Hee that fir≈øt di≈øcovered it thought that he had found a thing that would tran≈ømute metals into gold, (by which it appears that there ≈øeemed to be ≈øomething of gold in it or ≈øomething more glorious then gold) but his hopes were fru≈øtrated by a fruitle≈ø≈øe labour,
notwith≈øtanding which I conceive there might be ≈øome immature or crude gold in it; for crude gold is a ≈øubject (being there is ≈øome life in it) that is mo≈øt fit to receive the influences of the ≈øun according to the unanimous con≈øent of all Philo≈øophers, and therefore is by them not only called Solary but Sol (i.) the Sun it ≈øelfe.

It is prepared for the receiving of light thus, it is calcined two wayes, fir≈øt it is brought into a mo≈øt ≈øubtle powder with a very ≈øtrong fire in a crucible; ≈øecondly, being thus brought into a powder, is made up into cakes as big as a doller, or a piece of eight, either with common water alone, or with the white of an egge, put tho≈øe cakes being dryed by them≈øelves into a Winde Furnace S S S, with coales, and calcine them in a mo≈øt ≈øtrong fire for the ≈øpace of foure or five houres. When the furnace is cold take them out, and if they be not ≈øufficiently calcined the fir≈øt time, (which is known by their giving but little light,) then reiterate the calcination after the ≈øame manner as before, which is ≈øometimes to be done thrice. That is the be≈øt which is made with the choi≈øe≈øt ≈øtones that are clean, pure, and diaphanous, and gives the be≈øt light. With this being powdered you may make the formes of divers animalls of what ≈øhapes you plea≈øe, which you mu≈øt keep in boxes, and they will receive light from the ≈øun in the day time, give light in the night, or in a darke place, which light will vani≈øh by degrees.

div.head: The vertues of the afore≈øaid preparations of Gold.
div.p:
With the afore≈øaid preparations the Ancients did not only pre≈øerve the health and ≈øtrength of their bodies, but al≈øo prolong their lives to a very old age, and not that only, but cured thorowly the Epilep≈øie, Apoplexie, Elephantia ‚Ä¢ ts, Lepro≈øy, Melancholy, Madne≈ø≈øe, the Quartain, the Gout, Drop≈øue, Pluri ‚Ä¢ y, all manner of Feavers, the Jaundi≈øe, Lues venerea, the Wolfe, Cancer, Noli ne tangere, A≈øthma, Con≈øumption, the Stone, ≈øtopping of Urine, inward Impo≈øtumes, and ≈øuch like di≈øea≈øes, which mo≈øt men account incurable. For there is ≈øuch a potent fire lying in prepared gold, which doth not only con≈øume
deadly humours, but al≈øo renews the very marrow of the bones, and rai≈øeth up the whole body of man being halfe dead.

They that u≈øe any of the≈øe preparations for any of the foregoing di≈øea≈øes, mu≈øt be take them≈øelves to their bed for the ≈øpace of two or three houres, and expect ≈øweating to en≈øue, for indeed it will ≈øend forth ≈øweat plentifully, and with ea≈øe, and leave no impurity or ≈øuperfluity in the whole body. Note that they mu≈øt take it for ten dayes together in appropriated Liquors.

Let young men that expect long life, take any of the afore≈øaid preparations once in a moneth, and in the morning; but they mu≈øt ab≈øtain from meat and drink, till the evening of the ≈øame day, for in that time that matter will be dig ‚Ä¢ ≈øted into the radicall humour; whereby the ≈øtrength of the body is wonderfully increa≈øed, beauty doth flouri≈øh mo≈øt wonderfully, and continues till extream old age.
Let old men take it twice in a moneth, for by this meanes will their old age be fre≈øh till the appointed time of death.
Let young women and maids take it once in a moneth after their men≈øtrua, for by this means they will look fre≈øh and beautifull.
Let women that are in travell take it, and it will help and ≈øtrengthen them to bring forth without much paine, notwith≈øtanding many difficulties.

Let it be given to women that have pa≈øt the years of their men≈øtrua once or twice in a moneth, and it will pre≈øerve them very fre≈øh, and many times cau≈øe their men≈øtrua to returne, and make them capable again of bearing children.
It cures the plague, and expells the matter of a carbuncle by ≈øweat mo≈øt potently.
Whn I ≈øay that this, or it will do thus or thus, I mean any one of the forenamed preparations, viz. Aurum potabile, Oils, or Tincture of gold.

div.head: The preparations of Silver in generall.
div.p: All the ≈øeverall preparations of gold may, except that of Aurum fulminans, be applyed to ≈øilver, of which being thus prepared the vertues are inferiour to tho≈øe of gold, yet come neerer to them then tho≈øe of any other matter what≈øoever, or how≈øoever prepared.
Note that ≈øilver hath ≈øome peculiar preparations which neither gold or any other metalls are capable of.

div.head: A green Tincture of Silver.
div.p: Take fine ≈øilver, and di≈ø≈øolve it in twice ≈øo much rectified Spirit of Nitre, then ab≈øtract halfe of the ≈øaid Spirit in ≈øand, let it ≈øtand a day or two in a cold place, and much of the ≈øilver will ≈øhoot into Cry≈øtals, and in oft doing mo≈øt of it.

The≈øe Cry≈øtals are very bitter, yet may be made into pills, and taken inwardly from three grains to twelve; they purge very ≈øecurely, and gently, and colour the lips, tongue, and mouth, black. If in this di≈ø≈øolution of ≈øilver before it be brought to cry≈øtals, halfe ≈øo much Mercury be di≈ø≈øolved and both ≈øhoot together into cry≈øtalls, you ≈øhall have a ≈øtone not much unlike to allum. This purgeth ≈øooner, and better, and is not ≈øo bitter; It coloureth the nails, hair, skin, if it be di≈ø≈øolved in rain-water; with a lovely brown, red, or black, according as you put more or le≈ø≈øe thereof.

Take of the afore≈øaid cry≈øtalls of ≈øilver, mix with them a like quantity of pure Salt-peter well powdered, then put this mixture into the di≈øtilling ve≈ø≈øell expre≈ø≈øed page 76. at the bottome of which mu≈øt be powdered coales to the thickne≈ø≈øe of two fingers breadth, then make a ≈øtrong fire that the ve≈ø≈øell and coals be red hot, put in a dram of the afore≈øaid mixture, and it will pre≈øently ≈øublime in a ≈øilver fume, into the recipient, which being ≈øetled, put in more, and ≈øo do till you have enough Take out the flowers, and dige≈øt them in the be≈øt alcholizated Spirit of Wine, that thereby the tincture may be extracted, which will be green.

div.head: A green Oil of Silver.
div.p: Take of the above≈øaid cry≈øtals of ≈øilver one part, of Spirit of ≈øalt armoniack two or three parts, dige≈øt them together in a gla≈ø≈øe with a long neck, well ≈øtopt, twelve or fourteen dayes, ≈øo will the ≈øpirit of ≈øalt armoniack be coloured with a very ≈øpecious blew colour, pour it off, and filter it, then put it into a ≈ømall Retort, and draw off mo≈øt of the Spirit of armoniack, and there will remain in the bottome a gra≈øs-green Liquor. Then draw off all the Spirit, and there will remain in the bottome a ≈øalt, which may be purified with Spirit of Wine, or be put into a Retort, and then there will di≈øtill off a ≈øubtle Spirit, and a ≈øharp Oil.
This green Liquor is of great u≈øe for the gilding of all things pre≈øently.

If you take common rain-water di≈øtilled, and di≈ø≈øolve, and dige≈øt the afore≈øaid cry≈øtals of ≈øilver for a few dayes, you ≈øhall after the appearance of divers colours find an e≈ø≈øence at the bottome, not ≈øo bitter as the former, but ≈øweet, and in this Liquor may all metals in a gentle heat by long dige≈øtion be maturated, and made fit for medicine; but note that they mu≈øt fir≈øt be reduced into ≈øalts, for then they are no more dead bodies, but by this preparation have obtained a new life, and are the metals of Philo≈øophers.

div.head: To make Oil of Silver per deliquium.
div.p: Take of the afore≈øaid ≈øalts, or cry≈øtals of ≈øilver, and reverberate them in a very gentle fire, then put them into a cellar on a marble ≈øtone, and they will in two moneths time be re≈øolved into a Liquor.

div.head: To make a Liquor of Silver, that ≈øhall make the gla≈ø≈øe wherein it is ≈øo exceeding cold, that no man is able for the coldne≈ø≈øe thereof to hold it in bis hand any long time.
div.p: Take the afore≈øaid ≈øalt of ≈øilver, pour upon it the ≈øpirit of ≈øalt armoniack and di≈ø≈øolve it throughly, and it will do as above≈øaid.
With a gla≈ø≈øe being full of this Liquor you may conden≈øe the aire into water in the h ‚Ä¢ at of the ≈øummer, as al≈øo freeze water.

div.head: To make ≈øilver as white as ≈ønow.
div.p: Take of the calx of ≈øilver made by the di≈ø≈øolution of it in aqua fortis, dulcifie it, and boyl it in a Lixivium made of ≈øopea≈øhes, and it will be as white as any ≈ønow.

div.head: To make the ≈øilver tree of the Philo≈øophers.
div.p: Take four ounces of aqua fortis; in which di≈ø≈øolve an ounce of fine ≈øilver, then take two ounces of aqua fortis in which is di≈ø≈øolved half an ounce of argent vive, mix the≈øe two Liquors together in a clear gla≈ø≈øe with a pinte of pure water, ≈øtop the gla≈ø≈øe very clo≈øe, and you ≈øhall ≈øee day after day a tree to grow by little and little, which is wonderfull plea≈øant to behold.

I Have ≈øet down ≈øeverall vulgar preparations of gold and ≈øilver, and of almo≈øt all things el≈øe, I ≈øhall now crave leave to give an account of ≈øome philo≈øophicall preparations of the Philo≈øophers gold and ≈øilver. For indeed the Art of preparing of them is the true Alchymie, in compari≈øon of which all the Chymicall di≈øcoveries are but abortives, and found out by accident, viz. by endeavouring after this. I would not have the world beleeve that I pretend to the under≈øtanding of them, yet I would have them know that I am not incredulous as touching the po≈ø≈øibility of that great philo≈øophicall work which many have ≈øo much laboured after, and many have found. To me there is nothing in the world ≈øeemes more po≈ø≈øible, and who≈øoever ≈øhall without prejudice read over the Book entituled the New Light of Alchymie, ≈øhall almo≈øt whether he will or no (unle≈ø≈øe he re≈øolves not to beleeve any thing though never ≈øo credible) be convinced of the po≈ø≈øibility of it. What unworthine≈ø≈øe God ≈øaw in gold more then in other things, that he ≈øhould deny the ≈øeed of multiplication (which is the perfection of the creatures) to it, and give it to all things be≈øides, ≈øeems to me to be a que≈øtion as hard to be re≈øolved, yea, and harder then the finding out the Elixir it ≈øelf, in the di≈øcovering of which the great ‚Ä¢ ≈øt
difficulty is, not to be convinced of the ea≈øine≈ø≈øe thereof. If the preparations were difficult many more would find it out then do (≈øaith Sandiv ‚Ä¢ gius) for they ca≈øt them≈øelves upon mo≈øt difficult operations and are very ‚Ä¢ ubtle in difficult di≈øcoveries which the Philo≈øophers never dr ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ ed of. Nay ≈øaith the afore≈øaid author, if Herme ‚Ä¢
him≈øelf were now living, together with the ‚Ä¢ ubtle-witted Geb ‚Ä¢ n, and mo≈øt pro ‚Ä¢ ound Fa ‚Ä¢ mund Lullie, the would be accounted by our Chymi≈øts not for Philo≈øophers, but rather for learners. They were ignorant of tho≈øe ≈øo many di≈øtillations, ≈øo many circulations, ≈øo many calcinations, and ≈øo many other innumerable operations of Arti≈øts now a dayes u≈øed, which indeed men of this age did find out and inveÃÑ
‚Ä¢ ed out of their books. Yet there is one thing wanting to us which they did, viz. to know how to make the philo≈øophers ≈øtone, or phy≈øical tincture, the proce≈ø≈øes of which according to ≈øome philo≈øophers are the≈øe.

div.head: The proce≈ø≈øe of the Elixir according to Paracel≈øus.
div.p: TAke the minerall Electrum being immature, and made very ≈øubtle, put it into its owne ≈øpheare, that the impurities, and ≈øuperfluiries may be wa≈øhed away, then purge it as much as po≈ø≈øibly you can with Stibium after the Alchymi≈øticall way, le≈øt by its impurity thou ≈øuffer prejudice. Then re≈øolve it in the ≈øtomach of an E≈øtridge, which is brought forth in the earth, and through the ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe of the Eagle is confortated in its vertue.

Now when the Electrum is con≈øumed, and hath after its ≈øolution received the colour of a Mary-gold, doe not forget to reduce it into a ≈øpirituall tran≈øparent e≈ø≈øence, which is like to true Amber, then adde halfe ≈øo much, as the Electrum did weigh before its preparation, of the extended Eagle, and oftentimes ab≈øtract from it
the ≈øtomach of the E≈øtridge, and by this meanes the Electrum will be made more ≈øpirituall. Now when the ≈øtomach of the E≈øtridge is wearied with labour, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to refre≈øh it and alwayes to ab≈øtract it. La≈øtly, when it hath again lo≈øt its ≈øharpne≈ø≈øe adde the tartarizated qu ‚Ä¢ nte≈ø≈øence, yet ≈øo that it be ≈øpoyled of its redne≈øs the height of foure fingers, and that pa≈ø≈øe over with it. This doe ≈øo often till it be of it ≈øelfe white, and when it is enough, and thou ≈øee≈øt that ≈øigne, ≈øublime it. So will the Electrum be converted into the whitene≈øs of an exalted Eagle, and with a little more labour be tran≈ømuted into deep redne≈ø≈øe, and then it is fit for medicine.

div.head: The proce≈ø≈øe of the Elixir according to Divi Le≈øchi Genus Amo.
div.p:
TAke of o ‚Ä¢ r earth through eleaven degrees, eleaven graines, of our gold, and not of the vulgar, one graine, of our lune, not of the vulgar, graines two; but be thou admoni≈øhed that thou take not the gold, and ≈øilver of the vulgar, for they are dead, but take ours which are living, then put them into our fire, and there will thence be made a dry Liquor: Fir≈øt the earth will be re≈øolved into water, which is called the Mercury of Philo≈øophers, and in that water it will re≈øolve the bodies of the Sunne, and Moone, and con≈øume them that there remaine but the tenth part, with one part, and this will be the Humidum Radicale Metallicum. Then take the water of the ≈øalt Nitre of our earth, in which there is a living ≈øtreame if thou digge≈øt the pit knee deep, take therefore the water of it, but take it clear, and ≈øet over it that Humidum Radicale, and put it over the fire of putrefaction and generation, but not ≈øuch
as was that in the fir≈øt operation. Governe all things with a great deale of di≈øcretion, untill there appeare colours like to the taile of a Peacock, govern it by dige≈øting of it, and be not weary, till the≈øe colours cea≈øe, and there appeare throughout the whole, a green colour, and ≈øo of the re≈øt, and when thou ≈øhalt ≈øee in the bottome, a≈øhes of a fiery colour, and the water almo≈øt red, open the ve≈ø≈øell, dip in a feather, and ≈ømeere over ≈øome iron with it, if it tinge, have in readine≈øs that water which is the men≈øtruum of the world (out of the ≈øpheare of the Moone ≈øo often rectified, untill it can calcine gold) put in ≈øo much of that water as was the cold aire, which went in, boyl it again with the former fire untill it tinge again.

div.head: The proce≈ø≈øe of the Philo≈øophers ≈øtone according to Pontanus.
div.p:
TAke the matter, and grinde it with a phy≈øicall contrition, as diligently as may be, then ≈øet it upon the fire‚ñ™ and let the proportion of fire be known, viz. that it only ≈øtirre up the ma ‚Ä¢ ter, and in a ≈øhort time, that fire without any other laying on of hands, will accompli≈øh the whole work, becau≈øe it will putrefie, corrupt, generate, and perfect, and make to appeare the three principall colours, black, white, and red: And by the meanes of our fire, the medicine wil be multiplied, if it be joyned with the crude matter, not only in quantity but al≈øo in vertue. Withall they might therefore ≈øearch out this fire (which is minerall, equall, continuall, vapours not away, except it be too much ≈øtirred up; partakes of ≈øulphur, is taken from el≈øewhere then from the matter; pulle ‚Ä¢ h downe all things, di≈ø≈øolveth, congealeth, and calcines, and is artificiall to find out, and that by a compendious, and neer way, without any co≈øt, at
